Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The sanctions against the school were a punishing blow, and they seemed to what the efforts the school had made to change? Choices:  A: ignore B: enforce C: authoritarian D: yell at E: avoid<n><n>### Response:		A<n>Rational: Sanctions include authoritarian sanctions that force children to do the things that teachers tell them to do, sanctions that offer positive reinforcement when children behave well, and sanctions that allow children to make decisions because of how they behave.<n><n>####<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Instructions:Choose the correct answer from those offered.<n><n>### A: When teachers yell at students for bad behaviour, what do they do to help students? Choices: A: ignore B:enforcementof sanction C: authoritarian sanctions D: authoritative sanctions E: positive reinforcement<n><n><n><n><n><n>### Choices: B, C, A, E<n><n>### Rational:<n>Teachers enforce sanctions, which offer the opposite of rewards by offering consequences when undesired behaviours occur.<n>Teachers use authoritative sanctions or the positive reinforcement of rewards, which provides rewards when children behave in a desirable way.<n>Authoritarian sanctions are used because of how a teacher feels.<n><n><n>####<n>Answer A<n><n>### Choose the correct response from the listed choices.<n><n>### Choice: B<n><n>### Rationale:<n>Reasons: A, C, D<n><n>### Answer:<n>Incorrect<n><n>### Instruct:Answer the following multiple-choice question:<n><n>### Ration:<n>Which best describes an authoritative sanction? A: A reward for unwanted behaviour B: A reward for good behaviour C: A punishments for undesired behaviour D: A punishment for good behaviour<n><n>#### Answer:<n>B- A reward for unwanted behavior.<n><n>### Input/Output:<n><n>### The sanctions against the school that included the school going a year without receiving federal funding were a harsh way to which type of sanction?<n><n>	Choices: A:authoritative B: positive reinforcement C:enforcement D: authoritarian  <n>	<n>### Rationale/Rational:<n>1,2<n><n>### Input from a video (YouTube)<n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The fox walked from the city into the forest, what was it looking for? Choices:  A: pretty flowers. B: hen house C: natural habitat D: storybook E: dense forest<n><n>### Response:		A B C D E <br/><n>#### "A pretty flower"<n>Answer A<n>### 211<n>#### 5 3<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What do people use to absorb extra ink from a fountain pen? Choices:  A: shirt pocket B: calligrapher's hand C: inkwell D: desk drawer E: blotter<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>- A is right because most people do carry them in their shirt pockets.<n>- B is wrong because calligraphers use a different kind of pen, and calligraphy is not as popular as it was in the 18th century so a calligrapher' prefers shirt pockets. Calligraphers don't need to worry about ink absorbing their hand because their hand never touches the paper when writing; they also don't want calligraphy to be messy either.<n>- C is wrong because an inkwell is a container with water where you can put your fountain pen and it will absorb and dilute its own ink rather than being completely saturated by it.<n>- D is wrong because some people leave handwritten notes on their desk for others to read, so leaving ink on your desk drawer is bad because the ink can stain the paper while you are putting your notes in your drawer.<n>- E is right because blotters are made to absorb some of the paper's ink so it doesn't stain your shirt pockets.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Johnny sat on a bench and relaxed after doing a lot of work on his hobby.  Where is he? Choices:  A: state park B: bus depot C: garden D: gym E: rest area<n><n>### Response:		Answer the question based on the clues provided.<n><n>### 100<n>Answer: A: state park<n>#### Rationales: The clue is, "Sat at bench after doing much work". Johnny would likely be at a park after doing work related to a hobby such as reading or writing. Parks are a great place to relax. People would likely go to the park to do their hobbies rather than the gym or the garden.<n><n>### Input : The boss asked to meet the team before each customer presentation to set an agenda and determine presentation goals. What is the best way to do so?<n><n>### Rationales: It would be best to meet with team members after each customer presentation to set and determine goals and expectations so that they are known and expected at the next presentation.<n><n>### Response : Answer the question based on the rationales provided.<n><n>## Rationales: Each item on the to do list should represent something actually done, not something that has been planned.<n><n>### Answer:C<n><n>### 36<n>Answer:D: Rationales: Do to do list only for things you have done. It is too difficult to keep a clear and correct record of things you may do later.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The sensor would just the distance then set off an alarm, the installation expert explained it was called a what kind of sensor? Choices:  A: near B: closeness C: here D: proximity E: this<n><n>### Response:		E (Proximity)<n><n>### Instructions:Write an explanation to accompany your decision.<n><n>### Input<n>The proximity sensor works by utilizing the principle of electromagnetic induction. A coil of wire encircles a strong magnet to produce an induced magnetic field. The two pole pieces of a proximity sensor are formed by the wire coil and magnet, and the two electrical contacts at the other end of the sensor. Proximity sensors are sometimes used on high-speed production lines to detect objects that could be potentially damaging machinery and/or compromise the quality of the finished product.<n>If an object, such as a metal part, comes within a certain distance of the sensor, a signal can be transmitted that either stops the line or warns operators of something that is wrong.<n>#### 1) B:<n><n>### Response<n><n><n>### Instruct:Explain how you would solve the problem below.<n><n>### Response

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What do drugs do? Choices:  A: damage B: cloud mind C: lower i.q D: cause illness E: cause accidents<n><n>### Response:		B: cloud mind<n><n>#### Reason:  A: damage  B: cloud mind  C: lower i. q  D: cause illness  E: cause accident<n><n>### Input::<n>If a person's age is greater than their weight in pounds, do they weigh more than they weigh? Choices: A: yes B: No C: yes and no D: No and no. E: only if they weigh more than.<n><n>### Choice: B<n><n>### Example: A person's age is 30, weight in pounds.<n><n>#### 30 > 60 = <<30>(60)=50>>50 pounds<n><n>Therefore, they only weigh more than they do if they are 50 pounds or more.<n><n>#### Reasoning: Choices C and D are incorrect. If I weigh more than I weigh I would only weigh more when I weigh more. Choice E is also incorrect. There is other possibilities than weighing more than the amount you weigh. For instance, I weigh more than 100 pounds but weigh less than 200 pounds.<n><n>### Input 3: Janet, Eric, and Matt have 3, 3, and 0.5 feet respectively. Which one of the following is the sum of their feet? A: 7 (3 + 3 + 0.5) B: 8 (3 + 3+2) C: 8 (3+3) D: 12 (3+3+0.5) E: 11 0.5<n><n>### Choices A, B, C<n><n>#### 3+3+0=<<3+3+1/2>>3.5<n><n>#### Reason C: Janet, Eric and Matt each weigh 3 ft, 3 ft and 0.75 ft respectively. Therefore, the sum of their feet is 3+3+3.5=<<11.5>>11.5 ft.

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Can you name a good reason for attending school? Choices:  A: get smart B: boredom C: colds and flu D: taking tests E: spend time<n><n>### Response:		Choice A (colour): Boredom!<n><n>### Instructions:<n>1. In the following task, students are provided with a passage and asked to perform a step by step annotation on it.<n><n>2. Students are asked to write the answer to the first task before they do the second one.<n>3. The second task follows the annotation steps given on the previous task.<n>4. The students should read the passage twice before doing the task.<n>```<n>- Read the first task on the previous page - then read the passage again - then answer the two tasks.  23.<n>```<n><n>### InstructioN:Write a passage describing the following: 1. the reason why you are reading this text 2. what you expect to learn from the author 3. 4 rules on writing an essay 4. 5 characteristics of a well-written essay 5. why you choose this subject.<n><n>### Rational:Write an answer for each of the bullets.<n><n>```<n><n>- Reason for reading: Because I need to.<n>- Expectations: I am interested in how to write a good essay.<n>```<n><n><n>### DemostratIoN:The purpose of writing a sentence analysis is for students to practice and develop competence in writing sentence.<n><n>- Rules on writing essays: 1. Be formal, 2. Correct grammar, 2. Correct spelling.<n>- Characteristic of a well written essay: 1. Use correct phrases<n>2. Use correct punctuation.<n><n>### InstrUcion:The purpose of this task is for the students to practice using the correct verb forms. (The first passage deals with the present continuous tense, and the second one, the present perfect tense).<n><n>- 1.	Write 5 lines of English that describes the activities you do everyday. Use the continuous tense in your answer.  22.<n><n> - 2.	The students are provided with a paragraph in which the verbs are not in the present perfect form. Rewrite the paragraph using the present perfect form.  23.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where would you see people in uniform playing with a ball? Choices:  A: hole B: television C: sporting goods store D: pool table E: sporting event<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>C<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>### Choice C:<n>Input text is sports goods store. <n><n>### Sports goods store is not the answer so the right answer would be either D or E<n><n>### Explanation:Answer choices:A hole television C sporting events E sports shop<n><n>### Option B: Answer (TV) has holes so it is not an option<n><n>### Option D:<n>You got it. Option C.<n><n>#### C<n><n>### Input :A person who performs for a sports team in a game. Choices:  A : team B : player C : sport D : league E : coach<n><n>### Examle:<n><n><n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:She needs to visit a bookshop after buying the latest fashion, where should she look? Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:He was receiving workman's compensation, he had tripped over a metal rod while building where? How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where can meat last a long time? Freezing them in the butcher's shop.<n><n>2. Putting them in a freezer in the back for a short period.<n><n>3. Placing meat in a refrigerator for a little while.<n><n>In all of these cases, it is not necessary to freeze meat for a long time. It is just necessary to preserve it from getting warm and ruining the outside. <n><n>This exercise was written by Eric D. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The accountant used a calculator regularly, he kept one at home and one at the what? Choices:  A: desk drawer B: desktop C: office D: wristwatch E: city hall<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: The accountant used a calculators.<n><n>Explain your thinking <n><n>Answer: C: A desk drawer.<n><n><n>Codespace(E)<n>Input:<n><n>```python<n>my_name = "Alex"<n>```<n><n>Describe the Output<n>Explain how to arrive at the appropriate answer. (Hint – think of how to use the input to produce the output that is expected.)<n><n>Desired Output:<n><n>> "Welcome, {my_name}"<n><n><n>### Output<n>Welcome, Alex<n><n><n>### Instructions<n>The function above prints "Welcome, {message} " where "message" is the message variable that is set to whatever is in the "message" variable. For example,<n>```python<n>message = "Alex"<n><n>print("Welcome, {message}")<n>```<n>prints<n><n>```<n>Welcome, Alex.<n>```<n><n>### Demos<n>Input:<n><n><n>Describe the output of the demo.<n><n>The demo prints<n><n><n>Explain how to get the correct output from the function.<n><n>How does the call to the function print "Welcome, {lambda message}"?<n><n>### Output:<n>Welcome, {lambda}<n><n><n>#### Explaining how the demo prints<n>The demo function prints<n><n><n>```python<n>message  = "Alex"<n>print("Welcome{},{message}".format(message, message))<n>```<n><n>```python<n>Welcom, {message}<n>```<n><n>because the function passes in the string "Alex".<n><n>```python<n>print("Welcome,{message}".format("Alex"))<n>```<n><n>```javascript<n>Welcome,Alex<n>```<n><n>The demo outputs the string "Welcome, { message} ". The string "Welcome " is a fixed word. The string " {lex} " will take the value of the variable " lex". Since the word " message " is a fixed word in the demo, the strings "Welcome, " and " {message} " are always printed but the the contents of the "Lex" string varies in the output.<n><n>The demo calls the function using the variable "lex", but the function is expecting two variables. The function needs to change so that it will call the variables "message" and "message". Doing this changes the demos

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:If you're speaking to a lawyer about getting a divorce, what relationship status are you trying to end? How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:WHat leads to someone's death when they are very depressed? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Who is likely yo have a caring heart? Choices:  A: person B: species C: artichoke D: all mammals E: live animal<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Live animals are defined as being capable of independent movement. Caring is described as emotional attachment to an animate being. This would include people as well as species. While a caring heart applies to people, the other choices would have to be a machine, a plant, or live but not caring. A caring heart would encompass all mammals and most live animals.<n><n>### Score:<n><n>* You've answered: Correct<n>* You got: True<n>* Correction:<n>* How to score:<n>* Final Score: <n><n>### Instructions:Your responses are scored using the following rubric. Responses are rated as True or False. Use the rating system to assign score to submitted responses. Scores from multiple rubrics are averaged to generate results<n><n><n>* The following are examples of multiple choice questions that will be scored<n>* **True**<n>* **False**<n><n><n><n>### Rubric : Response to multiple choice questions.<n><n><div class="rubric" <n><n>   | **Point to** | **Explanation** | **Lead-in** |  <n>   | --- | --- | --- |<n>   | score | score your students work | score for each student response |            <n>   | question | multiple choice question #1? | explain what the question is to this task for multiple choice questions |            <n>   | options | Choices : A. B. C. D. E. | Choose from: A - D (other letters will be scored as false - that they don't exist)<n><n><n>   | **Score** | **Score comment if chosen** |  <n>  <n><!--<n>   | **Points** | **Comments** |<n>            <n>### 1<n><n>---<n>### 2<n>***<n>### 7<n>***<n>### ---<n>>>>>>>>>>>> <n>**Total number of scored problems on this quiz**<n><n><n></div> <n><n><n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What will happen to skin pinched in something? Choices:  A: feel cold B: feel pressure C: feel bumpy D: itches E: feel clammy<n><n>### Response:		 A: feel B: feel C: feel D: itches E itches<n><n>### Instructions: Please answer each statement based on the information you was given in the instructions above.<n><n>### Input<n>  Your dad has to be a lot of places for business. He has been in the bathroom a while; you heard farting.<n>Your dad is in the other bathroom too. There are no adults on the floor. When you tell him he's farting, you got a fart smell. The house is in an aisle.<n>####<n>Answer: You were farting, but you didn't hear him fart. Therefore you were farting louder than your dad.<n><n>### Answer:The teacher asked that the students find a number that could be written as sum of different squares.<n>####<n>A student answered 10.<n>####<n>The teacher replied and said that it is false.<n>####<n>If the teacher doesn't know what is an even number then he can't teach.<n>####<n>He will be fired if he knows it and doesn't tell.<n><n>###  Answer:I have found two different ways of dividing 600 by 20. Which one is correct?<n>Based on the information in the instructions above:<n>    The answer to 600 divided by 20 is <<600/20=2>>2. The answer to 6 / 2 is <<6/2=3>>3.<n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where is a tabby cat likely to be happiest? Choices:  A: box B: home C: alley D: lap E: barn<n><n>### Response:		Choices: Box, Home, and Lap<n>### Rationales:  Box Choices: Box Box Box Box Box Box (8 times)<n>Home: Home<n>Lap: Lap<n>Alley: Alley Alley Alley Al<n>Barn: Barn Barn Barn Bar<n><n>### Reference:<n>[Ask Lauren](https://asklauren.com/answer.php?question=586664)

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:There weren't potatoes but actually a snake in his what? Choices:  A: burlap sack B: hot country C: purse D: pet shops E: deep grass<n><n>### Response:		Input not correct.<n><n>### Rationale:Janet has 48 and Mara has 52 and Brenda has 68. Janet 48 (60 - 12) Mara has 64 (52 + 12). Brenda has 60 (52 - 8). Therefore, Janet and Mara divide the numbers evenly:Janet: 48 ÷ 2 = 24Brenda: 30 ÷ 3 = 10. Since Brenda needs 1/3 more than Janet, 24 + 10 = 34. Mara needs 40, so she gets 24 (34). She takes 2 more from Mara and she keeps the remaining 42. There, she got 48. Janet and Brenda keep their original cards. Brenda now has 68, Mara (Brenda's partner) has 48, and Janet has 48.<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Answer:<n>There weren't pots in him either!<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Mara would give Janet 48 cards since Brenda 68 Brenda would give Mara 48 cards.<n><n>### Output:<n>The answer was 61 not 34<n><n>### Rene<n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The president had to make a decision regarding the hate attack on his country, what did he do? Choices:  A: wage war B: fight enemy C: kill D: destroy enemy E: attacked his country<n><n>### Response:		A<n>### Instruction Description:<n><n>### Dem 1:<n> Input:I hate the country with the population >430k and density>600/km**2**. 100 k is below the country population and 15>600km**2**.<n> Output:100 is lower than the population and 15 is smaller than 600km**^2**.<n><n>### Demo Response:<n> Output: 100 < country population and 10 > density of countries with population > 430,000.<n><n>### Input<n>The area of my country is >26630000 km**^2** and the density is >43000000/km**^2**<n>Output: 100 k > my country population and 12 > 430 km**^2<n><n>Output: 12 is below the density of my country and 100 k < my country.<n><n>### Answer:<n>Output: 15 < 430.<n><n>## 1<n><n>## 1.  I hate my country.<n>## 2.<n>What is the highest and lowest number between 19 and 20?<n>```<n>Response:  20<n>```<n><n>## 3.  I hate the country with density more than 119km.<n>## 4.<n>```javascript<n>function largest(list) {<n>    var x = list[0];<n>    var largest = x;<n>    var secondLargest = x;<n>    for (var i = 1; i < list.length; i++) {<n>      if (largest < list[i]) {<n>        largest = list[i];<n>      }<n>      if (largast > largest && largest > secondLargest) {<n>        secondLargest = largest;<n>      }<n>    }<n>    console.log(largest, secondLargest, x);<n>  }<n>```<n><n>## What is the next number in the sequence after 1, -4, -16, -36, -64, -125, -216, ………?<n>```<n>Response 1056<n>```<n>## Output is always negative.<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:If you tell you boss your suffering from boredom they'll likely tell you to get back to what? Choices:  A: dream B: fiddle C: watch film D: see new E: work<n><n>### Response:		I need your help to solve this I have no idea how to do this and I've done 5 of these so far. Please help<n><n>### Input if statement if A <= 10 then A = 'H' else print 'e'<n><n># Instructions:<n><n># Demonstration of solution:<n><n>```python<n># Declare two variables.<n>A = None<n>B = None<n><n># Change the value of value of A. We have value = 10 before the operation, and value = False after the operation.<n>A = 10 if A >= 10 else 10<n><n># Change the values of the variables in the same way.<n>B = B if B == 10 else 2<n><n># Combining the results in a single condition.<n>result = (B == 10 and A >= 10) or (A < 10) and (B == 2)<n>```<n><n># Rationales:<n><n># Input<n><n>```python<n>if A <= 10:<n>    A = "H"<n>else:<n>    print "e"<n>```<n><n># Response<n><n>```python<n>A = 12 if A <= 12 else 10<n>B = 10 if B <= 10 else 9<n><n>if A =="H" and B =="H":<n>    print "H"<n>else if A =="H" or B =="e":<n>    print "f"<n>```<n><n>### Input If Janet has 9<n>then Brenda has 9<n>If Brenda has 10<n><n>then Janet has 10<n>Else<n>   If Janet has 11<n> then Brenda has 11<n> Else<n>  print<n>```<n><n># Expected Output<n><n>```python<n>If Janet has 9 more cards then Brenda<n> If Brenda has twice as many cards than Janet<n><n> Then Janet has 24 more cards than Brenda<n>```<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:An expressway can suffer from traffic, this traffic gets worse the closer you get to any what? Choices:  A: michigan B: map C: american city D: rest stops E: country<n><n>### Response:		The closer you get to an exit, the more it will cause delays since you have a limited number of exits, this will result in traffic congestion at the exits.  Therefore, The closer you get to any exits will result in traffic congesting the area.<n><n>### Input<n>An expressway can suffer form traffic, this traffic gets worst the further away from its origin you get. What do experts call an area where two roads intersect if they are both expressways at the point where they intersect?<n>Explanation: This answer will be the same as above since it is traffic that does not lead to exits, so, traffic will not lead to congestion.<n>#### Rest Stops<n><n>Response: The question above states that traffic gets worse the closer one is to an exit.<n><n>Therefore, If there is traffic on an expressway, getting further from its origin will worsen the traffic as it gets further from the location it is coming from.<n><n>### Concept:<n>1. If traffic worsens the closer one is to the origin, then the traffic will worsen as one gets closer to rest stops.<n>2. Traffic worsens and rest stops will increase as one gets closer to the origin.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What can someone feeling happiness fall into? Choices:  A: lead to laughter B: love C: laughter D: smiles E: tears<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Rationale: Happiness leads to laughter, love, and smiles. However, it falls into tears for those who have no sense of joy.

If Brenda is five years older than Jane, how old are they? Choices: A: 23 B: 19 C: 21 D: 17 E: 28<n><n>### Raison:<n>If Brenda is three times as older as Jane, then the difference = 3 - 1 = <<3-1=2>>2 years.<n>If Brenda is five years, the difference = 5 - <<2>>2 = <<5-2=3>>3 years<n><n>### True Or False:False<n><n>## Demonstrated:<n>The above statement is not correct because there is no information about the age of Brenda and Jane!<n><n>## Instrucions:The numbers 1 through 9 can be in three of the squares. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Though nearby, an apple from an apple tree where would be an imported product to the USA? Choices:  A: ohio B: washington state C: alaska D: canada E: flowers<n><n>### Response:		<n>C<n><n>### Input : A computer has 14 times as many bytes as a cell phone. The cell phone has 24 bytes. The computer has 7 times as many bytes as the cell phone. How many does the cell phone have?<n><n>1. 24 bytes<n><n>### Input  : <n>Write an algorithm that determines the total number of triangles that form a figure.<n><n>1. 36<n>2. 6<n>3. 39<n>4. 49<n><n>### Solution<n>``` python<n>def triangle(side_set, center_set):<n>  side_set.sort()<n>  center_set.sort() <n>  sides = len(side_set)<n>  center = len(center_set)<n>  <n>  if sides > center:<n>    triangles = 0<n>    <n>  if sides < center:<n>      triangles = (sides*(sides-2)*center/4) - 2<n>    <n>  if center < sides:<n>    triangles += (center*(center-2)*(sides-3)/4)<n><n>return triangles<n>```<n>### Test:<n>``` python<n>triangles = triangle([0, 1, 2, 3], [0, 0, 0, -1])<n><n>print(triangles)<n><n>>>> 2<n>```<n>``` pyhton<n>triangles = triangle ([-30, 10, -21, -22, -33], [100, 50, -10, -1, 1, 0])<n>```<n>``` python<n>print(triangles == 139)<n><n>>>> True<n>```<n>``` python <n>triangles = triangle(["100.10","75.25", "38.38", "27.27"], ["123","125","125","305"])<n>```<n>``` python  <n>print(triangles + " " + triangles + " " + triangle(["1010","2110", "3030","0030", "0000", "0063"], ["63.00","43.00", "30.00","6

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Eating breakfast in bed can make you feel what, assuming that you don't spill anything? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The judge did not take this part of the job lightly, the man was guilty but it was his passing sentence that condemned the man to what? Choices:  A: go to jail B: incarceration C: intercourse D: death E: judgement<n><n>### Response:		D- Judgement<n><n>## Solution:<n>-Input<n>Input: <code>The judge did not take it lightly, he had the man condemned to what?</code><n><n>-Response<n>-Rationale<n>Firstly, what is the judge supposed to pass sentence as for? Condemen? No way can he have 2 subjects in 1 sentence? What is "it"?<n><n>Secondly, the man is condemned to what? <Sentence 1> The Judge has already passed the sentence for that man. <Sentence 2> You cannot "condemn a man". Only an entity can take actions by themsleves. If the judge does not want to give sentence directly, he may just use 1 sentence "The man needs to be incarcerated". Then, he does not need to use such weird phrases (noobie language) to let those robots to "pass sentence" to the man.<n>And in the end....what is <Sentence 3>? The sentence is completed! What else!?!?<n><n>### Other languages<n>-Go [here](https://codefellows.github.io/codefellows-qa/questions/questions.html)<n>-In case of any difficulty, please feel free to ask a question<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where could you put a dollar that would make it hard to get out without breaking? Their test was on the same day when they got to school.  Tom is in the next room.<n>A rationalize:  Write and expression, equation, or formula that can be used<n><n>Input: Linda weighed 102.5 lbs on her scale at an airport.<n>She then went home and weighed on her doctor's office scale and<n>found that she weighed 108.2 lbs there <n>What will the correct answer be when she weighs on the doctor weighing in an elevator at 54.5 ft?<n><n><n>### Input A: A pest has killed the seedlings planted in the first row.<n><n>Input B:  He killed the planting in a way that the planting in the last row were in the same position as the one from the first row when planting was completed.<n><n>### Output:<n>A rationalized answer of how many planters is the pest in all.<n>```sh<n>#!/bin/bash<n>plant_num(){<n>    echo -e "Input: $1"<n>    echo -e "$2"<n>    output=$2<n>    echo -e $output<n>    if [ $output = 0 ]<n>    then<n>        plant=$1 <n>        echo "a"<n>    else<n>        if [ $output -lt $1 ]<n>        then<n>            echo "b"<n>        else<n>            echo 2"c"<n>        fi<n>    fi<n>}<n><n>###<n>plant_num 7 3<n>####<n>a<n>###<n>plant = $plant_num 4<n>###<n>if [[ $plant_num -gt 7 ]]<n>then<n>    echo "c"<n>else <n>    echo a<n>fi<n>```<n><n>### Output B:<n>### <n>if [ $(($plant+1)) -gt $plant_num ] <n>then<n>a<n>else<n>c<n>fi<n>```<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:After eating a dinner of uncooked chicken, what was felt by the poor man? Choices:  A: indigestion B: died C: illness D: feel better E: throwing up<n><n>### Response:		A. Answer should be A.<n><n>### Rationale:In our everyday life, food is an essential component. After eating a meal, you might feel that either you felt your stomach ache or your stomach is too tightly clamped. This feeling is known to be a type of indigestion.<n><n>### Input 1:The dog had eaten a chocolate cake that night. The owner was in a dilemma because he did not know what remedy to use on the dog.<n><n>### Choices:  A. give a tasty vegetables to him  B. feed him chocolate cake C. feed him his fave biscuits D. take him to the vet <n><n><n>### Rationales:<n>Dog's owner should take the dog to a veterinarian hospital because the dog may be allergic to the chocolate cake.<n><n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:If one sees a fox and is standing in a landlocked, southern state, where is this person? Choices:  A: at the zoo B: south carolina C: hen house D: louisiana E: arkansas<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>C) south carolina<n><n>### Why:<n>We know that the person is in the south since the fox is there, and we know its landlocked. <n><n>C) "south carolina" is given in the question as a possible landlocked southern state, thus "south" "carolina" are both in the south. <n><n>### Rationales (if necessary):<n>For each choice, we can either eliminate a choice (since one is false), or we can eliminate a place.<n><n>D: "South Louisiana" would be false.<n><n>B: "south Carolina" wouldn't say if they were close to a zoo or not.<n><n>E: "Arkansas" wouldn't say anything about being in the south.<n><n>A: "At the zoo" is true to the question, and "the zoo" would be a landlocked state. We can eliminate "the zoo" and "Arkansas" for sure.<n><n>A: The answer is "South Carribean" because it is the only choice that gives all three conditions to the question.<n><n>## Recipient:<n>1. 1.2.3.<n><n>## Subject:<n>Mini Quiz 2.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:If I am suffering from boredom, and I want to do something with a dictionary, what would help? Choices:  A: do crossword puzzle B: see art C: give up D: grocery shop E: play chess<n><n>### Response:		<n>Both, A and B<n><n>### Instructions:For each letter in the word, use the computer dictionary to find the number of words that are also spelled with that letter. So, the letter W in the word 'WORD' would be the letter W when it comes to the number of words that you found using the computer dictionary.<n><n>### Solution:<n>For each letter in the input word, put the letter W before and after the letter<n>the sum of all the found words.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>The letter W appears once after every letter of the word so we should add 1 for the number of letters of the word and a 1 to make it the letter W. Hence, the output is W. So, we get a number of words W. Therefore, the sum of all the words found is the total. For the word, "WORD" is:<n><n>|letter|number of found words |Total  <n>:---:|:---:|:---------<n>|W|1|1  <n>|O||1  <n>|R||1  <n>D||1  <n>T||1  <n><n>### Output:1+1+1+1=7<n><n>### Input<n>Find an expression that is different from 25 when multiplied by<n>5 or when divided by 2. Write the expression in the form of an integer. If<n>there is not one, write "Not Possible".<n><n>### Rationale (Examples)<n>Not Possible<n><n>### Output<n>41<n><n>### Instraction<n>In 2016, 90 children were playing at the playground. They all play for 2 hours each day. Their average age was 10. What was the age of the oldest child at that time?<n><n><n>### Ratiation (Example)<n><n>Average ages of 26 children are 10. The average age of the oldest is 10/26 * 10 = 38 years<n><n>### Response<n><n><n>### Instruption (Example)<n><n>How much does it cost to fill a hot water bottle when you charge 45p for the first hour and 50p per subsequent hour? For 16 hours.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Whether it's popped, grilled, or canned people like to what? Choices:  A: expect to die B: believe in god C: stay in D: watch movies E: eat corn<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input:Whether it' is popped, grilled or canned people like... Choices A: expect to die<br><n>Rationales:Expected to die means to die early, if you are very sickly or very old.<n><br>Choice B: believe in god<br><n>Rationale:A lot of people believe in God, but they don't have to tell it.<n><br>Choices C: stay in<br><n>Rationates:If they eat on food, they are eating in.<n><br> Choice D: watch movies<br><n>Rations:If something has a lot of entertainment or is on T.V., there is a movie.<n><br><n>Choice E: eat corn<br><n>Ratios:There is a lot of corn in many foods, one of those being popcorn.<n>Answer: Watch a lot of movies.<n><n>### Input<n>What's an important part in a science?<n><n>### Response<n>Chemistry is an important science because it's in everything you eat and use.<n>#### Chemistry <n>Answer: Chemistry<n><n>### Instuction:<n>Write a sentence with 5 words that contain the letter "A". It will take all of your writing skills.)<n><n>Response: I am a person, I am a bear, I love to eat. I am a bear for all to see.<n><n>### Answer:<n>I'm a person, I'm a bear, I love pizza and macaroni. I'm a bear for all to eat.<n>#### Answer: I am a person<n><n>### Insturctions:<n>Write a mathematical expression with two variables in exponent whose sum is -2.<n><n>### Response & Question:<n>Input: Write an expression with two exponential variables that add up to -2.<n><n>Rationa: (2x)^(3/4) and -(2x)^(3) = -2<n><n>Input: Write an expr. with two variables whose sum is -2<n><n>Ratio: 1/8 and 1

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where can the legs of a stool be built? The lady bought all items in the bottom of the cart and half the items in the top.<n><n>### Response and Reasoning:<n>The lady bought all items in bottom of the cart and bought half of the items in the top of each cart.<n>There are three carts in picture which had 3 items and the bottom of the cart had 2 items.<n>Therefore, it shows the total items in her shopping is 2 items.<n>The total price of her shopping is £380.83.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>I chose the correct answer because we all know that she bought all items in the middle of the cart because she is only in the top half of the three carts in her shopping that is on the 3rd cart.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>The total price of the shopping was £380.12 and we all know she bought all items in top.<n><n>---<n><a href="https://www.freecodecamp.org/learn/javascript-algorithm-problem-solving/algorithm-solution/how-do-you-check-to-see-if-a-phone-number-contains-only-digits-and-has-the-correct-length-for-a-phone-num"></a><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where would you find some swords in your house? Choices:  A: sheath B: sword closet C: collection D: container called scabbard E: museum<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## 13 questions.<n><n>### Input<n>Where did Lidia find the best chocolates? E: Lidia's roommate told her.<n><n>### Explanation<n>The best chocolates were $3 in Lidia's room mate's room.<n><n>### Response<n>E<n><n>### Instructiions:Answer the following multiplechoice question.<n><n>1. Most expensive.<n><n>1. Roommate<n><n>### Response B<n>Answer 3.<n><n>### Conclusion:<n>The response should describe both order in which the chocolates were found and what was purchased.<n><n>### Comment:<n>Lidia found:<n>-The least expensive chocolates in the store.<n>-In the bathroom where they were $1.50 each.<n>-The best chocolat in her room mates room for about $15. <n>-She could not find the best chocolatees in the library after they were moved there because the had already been bought from M.A.R,A.<n><n>### Multiple Choice question:<n>Lidia was comparing chocolates to spend the most money on. What else could she buy with that money besides chocolates?<n><n>What does this response mean?<n><n>Lidia could buy the most expensive chocolate in the first store or buy clothes.<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The garage had light sensors and automatic doors, what kind of house was it? Choices:  A: modern house B: building C: townhouse D: neighbor's house E: downtown<n><n>### Response:		The garage had sensor and automatic doors, so it is a modern house, and the townhouse is on downtown.<n><n>### Input #2:The store was out of the best ice cream in the country? Choices: A : No B : Yes <n><n>### Response #2: <n>There was no best ice cream, so it is No.<n><n>### 2.3:<n><n>## Input:<n>The restaurant had 60 guests who finished their food but paid for their own. The restaurant had 87 guests who paid for their food. The restaurant offered coupons, but none of the guests took them <n><n>## Response:<n>None of the guest took the coupon they had 60 plus 87 guests and 60 guests paid for their meal, which mean that 20 guests did not pay for their food.<n><n>## Instruction:Answer the question below. Rationales to 3rd and 4th questions are given in the comment 3 blocks below.<n>## Demonstration: <n><n>45% + 37% = <<45%+37%=82%>><n>81% - 80% = <<81%-80%=1%>><n>91% + 80% =<<91%+80%=191>>191%<n>191/2 = <<191/2=>95>>95<n>18 - 11 = <<18-11=7>><n><n>45/2 = <<45/2=22.5>><n>81/3 =<<81/3=27>><n><n>%2 - 5 = <<%2-5=2>><n>%3 - 2 =<<%3-2=1>><n>%5 - %9 = <<%5-%9=%4>><n><n><n>## Response: <n>33% = <<33%>=33/3===1><n><n>50% =<<50%=50//2<n><n>25.5 % = <<25.5%=25.5/2=12%> <n><n>33% - 1% =<<33%"- 1"=32%>><n><n>50%

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Billy went away because his parents were fighting and he didn't want to stay where? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where do most people keep magazines? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The lady was getting worked up about the article explaining the uptick in accidents in their area, but her husband was dismissive of it stating that accidents what? Choices:  A: happen to people B: hurt people C: happen anytime D: happen often E: happen anywhere<n><n>### Response:		D. happen anywhere.<n><n>#### <n>Accidents happen everywhere not just in one area, so  accidents happen to many people worldwide. Since most accidents are caused by humans, it is possible that accidents are happening where people go to eat, work, play (sports, video games, etc...).<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>You may use the following prompt to complete the response.<n><n>### Prompt:Rosa can tell time to the nearest half-hour. She sets her watch to 11:25 and needs to know how many minutes are before noon on her watch. Write a response that contains a correctly formatted and accurately completed code block.<n>```<n>#!/usr/bin/env python3<n><n>time = input("The time is :")<n>time = [int(hour) for hour in [time]]<n>t = int(time[0])<n>hh = t // 24 #hour<n>mm = t % 60 #minutes<n>mm = mm // 60 #seconds<n><n>min_sec = mm*60 #min seconds<n>min_sec = min_sec+(mm%60) #min +sec<n><n>if (mm%60) < 30:<n>    secs = (mm % 60)/ (30*60)<n>    h30 = hh + secs * 30<n>    print(h30, min_sec)<n>else:<n>    print(hh, min_sec) <n><n>```<n><n>### Instances:<n>```<n>#!/bin/python3<n>time = input("Time is :") #Input<n>time = [int('time')] #Convert time into int[] (convert time into seconds)<n>t = int(int(time)//24) #Convert seconds/minutes/hours to int<n>mm = int(time) % 60<n>hh = int(t)<n>mm = mm/60<n>min_sec = (mm*60) #Minutes<n>min_sec = int(min_sec % 60) #Seconds<n>hh = hh + min_sec * t<n>if(mm > 30):<n>    secs = mm/30 #Minutes and sec<n>    h30=hh+30*secs<n>else:<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:A person takes a seat to watch a movie, where is he? Choices:  A: in cinema B: at the park C: martorell D: jeep E: airplane<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rationale:He will answer that he is in Cinema but not so.

The clouds are not at ground level.<n><n>#### The radio station answer is incorrect because James lived in a tower and could see clouds. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:If people are vegetarian, what do they do more of? Choices:  A: believe in god B: sun themselves C: eat hamburgers D: gain wealth E: eat plants<n><n>### Response:		<n>Rationales:People who are vegetarian are those that do not eat meat so they do more things(eating plants) as a group.<n><n>### Output:<n>Choices: A: believe in god C: eat hamburgees D: gain wealth<n><n>#### Answer: 24<n>There are <<24>>24 choices. Answer:C<n><n>### Input<n><n>#### A: 2 B: 3 C: 5 D: 10 E: -1<n>#### F:18 G: 15 H: -18 I: -15<n><n>### Input 6:<n><n>#### Answer 4 5 2 1 6.<n><n>### Input Input<n><n>#### A,43 B,13 C,35 D,85 E,64<n><n>#### 549<n><n>### B: 2<n>C: 4  D: -16 E: 2<n>F:22 G: 7 E: 6<n><n>### F - 12<n>G = F + E<n><n>### F:8<n>G:10<n><n>### G - 3<n>G = F + G<n><n>### F<n><n>### A: 9 B: 5 C: 7 D: 3 E: 3<n>```javascript // 90+50+25=175<n>```<n>### F:55 <n>F: 30  <n>G: 80<n>```javascript if statement(condition)<n><n>```<n><n>### If we want to write a single line, we can insert a blank line with '\n'.<n>### The '\n' represents a newline.<n><n>### \n<n>### \t<n>### |<n>### \r<n>### \x1B<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What do humans do when they want to reproduce? Choices:  A: eat ice cream B: have sex C: sit down D: make mistakes E: hear sounds<n><n>### Response:		D.<n><n>### Explanation:Humans reproduce sexually.<n><n>### 4<n>### Instruction:: Choose the choice that correctly completes the statement: Choices for 3: 0 : 1 : 2 : 6<n>### Explanations:0 : 1 : If 1 is multiplied by 6, then 1 × 7 = <<1x7=7>>7 and 1 × 6 = <<1x6=6>>6<n><n>#### 3<n>### Input: How many integers from 1 to 10 will not be evenly divisible by 4? Choices: A: 1 B: 2 C: 3 D: 5 E: 6<n><n>### Response::C.<n>Rationales:Every multiple of 4 starting from 1 to 3, inlucding 4 itself, will be evenly divisible for 4.<n><n>### Input:: What is the sum of the first nonzero digit in each of the following numbers? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where is a monkey likely to be found in the rainforest? Choices:  A: tree tops B: rain forest C: zoological gardens D: great outdoors E: zoo<n><n>### Response:		<n>- If the choice is A: tree tops a monkey likely to found is tree tops<n>- If the choice choice is B: rain forest a monkey likely to is rain forest<n>- If the choice choices are C: zoological gardenses a monkey likely to not found is zoological gardenses, however, if the choice E: zoo the monkey is likely to be zoo.<n><n><n><n>

Choices:  A: cupboard B: countertop C: water D: hardware department E: england<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: Where do you keep a teapot?(Choices:  A: water B: countertop C= hardware department D: england)<n><n>### Rationale:<n>#### A: water<n>The correct response<n><n>#### B: countertop<n><n>This is incorrect since:<n>The teakettle would be kept on the countertop.<n><n>#### C: hardware department<n><n>The tea pot would not be in the hardware department because it is not a piece of hardware.<n><n>#### D: england<n><n>The teapot would not be kept in england because this question is about a teapot and not an english breakfast<n><n>#### E: cupboard<n><n>This is incorrect because:<n>"Cupboard" is not a valid response since the teapot is not in the cupboard.<n><n>### Inquiry:If you use a mover to move a table and it was 3 meters away, how would the mover know to stand 2 m away from the table?<n><n>### Response<n>Input: If you use a mover, to move a table it was 3 meters for how would the mover stand 2 meters away from the table.<n><n>#### 2<n>Answer: The mover would stand 2 meters away (in the same direction as the table, away from it).<n><n>*Since the table cannot move, that would be its "still," and the 4 meters distance would refer to the total distance from one end to another end of the table(=8 m).<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The disease was spreading fast, so what were researchers desperately seeking? Choices:  A: cause spots on leaf B: healthy C: wellness D: ball stopped E: cure<n><n>### Response:		<n>*C: healthy*<n><n>### Rationales: A: cause spots means the spot causes the disease whereas disease causes the spots.<n>B: healthy means disease-free hence the disease has nothing to do with health so it is a wrong answer choices.<n>D: ball stopped means stopping the ball for health, which is also not the desired result.<n>E: cure means to stop the disease.<n>So, we finally came to healthy, which is what the researchers' desired.<n>

The given options are:<n><n>### <n><n>Answer:  Australia<n><n>### Instaction:Answer the following question based on the given information.<n><n>### There are more dogs than cats in Tucson, Arizona, but there are more cats than dogs in San Francisco, California. How do they compare?<n><n>### Example (input and Rationale):  130 dogs  +  60 cats = <<130+60=190>>190 dogs are in Tucson, Arizonia.<n>190-30 = <<190-3=120>>120 dogs are in Tuscon and 100 dogs are in San Francisco. There are more dogs in Tucson than SF (190-100=<<90>>90 dogs). In San Francisco there are 100 cats more than 100 dogs (60-30=<<3>>3 cats). Total: 130 + 3 = <<133>>133 cats and dogs <n><n>### Answer:  More Dogs in Tuscon and More Cats in SF<n><n>### Instraction:Answer the following multiple Choice question.<n><n>## Input:You need tuna for the sandwiches tomorrow, and your favorite grocery store doesn't carry it any more. Choices: 1: Get tuna at the local grocer, who may run out of the stuff again soon. 2: Order a supply from the Web site that offers the best price. 3: Buy from the wholesaler, who promises you'll never run short again.<n><n>## Instruction to the Student: How could the above instruction be modified to include a 2nd Choice as an alternative?<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Nowadays people have smart ones, but at one time it was cutting edge to have a tiny calculator on your what? Choices:  A: mobile phone B: wristwatch C: briefcase D: office E: desktop<n><n>### Response:		Briefcase. The correct response is "B."<n>

A person can use their freedom of speech to protest. To protest, a person can talk with others in order to support or oppose a cause.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>It's most likely that a person would take it to court in order to institute civil action.<n><n>#### A<n>This choice is incorrect because it's not a feeling.<n><n>#### B<n>This choice is correct because a person might be tired, so they might take action.<n><n>#### C<n>This choice is incorrect as anger is not a cause for court cases.<n><n>#### D<n>This choice is incorrect.<n><n>#### E<n>This choice is correct as the court case would make people aware.<n><n>### Reference<n>Given the prompt [In this lesson we examined how a sentence is constructed by its structure.] in the section [Sentence Structure], write a response that addresses the task.<n><n>### Example:<n>Write the sentence 'Brenda has the same number of cards as Mara and Janet combined.'<n><n>### Instructions:Reply to this post with a revised sentence by doing one of the following:<n>Answering a different question from this one:<n>Replying with a correct answer to this question:<n>Replying with incorrect answer to this question.<n><n>## Instructing:Written Expression - Sentence Combinations<n>Answer the following instruction.<n><n>## Demonstration: <n>To find the difference of one number from another, subtract the second number from the first.  <n><n>## Writing: <n>For the following, determine if each sentence requires a capital letter. <n><n>### Choice:A) The cat has eight different colors.  <n><n>### Choices: B) The cats has eight colors.  <n><n>To find the difference between two numbers, subtract one number from the second number. You will first need to arrange the numbers from greatest to least.  <n>You can use the following equation to find the average:<n>[Ln(a + b)/2] / [a + b]     <n><n>## Rationale: <n>The average is determined by the numbers inside the function, and will not apply with the two choices given.<n><n>### Choic:C)

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What can happen in your mind while sleeping? Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:If I take my heifer out East, where's a place we might end up? Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Water is an important ingredient in what sugary beverage? Choices:  A. the sum of all the cash flows that a company will generate<n>B. the price for which the company's stock was sold to investors<n>C. the amount that a company receives on the sale of equipment<n>D. the price at which the stock was bought in the market E. a cash flow that a company has not received because a customer did not pay on time<n><n>### Rationales : The correct answer is the sum of all the money that a company will earn/generate from its investments, including all the cash inflows and outflows for products, services and other transactions it had over a certain period of time. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where would there be a connection to go to another place? Choices:  A: wires B: electrical circuit C: computer network D: wall E: freeway<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>1. The network is connected to another place through wires.<n><n>A wall has no connection to another place.<n><n>B. No.<n><n>A wire has no connection to another<n>place. An electrical circuit has a connection to another place. To go to another place,<n>however, there must be a way for data to leave the computer in order to reach the<n>new destination.<n>In a computer network, there are wires that connect the devices in the network to<n>other devices and the outside.<n><n>A freeway has a connection to go to a new place using different paths.<n><n>In a network, data from the computers on the network is exchanged<n>via the network. It passes from one computer to another on its own path that it takes by following a predefined route called a<n>routing algorithm. One computer, called a router, decides where to route the<n>information.<n><n>2. A: The wall is in the building. B: The wall is not in the building. C: The router is in the building<n><n>D: Wall is not in the building<n><n>A network does not contain walls or other parts of<n>buildings.<n><n>B Networks are created for sharing information among<n>different computers. The router is the computer that decides where to route<n>communication traffic among a group of interconnected networks.<n><n>A freight is not in the building, so no, that is not a<n>router.<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>1.<n><n>1. A<n><n>2..<n><n><n>### Instructions<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>### C: The wall is not a computer. D: Freeways or highways are not computers.<n><n>The router's function is to determine<n>which path it will take to get from one destination to another. A computer is a device with a CPU (central processing unit), memory, hard drive, etc. that performs<n>calculations and makes decisions by following input it receives through the keyboard or a connected device. To answer the<n>question correctly, you must differentiate between the router and the wall.<n>Therefore, the answer to 1 is C.<n><n>You would not connect an electrical circuit to a freeway or highway. You<n>would connect an electrical circuit through wires. That would be answer D.<n><n>You must also be able to

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What white meat goes well with potatos? Choices:  A: kitchen cupboard B: maryland C: chicken D: tuna E: pantry<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>1. Kitchen cupboard has a white meat and potato ingredient: pantry.<n>2. Maryland has a white meat and a potato ingredient<n>3. Chicken has a white meat and no potato ingredient.<n>4. Tuna is white meat and has no potato ingredients.<n>5. Pantry does not have potato ingredients, but does have a white meat ingredient, kitchen cupboard.<n><n>### Input<n><n>#### Question: Which one of these words doesn't belong on a grocery list? You are free to use context clues as you answer<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>1. List: list:<n>2. List: grocery:<n>3. List: list grocery:<n>4. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where would a human expect to find manufacturing operations? Choices A: machine, device, operator B: machine, tool, operator C: tool, machine, operator D: tool, device, operator E: device, tool, operator<n><n>### Response A:A: machine, device, operators<n><n>### Rationales:A: A machine requires an operator to start it. Thus, an operator is a person who runs a machine.<n><n>### R: A: Device. A device is a machine or tool that requires a person to operate it.<n><n>### A: A: To keep a device working, it requires a person to operate the device.<n><n>### B: B: A machine. A machine is a device or tool that requires a human to operate it.<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where would people be looking at some things which can move, but are not moving? Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:If you're standing in line and the line isn't moving what might you feel?
