This is a multiple choice so it needs to be B) queueing up.<n><n>- Queuing up <n><n>Choose the answer<n><n>### Exemplary work:<n>```<n># input:<n>If I am in a line but the line isn't going I might feel<n>A: order<n>B: queueing up<n>C: wait turn<n>D: fatigue<n>E: anger<n><n># Answer:<n>I choose the one or only one since this is multiple choice.<n>My answer is B) queueing up<n>```<n><n>### Crediting the solution to the original author<n>```<n># Inspired by the first chapter of Code, Teach, and Refactor:  [https://github.com/CodeTeachRefactor/Code-Teach-and-Refactor/commit/5da6999d747f0a4e90c825140d7f082d159f8595](https://github.com)<n>```<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:If I wanted to store dirt in my home, where could I put it? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Learning usually leads to greater what? Choices:  A: get to know B: gain knowledge C: intelligence D: education E: gaining knowledge<n><n>### Response:		A <n><n>### Rationale: Learning usually leads to intelligence, or gaining knowledge, BUT often in return, it does affect or alter your thoughts and opinions as well. Learning is what you gain from experience.<n><n>#### <n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input;  The correct response would be to create a new thread or reply to an existing thread. <n><n>### Response;  I just created a thread in one of the classroom forums, here: <n>https://community.safetynet.com/ideas/5250.<n><n>####<n>Answer: Create New Thread<n><n>### Input : Explain the following expression.<n><n>### Rationales :  5/0 = Infinite <n><n><a href="https://www.mathsisfun.com/sets/ratio-expressions.html" target="_top">Click here</a >to learn more.<n><n>####<n>Response:<n><a href="http://math-forum.com/problems/ratio-f230946.html">Click here</a> to learn more about how to find the denominator of infinite ratios.<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Illegitimate designer handbags will not have a certificate of what? Choices:  A: actions B: legal C: authentic D: logical E: legitimate<n><n>### Response:		A, illegitimate handbags will not be able to show a legitimate certificate of authenticity.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Everybody seemed to have a horse not just the regular gamblers, which event always brings out the biggest crowds to the sport? Choices:  A: race track B: kentucky derby C: american southwest D: triple crown E: horse derby<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rationales:The Kentucky Derby is a premier event on the American horse racing calendar. It takes place each May in Louisville, Kentucky, and is open only to 3-year-old thoroughbreds. Its name derives from the city that hosts the race wherein it is a race for the best 3-year-olds and an official event for the Triple Crown which has other races including Belmont Stakes and Preakness Stakes.<n>The Kentucky Derby, run at Churchill Downs in Louisville, Ky., is part of the Triple Crown, which also includes the Preakness Stakes and Belmont Stakes. Other Kentucky Derby facts: The horses race 1¼ miles, or 9 furlongs, at Churchill Downs. Churchill Downs opened for business in 1875. The Derby has run every year since 1875, except during World War II when the race was canceled. The Derby also has had different lengths over the years, due to a variety of reasons and rule changes. The current race distance is 1¼ miles.<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What kind of people will someone who is in charge of project look for? Choices:  A: greedy B: worry C: have knowledge D: take charge E: boss<n><n>### Response:		<n>What kind of people will a person who is a boss look for?<n><n>#### B<n><n>Answer: Bosses<n><n>### Instructions:<n>The instructions below provide guidance when working on the task. Write a response.<n><n>### Direction:<n>A person in charge of a project is also called a _____. Choice:<n><n>#### Project leader A<n><n><n>#### Project director A<n><n>#### Project manager A<n><n>#### Lead B<n><n>#### Coordinator B<n><n>#### Co-supervisor B<n><n>#### Supervisor B<n><n>#### Director B<n><n>#### Manager B<n><n>Answer: Project Manager<n><n><n><n><n><n>#### Direction:<n>A group of people called "project contributors" is working on the project. Who, among the following, is NOT a project contributor? Choices:<n><n>#### People A<n><n>#### Students (both from Business) A<n><n>#### People B<n><n>#### Professors (both from Business) B<n><n>#### People C<n><n>#### Students C Direction:<n>Which two of the five who are NOT project contributors?<n><n>#### People A and B<n><n>#### People A, B, and C<n><n>#### People A or B<n><n>#### People B and C<n><n>#### None - all five are project contributors A<n><n>#### A, B, C, and D<n><n>Answer: Project contributors are: Students (both from business)<n><n>### Task:<n>Input: Who among us is an administrator? Choices: Student (from Business), Admin, Manager, Supervisor Direction: Who among the choice given above (1-3) is NOT an administrator? Answer: Manager<n><n><n>### Instroduction:<n><n>Input: What happens when we lose access to the internet? Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:She was processing the wool, she kept her leg bouncing to operate the what? You can use array methods `contains`, `lastIndexOf` and `indexOf` here to solve this problem.  <n><n>---<n>### Solution<n>```<n>#!/bin/python<n><n>def dominate(arr,n):<n>	if(len(arr)<n):<n>		return False<n>	for i in range(1,len(arr)):<n>		if(arr[i]
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:When going to sleep what noise does a human make? I rolled over and couldn't stop trembling after that! Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:In what place could you find air that has been breathed by many people recently? Choices:  A: charming B: space shuttle C: house D: train station E: surface of earth<n><n>### Response:		<n>Surface of earth<n>####  E<n> <n>### Instruction<n>Please use the following formula to help solve the problem. Show the formula and the steps used to solve it.<n><n>$$\left(\sum A_{i} \times \left(\frac{i}{m}\right)\right) \times D^{\frac{-1}{n^2}}$$<n> <n>### Demonstraition:<n>Input: How many $45 \text{ mm}$ wide strips of $5 \text{ cm}$ long will cover the back of a book of size $45 \text{\" cm}^2$?<n>Rationales: D=45/5= <<45/5=9>>9 cm.<n>Then, we multiply $\sum$ by the quotient of $i$ by $m$ as $\left(\sum A_i \times\frac{i}{m} \ldots\right)$<n><n>$\left(\sum{45} \times \left( \frac{1}{9}\right)\right)$<n><n>= $\left(\sum A_{45} \times\frac{45}{9} \ldots\right).$ <n><n>Next, $D^ {\frac{-1}{n} )$ would be the same value as 9. Therefore, $D^{\frac{-1}{9}}$.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:To gain her trust the real estate agent was very polite, delightful and all around what? Choices:  A: manipulate B: charming C: deceive D: exaggerate E: incompetent<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>###### A: manipulate<n>B: charming<n>C: deceive<n>D: exaggerate<n>E: incompetent​<n><n>### Input (Detailed):<n>The agent was all of the ways they were not polite, manipulative, charming, deceitful, and competent.​<n>### Response (Detailed):<n>Yes. What a terrible person. All of the above are correct​<n>### Input (Bonus):<n>The agent was not one, some, all of the ways they said something that should not have been said to gain her trust.​<n>### Rationales:<n>The above answer is based on the assumption that they were not all of the above. This is not a reasonable assumption (e.g., manipulative is an all or nothing statement). The question should not be interpreted this way. To gain someone's trust would mean that they wanted to manipulate them.​ ​<n><n>### Bonus:<n>Yes.​<n><n>### Rational(Bonus):<n>I agree with the response. To gain someone'ss' trust would mean that trust was lost. This means that they wanted to manipulate the person.<n><n>###### Answer:<n>D<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:A person would carry a large netted drawstring bag to what sort of place? Choices:  A: airport B: car C: jewelry store D: garbage can E: laundry room<n><n>### Response:		 C<n><n>#### How do you know?<n>1. A: airport<n>A large bag for carry on is needed for long trips because it can hold more.<n>2. B: car<n>A car bag can hold shoes, jackets and many other things.<n>3. C: jewelery store<n>You usually have to carry jewelry in a protective case in the event is gets broken.<n>4. D: garbage can<n>You dont carry around a garbage can.<n>5. E: laundry raom<n>The laundry might be in a big bag but it isnt a big drawstring bag.<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:My house is very dry, with little water in the air. Water vapor is more likely to evaporate inside a very cold environment. An ice cube is also useful on a hot summers day, providing cold water to drink.<n><n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Collections of atoms called molecules make up everything you can hold in your what? Choices:  A: atom B: anything C: air D: feet E: hands<n><n>### Response:		<n>An object<n><n>####  Choice (D)<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write an explanation for how to add and subtract whole numbers.<n>###  Demonstration: Adding whole numbers requires only the step of adding the units, which are just the digits in the ones place of each number.<n>Since they are just in the ones place, they can be added as normal (for example, $36 + 79$ => $3 + 7$ since $6$ + $9$ is $15$).<n><n>Now, if you subtract whole numbers, then it is the same as adding them: simply subnet the sum (start at the ones place of the addition) and add up the tens and the units.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>So,<n>Subtracting:<n>$16$ - $9$<n>$1$<n>-<n>$0$<n>+ 9 - 1 = $8$<n>$9$ - $1$<n>$8$<n>+ 8 - 8 = $0$<n><n>Adding:<n>$197$<n>+ $107$<n>$204$<n><n>$0$<n>-<n>$2$<n>+$ 16$<n>$18$<n>- $6$<n>= $12$<n>$197 - 107$<n>=$10$<n><n>#### Add an answer to your response.<n>## 7. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What do horses do to get energy? Choices:  A: eat grass B: play C: kept in stables D: dominated E: drink coffee<n><n>### Response:		<n>B<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Horses can't eat coffee.<n>Horses can be kept in stables.<n>Horses eat grass.<n>Horses often play.<n><n><n>### A B C D E<n><n>### Input:"You have to stay over here for at last 7 days." said the flight attendant. "How many days do I've? Do I need to wait for 7 days or less?" asked the passengers. "Either you have to wait for 7days or less than 7days." said the flight attendent again. "What is right answer?" asked the passenger. "Are you asking about 7days or less? Because I answered that." replied the flight attendant angrilly.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The competition was to see who would be the last one the drop the object, the hard part was you had to have your arm extended straight out while what the object? Choices:  A: holding B: lift up C: pick up D: lifting E: hold onto<n><n>### Response:		C <n><n>### Expanded Instruction:Answer the question above.<n><n>### Explain:<n>Input: The competition was to see who could be the last one to drop an object while their arm extended. C: Pick up was correct.<n>I used the following strategy to solve this problem: <n><n>I used the strategy of elimination to solve this problem by eliminating B: lift up and E: hold onto because the object could not be picked up, nor could it be lifted. <n><n>### Input A:<n><n>### Response B:<n><n>### Explained:<n><n>### Input C:<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>### Extended Instruction:<n>Explain your thought process of how you went about solving the problem.<n><n>### Explanation A:<n><n>## Extended Instruction: <n>The strategy I used to solve this problem was the strategy of elimination. I eliminated B: lift up and C: pick up because the object could not have been picked up or lifted, as doing so was the task of the competition and no one could be the only person to be the last to drop. <n><n>## 12+ Question:<n>### Challenge 1:<n><n>### Challenge 2<n><n>### Challenge Response:<n>### Challenge Answer:<n>### Answers by Group:<n><n>### Challenges in the Challenge:<n>### Challenge in the Challenge Answers:<n>### Challenge Question:<n>### Challenged Question(s):<n>### Challenge for Question(s):<n>Given an input and multiple choices. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What is a convenient place for a bus station? Choices:  A: maps B: street C: catch bus D: city centre E: school<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### C<n><n>#### Hint: In case you are thinking that “Map” should be the answer, but don’t know why you should not choose it, here it says “The answer is not A”. Since you know that the answer cannot be ‘A’, you can conclude that it must be either B, C, D, or E.<n><n>C = A, B, D, or E<n><n>#### <n><n><n>### Input<n><n>Demonstration: Janis and Jessica work at the same post office.<n><n>Janis<n><n>- Janis: sorts post within 12 hours<n>- Janis: is friendly<n><n>#### Jessica:<n>Jessica<n><n>- Jessica: sorts post within 6 hours<n>- Jessica: is friendly<n><n>### Choices:<n>D)<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>- You can't sort mail twice and the work is not friendly.<n>- The answers for Jessica are not all acceptable<n><n>#### D<n><n>Answer: <n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>#### Choices: (A) There are no cars in the village. (E) The sign is too high for cars<n><n>### Choice:<n><n>#### A<n><n>#### Hint<n><n>Asking the question (or at least hinting) when you aren’t sure is a decent idea for this quiz.<n><n>To summarise (without giving any answers) the choices are: A, B, C, or D. This choice is not acceptable since “no cars” doesn’t mean that cars can’t leave the village. Neither does “no buses”.<n><n>Since this isn’t possible, you probably want to try “B” since other roads aren’t closed.<n><n>#### A<n>Answer: no cars<n><n>### Instruption:In the word below, can you select one word which is suitable for each space?<n>#### Lines 6 to 4: <n><n>6. __ <n><n>#### Line 11: <n><n>7. __<n><n>#### Line 4: <n>#### <n><n>#### 22<n>Answer

She has enough money for 4 pairs of pants and 3 pairs of shoes, but not both. She has enough money to buy 1 shirt but not 2. However, she has enough money to buy one jacket and two ties. How many shirts can she buy?<n><n>#### 23<n>Answer: 7.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>### We know that one pair of pants is $40, one pair of shoes is $100, one shirt is $110, one jacket is $120, and two ties is $180.<n><n>So, if she wants to buy 4 pairs of pant that's $40 x 4 = $160.<n>If she wants to buy 3 pairs of shoeses that's 100 x 3 = $300.<n>If she only wants to buy 1 shirts that's $110 - how much left?<n>If she only buys 1 jackets but 2 ties that's that's 120 x 2 = $240. <n>So if she spends all her money, what's the total money?<n><n>## Requiremnet 03<n><n>### Demetrate:<n>#### 112

The one that is heads always has half a chance of each. C:The one that is tails has one chance of coming out with tails again. It is even more likely for the ones that is heads to always come up with heads because they even out with half a chance of coming out with heads and tails. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Along what feature will you find a rosebush? Choices:  A: park B: in the ground C: hedgerow D: temperate climate E: botanical gardens<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Answer: <n>You can find rosebushes along a hedgerow. A hedgerow is a line of trees, hedges, or shrubs creating a boundary. The hedgerows are more common in more temperate climates. Rosebushes are found along hedgerows, which need a temperate climate to survive. Rosebushes thrive in temperate climates because they need sunlight and lots of water.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Hedgerows provide a useful role for animals such as wildlife, pets and birds to travel to another location during the warmer and cooler seasons. They help to connect two ecosystems together which provide essential habitat, food, water and shelter for a variety of animals.<n><n>[Hedgerow - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hedgerow )<n><n>### Exercise:<n>* Write the correct letter on the blank line next to the best choice.<n>* The first line of the description, underlined in the example, shows several choices. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The print was extremely small, as he was reading letter after letter he began to suffer eye what? Choices:  A: strain B: though C: happiness D: realization E: understanding<n><n>### Response:		A, B<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following true or false question.<n><n>## Instructions:Answer true or false.<n>1. The statement "I think that" is a universal statement. <n>2. The statements "My mother thinks that" and "Molly thinks that" are not universal statements. <n>3. "I think that it will rain later" is a universal statement, and "It will rain later" is the conclusion. <n>4. A universal statement needs a conclusion to be true or false. <n>5. The statements "She thinks that it is cold today" and "It is cold today" are not universal statements since they don't rely on a conclusion to be true.<n><n>### Answer:A, B, E<n><n>### Response<n>1. A, E<n>2. A <n>3. A<n>4. A B E<n>5. B, E<n>  <n>#### 25/42<n>Answer: 42<n><n>### Input<n>Choose the correct statement.<n>The best solution to the problem is to cut down the trees along the side of your house.<n><n>A) The best solution to the problem could be to cut down the trees on the side of your house B) is that<n>C) The best solution to get rid of the problem was to cut down the trees alongside of your house D) that<n><n>#### 42<n>Answer: C E D<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:If I have a reception with many people attending, where should I be sure to hold it? Choices:  A: grand casino B: large room C: restaurant D: country club E: lobby<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is option E because Grand Casino, Restaurant, and Country Club are all too small for a reception that many people attend.<n><n>#### 

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Too many people want exotic snakes.  The demand is driving what to carry them? Choices:  A: ditch B: shop C: north america D: pet shops E: outdoors<n><n>### Response:		There is an ecosystem in north america in which snakes reside. Demand for snakes is driving the price down, but the supply is remaining intact by keeping the environment the same and not selling the snakes.<n><n>### Input2:The snake supply is increasing by 3 each year.  If 20 years from now there are 12 million snakes, how many would you have 20 years from today?<n><n>#### Answer: 0.3*y<n><n>Rationales: The answer is 20 years from the end of 20 years ago.<n><n>#### 12 million<n><n>Answer: 0.3 * 12 = <<12*0.3=3.6>>3.6<n><n>Answer: 3.6<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:He wanted a house that was gated off from other places, where should he start looking? Choices:  A: neighborhood B: subdivision C: city D: suburbs E: street<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>### Instructor's Correction: Choice A was incorrect. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Mark's semen was very thick, but after his vasectomy it was also what? Choices:  A: blank B: sparse C: thin D: clear E: free flowing<n><n>### Response:		A<n>Rationales:Thick = Not thin.<n><n>Answer:<n>========<n>Thick = Not thin<n><n>Thin = not Thick<n><n>Clear = Not Free<n><n>Free = Not Clear<n><n>1  - 2 = 3 <n>----------------------------------------------<n>Thick = Not clear, so choice B<n><n>Thick means dense like concrete Thick: very dense or dense with very little space between (things or people).<n><n>Sparse: Scattered.<n><n>Thin: Very narrow; slender.<n><n>Clear: very free and easy, or very easy to read. Not free flowing.<n>Free flowing: Very easily flows out.<n><n>Choosing<n>------------

When I buy my house, I will consider buying a townhouse over an apartment complex that comes with a lot of additional fees and responsibilities for safety and security.<n><n>There will be no difference between when I rent a townhouse or rent an apartment from my landlord. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The fat man refused to accept what was possible, he complained that he what the simplest activities? Choices:  A: no go B: unlikely C: unable D: cant do E: impossibility<n><n>### Response:		<n>### Rationales<n>A) No, the fact that that activity is an ordinary way of making choices.<n>B) No, there is no information that supports the possibility to do simple activity.<n>C) Yes, the fact that activity is not simple.<n>D) Yes, the facts do not support what was easy.<n>E) Yes, the fact is the simple activity.<n>#### B<n>The most likely to answer is the simple activity. <n><n>### Input :  Which letter completes the equation? F=12.8 + 7.4, A=50% + 1.8, C=800/9, B=7/2-1.2, D= 95/-40...<n>### Response:B<n>Rationales: When an equation is divided by 2, the number will be subtracted by 1.0.<n>The equation has 7/2-1,42-128,7.4-12.8,74-78,-40-(-40),800-99,etc.<n><n>### Inputs : In which mathematical equation, the value of 9 has the largest place?<n>### Option A: x+x=2(x-x)<n>### Option B: x/x=x(x+x)<n>### Inputs: C: 3/(1+x)=(3*x)/(1)<n>### Input: What will the value of this equation be?<n>### 65% of 868.5<n>### Option: 419.0<n>### Option: E<n>### Answer:<n>### Explain:<n>Rationales:<n>x+x=2(1-x)<n><n>### Example: 3+3=6-2 = 4<n>### Example: A (65+65=65+130=195-130) B (A (65+60)) C (9.5+9.5)<n>### Options: A B C E<n><n>### 35x + 400 - 2/3 x = x/x + (400/3) = 21<n>### Answer: 21<n><n>### R

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where would there be many people sitting in chair and listening to religious speech? Synagogue - A synagogue is a place of prayer, meditation, and worship for Jews. Auditorium - An auditorium is a large building for an audience of people. Office - An office could be in a church. Confession - A confession is a place where you tell an adult or God or both of your secrets.<n><n>### Exercise:<n>Find the word of the following sentences that does not make sense:<n>1. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What is a mobile launching platform found in the ocean? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What is committing perjury likely to lead to? Choices:  A: shame B: arrest C: embarrassment D: go to jail E: tension<n><n>### Response:		I have read the provided statement, and I am fully aware that committing perjury is likely to lead to the following negative outcomes: arrest or imprisonment, negative publicity, and increased anxiety and stress.<n><n>---<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:A soccer field that is not contained in a building would be where? Choices:  A: playground B: mexico C: town D: outside E: world cup<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>-A mexico and world cup and building don't have soccer field<n><n>D = outside because all of the choices are about soccer field and outside is the only one of those that contains the word outside. So the only choice that it contains the word "outside" is A - playground<n><n>### Question:A soccer field not enclosed in a building will be where?<n><n>#### Playground<n>Answer: A<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Sky diving scared him, once they jumped out of the plane he began losing consciousness while what? Choices:  A: injury B: death C: playing uno D: coma E: falling down<n><n>### Response:		15)A<n><n>#### A<n>Rationales: He was having a heart attack. He was losing consciousness<n><n>### Demand: Find the total of 5, 11, 10, 18 and 1?<n><n>### Answer: 38<n><n>####38<n>Rationales: Add 5+11+10+18+1<n><n>### 6 + 4 =? 12? 13? 14? 15?<n><n><n>### 15<n>Rationales: 1 + 2 + 3 + 4 + 5 = 15<n>1 + 3 + 5 + 7 + 9 = 25<n>1 + 2 +... + 14 = 34<n>  <n><n>### Evaluate the equation 2 * 3 + 1 =?, using the order of operations!<n><n>### 5<n><n>### 9 * 2 + 2 =<n>Demonstration: 9 * 2 = 18<n>1 * 2 = 2<n>1 + 2 = 3<n>Evaluate the expressions 18 + 2 + 2 + 1 = 23 <n><n>### 23<n>Order of operations rules:<n>1. Parenthesis grouping terms of the formula<n>2. Exponents(if any)<n>3. Multiplication and Divisions<n>4. Addition and Subtraction<n><n>### 765 / 70 * 700 =<n><n>### 35<n>Rationales:: <n>710 * 70 * 16 = 35 * 700 * 70 = 350000 =?<n>Simplify the product <n><n>### F<n><n>### 8 % 15=?<n><n>### 40<n><n>### <n>Divide 15 by 8<n> <n>### 16 times 8 equals 128; write this as a ratio<n><n>### 0<n><n>### The quotient of 9 and 12 is 5 1/2, written as.5 1/2. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where is a fox likely to be caught? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:He was a very sharp engineer, but when it came to the details his calculations could were often what? Choices:  A: complimentary B: inelegant C: ocean D: dull E: inaccurate<n><n>### Response:		E-Dull<n>#### A,B,C,D<n>Input:Which has longer, 38 minutes or 23 minutes?<n><n>Output :38 minutes<n>Answer: B><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:If I am a person, I have a unique ability to do what? Choices:  A: cross street B: stand upright C: speak spanish D: speak chinese E: further education<n><n>### Response:		<n>[Choices: A: B: C: D: E:](https://github.com/WillyChen/Coding_Interview_Preparation_Challenges/tree/main/chapter010/daily500-Coding_Interview-questions)<n>The person who can cross street also can stand upright.<n>The person who can stand upright also can speak Chinese.<n>The person who cannot cross street also cannot stand upright. <n>The person who cannot speak Spanish cannot speak Cantonese.<n>The person who learns the hard way cannot be lazy. <n>The person is lazy means he does not do exercise. Doing exercise helps to stand upright. Doing exercise helps the person to cross street.<n>#### Cross Street <n>Answer: stand upright<n><n>### 10.How many balls of a specific kind to get a ball with a certain weight?<n><n>### <n>### Instruciton:A weighted dice whose weight is random, can only sum up to 12.<n><n>1. a dice:<n>- If the top side is facing up => 1<n>- If the top is facing down => 2<n><n>1. b dice:<n>- If top side is the middle of the two side => 1<n>- if the top side is facing side => 2<n><n>### 2. If A = {1, 2,4, 6, 8, 10} and B = {2, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11}, find each value in A or B that satisfies the equation k + v = 12.<n>Answer: 6<n>Note: <n>> The sum of k value and v value can only equal to 12. Since in 12 possible number of value that are between [0, 12] (12 - [0, 11]).<n>### Code:<n>[Go](https://github.combilang.org/WillyChen)<n><n><a name="daily500"></a>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What common chemical reaction is often used as a heat source? Choices:  A: coal or wood B: fire C: lava D: house E: solar energy<n><n>### Response:		Choice B<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>#### Chemical Explanation:<n>The chemical reaction used to make fire is: Carbon (charcoal) + oxygen = carbon dioxide gas<n>Note: Charcoal is almost pure carbon.  This reaction combines the two substances that are needed to start a fire: carbon and oxygen.<n><n>#### Explanation of Question:<n>The question asks "What common chemical reaction... (is) often used as a heat (source)".<n>The choice that uses "common" as in every day or frequent is "often."<n>The question says, "is (to be used as)" a heat source.<n>A chemical reaction often used to produce heat is called a fire.<n>All the answers except for "solar energy" are combustion processes that produce heat, the opposite of a cooling process like "solar energy."<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:I am looking to buy honey right from an apiary, where should I go? Choices:  A: jar B: stick to fingers C: beehive D: stick to fingers E: farmer's market<n><n>### Response:		F: beehive<n>```<n>D:  Jar<n>E:  Farmer's Market<n>A:  Stick to fingers<n>C:  Beehive<n>```<n><n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: What are two different ways to add 16 to 5? Answer: Choices:  A) 21 B) 22 C) 20 D) 19 E) 23<n><n>### Rationale:<n>A: 21<n>B: 22<n>```C:19<n>D:16+5=21```<n><n>### Output:<n>```<n>1)  19<n>2) 16+5=11<n>3) 21<n>4)  22<n>5) 26<n>```<n><n>#### 19<n>Answer: 16<n><n>### Instraction:<n>Which of these events took more time to begin?<n><n>1) 739 minutes<n>2) 694 minutes<n>3) 521 minutes<n>4) 195 minutes<n>5) 100 minutes<n><n>### Demstortion:<n>Rationale:<n>5 took me the least time and 1 took me the most time<n>```5 => 10 minutes<n>3 => 27 minutes<n>1 => 110 minutes```<n><n>### Answer:<n>Answer: 1<n><n>### Instuction:<n>1) 16 = 16, 2) 42 = 2x21, 3) 12 = 21, 4) 12t = 2n-1, 5) 12y = 4, 6) 12 = y<n><n>### Insturation<n>```1)<n>16=16.3)<n>20=2x20.52)<n>14=2x7.4))<n>6n=1=5.3)<n>4y=2=8.5)<n>```<n><n>### Demistraction:<n>answer: Choices: 7.2) 20.Answer: A) y = 8<n><n>### Input<n>```1<n>y=4<n>n=d

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Jimmy wanted a beer but his wife was an alcoholic on probation. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. They were standing in place.  The line was fast, but the children in front of them were loud.   They were what? Choices:  A: frustration B: being annoyed C: delays D: irritation E: out of order<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Rationales:<n>The line was fast, but they were both irritated with the children and the cashier that they could not get their items out to them.   Therefore, the queue was out of order.<n><n>Answer choice "B" (irritated): Out of Order<n><n>Answer choice "D" (irritated) or "E" (out of order) since both have an irritated tone towards the customers next to them.<n><n>### Input:'The bus schedule was posted on the bus shelter, but the schedule was: A: in order B: a disorder C: out of order D: not posted at all<n><n>### Response:"B"<n><n>### Rationale:<n>The schedule was out of order because it was not posted where it should have been. A: I was annoyed.  B: the wind was chilly C: the sun was shining D: it was the same every day<n><n>### Response:'D'<n><n>### Ratives:<n>The wind was chilly, because it was the same everyday. When there is the same thing over and over, then a change is needed.<n><n>Answer choice 'A' (annoyed)<n><n>Answer choice 'B' (wind was chilly')<n><n>Answer choice 'C' (sun was shining)<n><n>Answer Choice 'D' (same everyday)<n><n>Answer Choices 'A' (annoy) and 'C' (sun) since the change is needed.<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The child pounded his mitt in excitement while enjoying his first game in the bleachers where? The converse is not necessarily true.<n>A proposition is a statement that describes some sort of relationship between its components - a hypothesis is a statement that describes the result of an experiment - a prediction is a statement that describes an event that is likely to happen.>><n><n>### Input  : Choose the synonym for logical fallacy :<n><n>A: circular reasoning B: non sequitur -------------------<n>C: false analogy D: post hoc fallacy<n><n>### Response<n><n>A:<<Non sequitur : failure to draw a valid conclusion.<n>A circular reasoning a fallacy in which the reasoning or the explanation is based on its own premise. This means that the premise and conclusion are so closely related thaat they are basically the same.>><n><n>## Conclusion:<n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:People want to explore space, so what should they use to do it? Choices:  A: public place B: roadblock C: space shuttle D: hoverboard E: supermarket<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>- A: public place<n>- B: roadblock<n>- C: space shuttles<n>- D: hoverboards<n>- E: supermarket<n>- E<n>

Choices:  A: meat grinder B: stable C: red barn D: gate E: green field<n><n>### Response:		It wouldn't leave the Stable<n><n>### Input Choices for Demonstration: <n>1. B<n>2. C<n>3. D<n>4. A<n>5. E<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>* B:  It does not have something to do with Meat Grinder since it's not an ingredient for meat.<n>* C:  it does not match the clue since it's not something to do with a stable.<n>* D:  It's not  a gate, stable, or farm, so it does not match.<n>* A:  It's a meat grinder, stable, gate, or farm because those are things to do with The Cow would come outside even after The Storm had passed it wouldn't leave The.<n>* E:  It's stable, farm, meat grinder, gate, or cow because the Cow comes out and it would leave the stable if the cow comes out.<n><n>### Input<n>Lisa is faster than Daisy. George is two years older than Sam. Paul is less than Daisy. How many years must Daisy be older than Paul?<n><n>Because Daisy is two years older than George. and since George is older than Sam, Paul is less than Diana.<n>1. Lisa is faster than Daisie<n>2. George is 2 years older then Sam, and Sam is less than George.<n>3. Paul is less than George because of that information<n>4. Therefore Daisy is less than Sam(because she is 2 times older, she is still older but a smaller difference)<n>5. and Sam is less than Paul, since Sam is slower than George, and George is less than Daisie.<n>6. Therefore Daisy must be older than Paul by more than 2 years.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>* 1: because Lisa is faster than Diana<n>* 2: George is 2 years old, because George is 2 years Older than Sam. Diana is 2 years younger than Sam.<n>* 3: Paul is less than Diane because Paul is less than George. Diana is Older than Diane.<n>* 4: Since Diana is Older then Diana. Diana is 6 times faster than Paul. George is older than Paul, and Sam is less then Diana

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What would release energy, but not mainly in your muscles? Choices:  A: vent B: think C: shouting D: work off E: exercise<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### A: vent<n>VENT: to let out or release gas, air, or other matter from a pipe, container, or the like, as by means of a blow-off valve, safety valve, or whistle.  The gas is not being used, so venting is "working off"<n><n>#### B: think<n>Think: to have in the mind as a preexisting disposition of thought or as an original act of conception.  Energy is a preexisting disposition.  Therefore, thinking is also working off<n><n>#### C: shouting<n>SHOUTING: to use an unusually loud voice or utter a sound at the top of your lungs.  In other words, use your voice and/or the top of your lung.  Not using those is working off<n><n>#### D: work off<n>WORK OFF: to discharge, absorb, or remove by work, as waste or impurities.  The energy can be "discharged or absorb" or in other words "worked" off<n><n>#### E: exercise<n>EXERCISE:  to work out in a specified way or manner.  The body is "working" out.<n><n>#### 214<n>Answer: Think<n><n>### Instructions and Rationale:<n><n>#### Instructions:<n><n>#### 302<n>Answer: Exercise<n><n>### Instuction:<n><n>### Answers:<n><n>In which of the following places would you most likely find the most vegetarians?<n>### Choices:<n><n>#### 406.<n>Answer: Church.<n><n>In "A Hanging", how does Edgar Sawtelle die?<n>### Choice: <n>#### 502<n>Answer: By hanging himself<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:what is the goal of going jogging? Choices:  A: heavy breathing B: feel pride C: getting tired D: lose weight E: run away<n><n>### Response:		<n>what is the goal of <<what is the goal of>> going jogging?<n><n>### Choices<n><n>- **A:** <<Heavy breathing>> or <<B: <<Heavy breathing\u2212>|B: Heavy breathing\u003B/C: Heavy breathing>> <<C: Pride>> or <<D: Tiredness>> or <<E: Running away>><n><n>### Rationales<n><n><n>The options represent the best guesses for the answers from some of the answers given.  If there was no reasonable guess for any answer, <<no answer available>> would be an appropriate response.<n><n><n>### Input (1): <<Answer (0): A B E C D>><n><n>### Response (1): what is the goal of <<go>> going jogging? <<Choices:>> Go to sleep Echo in the forest <<Go>> to sleep Echo in <<the>> forest<n><n>### Rationale (1)<n>There are 5 choices for the answer.<n>Echo in the forest is not appropriate, so it is not appropriate to provide a response of Echo in the forest.<n><n>### Input 2 (2): <<Answer 1: A B E>><n><n>### response 2 : <<what is the goal of go jogging>>?<n><n>### Rationals 2:<n><n>The response is not appropriate. A B E are not in the answer choices.<n><n><n><n>#### [![][124]]<n>**\[124\]**<n><n>### Input-<n><n>The above diagram shows a set of data points in the form of a scatter plot. Write a response that addresses all items listed below.  <n>### Input- 1: is the relationship between X and Y linear?<n><n>### Response 1 : <<No relationship>><n><n>### Input -2: what is the y intercept of the equation that represents the line that best describes this plot with the highest correlation and a slope = 1?<n><n>### response -2: <<y-intercept: \u230C(0, 38)\u003B\u003Cx\u003E38>><n><n>### input 3: what is the slope of the line that best describes the plot above

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where would one find a shopping bag for packing groceries? Choices:  A: supermarket B: home C: closet D: mart E: hardware store<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>- Mart or Hardware store.<n><n>### Input.How long do you sit in the classroom? 1: A/B/C/D years; 2: C/D/E years; 3: A/B years; 4: years B: A year; C: B year; D: C year; E: D year; F: A&B<n><n>#### Explanation:<n>A student has 210 days in an academic year. <n>1: A/B years <br><n>A: 1x210= 210 <br><n>B: 2x210=420  <br><n>C: 3x210=630 <br><n>D: 4x210=840 <br><n>E: 5x210=1050 <br><n>F: 6x210=350+310=660 <br><n>2: C/D years  <br><n><n>C: 1x290=290 <br><n><n>D: 2x290=580 <br><n>3: A/B (A*210)+B=210 <br><br><n><n>A: 210+0 = 210 <sub>  x 1=210 <span> <span><sup>x210=xxxxxx=xxx</sup></span></sub> <br><n><n>B: 0+210 = 21<sub>x+6</sub> <br><br>4: C-year <br><n><n><n>Reasoning: <n>> 850 = 5+1+4+20<n><n>5+1=6 -> 6 years <br><n>4+20=24 -> 1+4*19=60 <br> <n><n>- 2+1+4+6+49<n>- 6<n><n>### Input and Answer<n>#### Input: What is the square root of 26?<n>#### Answer: The square root of 25 <br><n><n>sqrt(25)>=> 5<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where are you likely to find a paper program? Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What is a living thing with a lip? Choices:  A: mouth B: can C: human D: snake E: kentucky fried chicken<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>#### rationale:<n>-mouth is living thing with a lip

How many people were there? Choices: A : 44 B : 18 C : 50 D : 20 E : none of the above<n><n>## DemonstrAtion<n><n><n>#### 50<n><n>### There were 44 people in the room as a whole, which is 40 people less than 19 people in total.<n><n>### 19(=the total number of people, i.e. you have to add 9 people to it) is 2 times (i.e.2 x 9) more than 9 people: it is equal to 18. There were 20 people more than the sum of half the number of servers, i.e. the number is 50 people.<n><n>### You have to add 40 people to 18 and then you will know how many people were in the dining room (50 - 18 = 32).<n><n>## Input<n><n>Input: 15% of the people in the United States is in one of five states. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where is a system of electronic devices likely to be used in school? Other possible places where electronic devices are used are in nature and the human body.<n><n>#### 10 pts<n>Answer:  computer science<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Someone who doesn't care about about someone else and wishes them to fail has what feeling towards them? Choices:  A: unfeeling B: negligence C: antipathy D: indifferent E: rapport<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>I picked choice:<n>C: antipathy  <n>because antipathy means to have an intense feeling of dislike.  <n>C: antipaty <n>I chose A: unfeeling <n>because unfeeling means to have no emotions, feeling, or affection.  <n><n>![image alt text](images/test2.jpg)<n>

How are the lines of java code organized?<n><n>#### Answer:<n>1. hello() will be invoked a total of 10 times<n>2. In the sentence "They were upgraded to the __________", the meaning of the sentence is that "They were upgraded in a way larger than'smaller.'" So, "smaller" must also be larger than "small." The meaning of the sentence "The small cabin was not larger than what?" can be read by using antonyms.<n><n>### Input:"I will visit the __________." Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The crab was scuttling but strained when he moved, what was impeding him? Choices:  A: tide pool B: beach sand C: tidepools D: current E: cooking pot<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Demo:<n><n>### Justification:<n><n>The crab was scuulting but strained when he was trying to move. Why?<n>We can figure this out using the concept ______________________.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>It was impeding him.<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>It was impeding, impeding, impeding him!<n><n>### Credits and Resources:<n><n>Credits: https://github.com/koding-io/veteran-recent-questions.git<n>Credit for image: (https://cdn.free-programming-books.com/books/mathematics/images/p147-028.png)<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What would you put in a container? Choices:  A: food B: cargo ship C: refrigerator D: closet garage E: port<n><n>### Response:		<n>Please, check your choice.<n><n>### Note:<n>This is a [Python script](https://www.python.org/) that prints out the instructions and accepts the answers as input.<n><n>Here is the output:<n><n>### Instructions:Choose one out of the five.<n><n>### Your Response:<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Your Score:<n>Score: <<1>>Score 1<n><n>### Note 1:<n>Note 1: I have only one score and I got 123 points.<n><n>### Score 1:<n>Score 1: <<1>>Score1<n><n>### Instructor Comment:<n>You have passed the test.<n><n>### Input 1: How many letters does she write. Choices: A:14 B:16 C:17 D:18 E:19<n><n>### Input Response:<n>Please, enter your answer.<n><n>### Answer:<n>Answer: D<n><n>### Answer Score:<n>Score 1+18=<<1+18=20>>Score 20<n><n>### Instrument Score:<n>Scores: 20<n><n># 20<n><n>This is an example of a multiple choice task.<n><n>### Introduction<n>This is a task that requires some knowledge or skills. Each item has been selected, and each item has a different value. A score is the combined total of all the item values.<n><n>### Experimental Procedures<n>These are instructions that direct the learner/participant how to solve a task. Instructions can be presented in a different order. Learners can try various ways of solving tasks, so instructions often include descriptions of each possible answer that the task may produce.<n><n>- [x] This step is optional because there are two possible answers at the end of this instruction.<n>   - Answer. The first step is optional because learners can either answer the question or try choosing a different question.<n><n>## Task Solution<n><n>### Demomtion<n><n>### How many do I need to get a passing score?<n><n>### Answer 1<n>### Please, enter your answer. Answer 2<n>### Input Score<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What is illegal to do when you play cards at a casino? Choices:  A: remember B: help C: count D: winning E: dealing<n><n>### Response:		<n>Help, deal, and count<n><n>### Rationale:You cannot help another player at their game. You are not allowed to count cards or touch another player's cards<n><n>### Input:"Toby's cards have a higher value than Jared's cards. If Jared has 8 cards he would not have 93 cards" Which cards has a higher value in this sentence?Choose a: The King or The Queen b: a card and Jack c: Ace and Jack d: The AJQ cards<n>#### 212<n>Answer: a<n><n>### Rationales:A card’s value is higher than Jared’s; therefore, A would have high value and King and Queen would be low value cards<n><n>### RATIONALE:<n>1.A-Ace, King, Queen<n>2.J- Jack<n>3.K-King<n>4.Q-Queen<n><n>### InputWhat is the smallest of all three card values, in an addition sentence like "Add 5 + 6 + 7 + 8"? Choices: 8 A: All of them will be same B: the smallest C: 5 D: 7 E: 5 only<n><n><n>### Response<n>5<n><n><n>### Rationales:  Since 5 is the lowest digit of all of them, it is the smallest number.<n><n>### Input"If we are playing 2000 blackjack and you have 18, how many cards are left? Choices: 2001 A: 9001 B: 21000 C: 11000 D: 2000<n><n>### Response2000<n>### Input:How many different kinds of cards are there in a deck?Choices: A: 31 B: 32 C: 44 D: 25 E: 15<n><n><n>## Input:<n>Choose one of the options.<n><n>> What should you do when you are playing blackjack in a casino?<n><n>Choices:<n><n>A: You have to stand on 17.<n>B: You have to stand before you go bust.<n>C: You have to stay under 21 (to win the game).<n>D: I'm not sure -
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:At a state fair judging pigs requires careful what? Choices:  A: verdict B: judging C: responsibility D: evaluating E: prejudice<n><n>### Response:		Evaluating<n><n>### Justification:Evaluating is a judging term meaning care about the criteria involved.<n>#### Evaluating

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What do people who are speech therapists do? Choices:  A: make music B: believe in god C: give speeches D: complete sentences E: build houses<n><n>### Response:		<n>**A: Make music. A: Make music.**<n><n>### Rationale:<n>*A:* People who give speeches do speech therapy not make music.<n><n><n>*B:* People who believe in god do not believe in it. They do not give speeches either.<n><n><n>*C:* Completion of sentences helps people be able to express themselves. People who engage in speech therapies do not do that.<n><n><n>*D:* Making music is what is done in music therapy.<n><n><n>*E:* Completing sentences is only one of the things a speech therapist does. People who engage with speech therapies complete sentences and also speak.<n><n><n>#### 4<n>Answer: A
