Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What did the business require of everyone walking into their store? Choices:  A: wear shoes B: learn C: hope for peace D: have a great day. E: do well<n><n>### Response:		What the instructor says<n><n>Answer: C: HOW RESPONSES?<n><n>#### What does our team want to do in class tomorrow?<n><n>Answer: B: Learn how to solve.<n><n>### Demo of answers:<n>Input: What the team want to do in the day?<n>Rationales; B: Learning = <<How to solve=>>Learning<n><n>### What the students want to do in the class tomorrow?<n>Answer: B: Learning = <<Learning>><n><n>### Input-The team wants to do in class tomorrows. Choices A: walk all around together, B: play in class, C: answer the students questions and D: practice math word problems<n>### Response:<n>The team answer the student questions:Ans: B<n><n>### A solution to the problem is<n>- <n>### Input: What 7x14 is?<n><n>### Response-1<n><n>### Dem-1<n>Rationales-1: 110/14 = <<110<n>Rationales-2: 55/7 = <<55<n>Rationales-3: 46/7 = <<46<n><n>### <n><n>### Response<n><n>### Demand:1 How many cards does Janet have if 2 cards?<n>### Demand2 How many cards does Brenda have if 9 cards?<n>### Response: Janet: 1<<1>>Janet has 2<n>### Janet: 1.1<<1.1>>Janet has one more than 1<<1>><n>### Janet-1<<2>>One<<2>>Janet has one 2 and 2<n>### Brenda: 3<<3>>Brenda has 9 cards.<n>### Brenda-1<<9>>Brenda has one less than 9>><n>### Brenda - 1<<3>>Brenda is one 3 and 3<n><n>### A 7x14 solution is<n>### Janet = 27<n>### Brenda= 53<n>### Mara = 72<n>### A 40X150 solution is<n><n>### Janet= 2<n>### Mara- 450<n>##
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The college kids weren't known for their apartment decor choices, they used a folding chair inside their what? Choices:  A: bathroom B: closet C: school D: room E: church<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### The college kids weren’t known for their apertment decor choices.<n>The college kids wer’t known for their aparments decor choices. A, D, and E are eliminated. B is impossible because the kitchen couldn't be folded.<n>So the answer is bathroom.<n><n><n>---<n><n><https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSct8wFfL_r08sU8j98WtS0CbLvQkq77GZ6FNMkRPdCjKX3pFg/viewform><n><n>---<n><n># Resources:<n><n>* [Instruction:](https://www.gcflearnfree.org/)<n>* [Directions:.](https://www.gcu.edu/academics/gct/mathematical-statistics-programming/helpful-tools-students/gain-independent-studying/understanding-short-answers)<n>* [Answer:](https://www2.uwsp.edu/academicaffairs/Assessment/Pages/Assessment-Rubrics.aspx)<n>* [Instructions:](https://support.wgu.edu/hc/en-us/articles/208748059-Student-instructions-for-Rubrics)<n>* [Learning Outcomes:](https://www1.vccs.edu/files/101-6457822-FH_E-Learning_Guide_v1.0.pdf)<n>* [Rubric Checklists:](https://www3.iupui.edu/~sandrsst/207/ChecklistRubrics.pdf)<n>* <n><n>[Instructions:]((https://www2.southeastern.edu/academciaffairs/institutional-effectiveness/program-assessment-planning/tips-for-developing-a-rubric.html))<n>* [Answer: ](https://files.eric.ed.gov/fulltext/ED549402.pdf)<n>* Resources:(https://www.ncbi.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What could you put a table in if you want the table to be in your house? Choices:  A: library B: demonstration C: corner D: football ground E: rug<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### A:<n><n>#### B:<n><n>#### C:<n><n>#### D:<n><n>#### E:<n><n>#### 17<n>Answer: A, B, C, D, E<n><n>### Input<n>Input: Brenda is at home. She has a book and three apples. She is carrying a book. Which object is she not holding? Choices: 1: Apple 2: Book 3: Rug 4: Chair<n><n>### Rationales<n><n>Brenda has three apples. She has one book. Brenda is not carrying a book. Therefore, Brenda is not holding a book. However, Brenda has a book. She has a rug. Brenda has one chair. Brenda does not have three apples. Brenda also does not have a rug nor a chair.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 1<n><n>### Instructions<n>Input: How are 97 and 93 different from each other? Choices:  a) 4.78 b) -8.73 c) 3.23 d) -32.23 e -23<n><n>### Rationale<n><n>93 + 4.78 = 97 - 4.78<n><n>#### -7<n>Answer: d) -32,23<n><n>## Input:<n>Input: Brenda has 5 apples. Brenda has three apples more than Jasmine. How many apples does Jasmine have? Choices: a b c d 14 11 15 14 c<n><n>### Rrationales<n><n>Brendas has 5 apples and Jasmine has 11 apples.<n><n>#### 8<n>Answer: c<n><n>### Input :<n>Input: How is 97 different from 129? Choices : a) - 32 b) +28.23 c-6.23 d)-28 e) +6.23 f)-4 B) 4.73 <n><n>### Rationale<n><n>97 - 129 +28.2<n><n>#### -6<n>Answer: f) +6.2<n><n>## Input: How are 111 and 54 different from each other?<n>Input: Choices
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:James was cooking s stew in his apartment kitchen.  Where might he look for a potato. Choices:  A: restaurants B: casserole C: root cellar D: pockets E: pantry<n><n>### Response:		B<n>Answer: Pantry<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Example:<n><n>### Demostration:<n>What will replace the following symbols (< > * / ) as you type them?<n><n>* - =? # = @ $<n>\<n><n>### Input A) The temperature outside is 44 degrees. What is the temperature of an apple? Answer:<n><n>### B) Find 1.515 x 3.837<n>Answer:<n><n>### C) One plus 7 equals 8<n>Answer:<n><n>\-3175557<n>\@^869708645,2783 #45,175<n>\-17/5<n>\$8755 #$48 - $253<n><n><n>### Input B) A number is written as follows:<n><n>#### -436<n>Answer: -436<n><n>### Input C) Two numbers are subtracted and their difference is added.<n><n>#### 7 - 3 = 10 - 3: 7 - 3<n><n>>>>>>>>> 12 - 2<n><n>Answer: 7 - 7<n><n>### Input D) One number is added to 10 + 4 + 8 = 10 + 9 = 20<n><n>#### 3 + 3 = 47<n><n>The answer would be 3 + 3<n><n>### Input E) Two numbers are subtractded where a difference is their sum.<n>#### 8 - 4 = 4 - 8<n><n><n>4 - 3<n>4 - 4<n><n>Answer:<n><n><n>The difference between 3 and 8 is the sum of 4 and -4.<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The sun was out and the temperature changing rapidly, it was really beginning to what? Choices:  A: drop to zero B: increase C: cool down D: dropping quickly E: heat up<n><n>### Response:		D the sun was quickly dropping and it was cooling down.<n><n>### Input::<n>The sun was out and hot, in fact, it was so hot that people couldn't even leave their houses. So they went down to the beach because, well, it was right on the beach. It was not crowded except for two old surfers. They asked if they could help a friend of the day's fishing so the old surfers brought them to the beach as well, so hey, how were going to go fishing?<n><n>### Response<n>Answer: The sun was out and hot. The old surfers brought out some fishing poles but they said no.<n><n>### Extra Credit: <n>Answer:The sun was out so it was hot. The surfers went down to the beach and brought fishing poles.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where did his wife ask him to look first when he complained of missing deodorant? Choices:  A: grocery store B: nightstand C: armpits D: own bathroom E: medicine chest<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>#### E<n><n>Answer: E<n><n>### Input:(1 pt) If x = 149 and y = 276, find the possible values for 26x – 7y + 13?<n>### (1 pt) Demonstration: x = 146 and y = 264.<n>### (1pt)<n>### Input:Find the value of the angle whose tangent is 0.92. Choices:  A) acute angle B) right angle C) obtuse angle D) straight angle E) supplementary angle <n>### (1 point)<n>### Response: A<n><n>#### A<n><n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input(1 pt)The temperature is 71 degrees Fahrenheit and the humidity is 52%. What is the apparent temperature in degrees Fahrenheit? Choices: 246.32 A: F B: R C: C	<n>### (1point)<n>### Demonstation:<n>71/1.8= 39.8 52/1.8=32.2<n>therefor apparent temperature 39.8-32.2=7.6
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:When we are thankful for getting something what do we do? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Some might say that if you want to do something that results in changing society then you need to start from within, to do this what would you be doing? Choices:  A: riots B: vote C: change yourself D: social activism E: change clothes<n><n>### Response:		<n>It all depends on your values.<n>You have to understand your values and beliefs and then the steps you want to take.<n>If your purpose is to make changes as a society, I believe you need to start from changing yourself. Then if others see the change in you others will follow you. <n>### A: Riots<n>Riots will help you express your anger and rage and you can vent out. But, will that change your society?<n>You may be putting your life in danger. <n>In short, violence won't help you.<n><n>### B: Vote<n>There is a difference between voting for your favorite actor/ actress, and casting vote in a political election.<n>In some countries, they have the right to vote even though they are uneducated.<n><n>### C: Change Yourself<n>I suggest you to become a role model for all those who have misfit in society with regards to discrimination on the grounds of race, color, caste, creed and religion. <n>I know it is quite difficult to take this, but when you succeed that you can make a change in the society.<n><n>### D: Social Activity<n>In this case I believe that only if you involve yourself in social activism that will help you. You may become a good leader in activism and then you can help others in changing the society.<n>You can make a difference in the society only if all the people working with your team are passionate about the cause of activism.<n><n>### E: Change Clothes<n><n>When it comes to discrimination on grounds of color, caste, religion etc. changing your clothes would have no impact on the society. <n>You need to become a role model and a leader in such cause.<n>If you want to change the attire of others, you need to start from your family then from the society.<n><n>#### Answer:C<n><n>### Input You are an old man who suffers from senile dementia and want to express your own feeling in writing, you can choose the choice you like.<n><n>### Choice A: I want to meet my friends.<n>### Choice B: I do not understand people anymore<n><n>### Choices:<n>#### Answer：B<n><n>### Choise：<n>#### Answer：E<n><n><n><n>### Question 1:<n><n>### Ex

It is a reasonable choice.<n><n>A: City makes little sense with city's meaning being any area, while the context is talking about yard, not area (in particular, the question is about the width of a yard).<n><n>E: three arm span does not make sense either. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:If children get confused walking home where may they go? Choices:  A: play chess B: sun themselves C: wrong house D: set table E: gettable<n><n>### Response:		E: gettable<n><n>#### Choices:<n>A) A:play chess<n>B) B: sun themselves<n>C) C: wrong house<n>D) D: set table<n>E) E:gettable<n><n>### Solution:<n>A) A)Play chessB) sun themselvesC) Wrong houseD) set tableE) gettable<n>Rationales: E is the correct response because all the other options are all places they can go.<n>### Rationale:<n>A:Play chess - Not all children go home when they are confused, they might play chess in their friend's house.<n>B) Sun themselves -This could only happen if the neighborhood they live in is a great place for sunbathing.<n>C) Wrong house - The child would have to be going home to the wrong house and then go to the right house to get help.<n>D) Set table - What child is going to set the table? All they care about is to get help to find home safely.<n><n>### Input :How tall do you have to go to see a hawk flying? Choices: A: less than 30 B: less than 35 C: less than 40 D: more than 50 E: more than 75<n><n>---<n><n>### Rationale<n><n>E is correct because hawks are large birds that are found in open fields such as in Australia, Africa and America. In any city it's unlikely that you will see a hawk except for maybe a falcon flying over a football stadium.<n><n>---<n><n>**A) A)Play Chess:** A child should play chess with someone to know the rules. You should not play chess in the winter because it may be too cold outside.<n><n>----<n><n>**E) E: Gettable:** A child who may get lost should be able to stay warm if they get lost.<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:A strong laxative will help you keep what kind of bowel movements? Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where would you carry a pen as you go through your day? Choices:  A: pocket B: office supply store C: friend's house D: desk drawer E: city hall<n><n>### Response:		<n>B(office supplies - it used to be A(Pocket) back in the day.<n><n>### <n>It's always A(Pocket) - it's used to be B(Office supply) back in the day as your writing tool.<n>#### E<n><n>* <n>

For example, if people are ordering pizza at a restaurant, we should not ask if it's delivered or not, because it depends on the customers situation.<n><n>### Answer:C)<n><n>### Ratiocinator:<n>The problem is "Do I want thin crust or not?" so that's how we know the input is "Do not". If we wanted thick crust, the input would be "Do" instead of "Do not". The output is "I cannot eat pizza."<n><n>### Answer:(B)<n><n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The children saw superman fly overhead, what did they exclaim as a result? Choices:  A: ouch B: skip C: enjoyed D: awesome E: watch television<n><n>### Response:		D <n><n>#### 4 <n><n># Challenge:<n>Choices:  A: I am a woman B: I am a man C: I am the queen D: I am a prince I am the queen<n><n>### Response D<n><n>### Note:<n>Please write a comment about this section.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where should an excavation never take place? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The clothing was extremely expensive compared to other places, where was it likely purchased? His notes for his Economics class are blue, his notes from English are green and his notes from his Art class are red. He has 45 blue, 69 green and 42 red notes in all. How much does he have of each? Write the correct expression of the amount of blue, green and red notes in Jan's notebook in the order of smallest number to largest number.<n>Notes:<n>Jan has:<n>45 blue >><<45>> <<blue>><n>69 green <<69>> <<green>><n>42 red <<42>> <<red>><n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>#### 45<n>Notes:<n>225<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Jan is writing each note 45 times (blue), 69 times (green) and 42 times (red).<n>All three notes must add up to 225.<n>45 + 69 + 42 = <<45+69+42=156>>156(the only way to make 225).<n>Therefore, the number of each note must equal to 45(blue), 69(green) and 45(red) to make 227.<n><n>### Example:<n><n>####<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:They don't get grades or sit at desks, but crowds of fish do what? Choices:  A: pets B: fills the pond C: attempt to fly D: school together E: breath in water<n><n>### Response:		<n>We are going to go with B for this question, because that's the one that makes the most sense but it could also be A.<n>Crowds of fish do what ever they want. They either school, or swim to whatever they want.<n><n>#1 : <n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where is one likely to hear a harpsichord? Choices:  A: make noise B: band C: museum D: concert hall E: rubber band<n><n>### Response:		<n>A) Harpsichord is likely to be in E) Rubber band since the string is plucked in it and not hit.<n><n>### Alternative A:<n>When we hear the harpsichord, we usually hear from B) In a concert hall since harpsichord is played in the concert hall.<n><n>### Answer:<n>D) In a concert hall<n><n>### Input :<n>Betty’s parents have two and a half times more children than her. One sister is younger than Betty. If Betty has five children, how many children does her youngest brother have?<n><n>### Response :<n>Betty has five children and one sibling that is her youngest brother. Therefore, Betty has a total of six children. Her brother should have three children and therefore the answer to Betty’s question is nine.<n><n>```python<n>print("Answer",  " ", "Nine")<n>```<n><n><n>### Correct Answer<n><n>```python<n>answer = input("answer: ")<n><n>print(answer)<n>```<n><n>```python<n>9<n>```<n><n>### Alternate input<n><n>```python<n>while True:<n>    print("answer: ")<n>    answer = input()<n>    print(answer)<n>    if(answer == "9"):<n>        break<n>```<n><n><n>---<n>#### [![MIT License](https://img.shields.io/badge/License-MIT-brightgreen.svg)](https://opensource.org/licenses/MIT)<n><n>#### Copyright(c) 2019 by Annie Cao <n>---<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:How often are secular parties held? Choices:  A: short term B: crowd C: unpredictable D: frequent E: eternal<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choices:<n>- Choice A has the same number of letters as the correct answer.<n>- Choices B, C, and D have the same number of letters in each choice.<n>Answer: <n>  -C: unpredictable<n><n>### Input : Mara has 12% more credit cards than Janet has. How many credit cards does Mara have?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Answer: 1.2 Janet has 12% less than Mara 2.2 x 5 % = <<2.2x5%=11%>>11% of the number of cards 3.2 x 5% = <2.2x5%>=11% of the numbers<n><n>### Inputs : Cynthia does one third of the work that Diana does. Diana does 5 more units. How many units have they all done?<n><n>### Response :<n>Answer : Diana does 1/16 of the number, so all of there units are 16 units total.<n><n>### Input  : What is 0.3 * 0.1?<n><n>### Output : Choose an answer: <.1>.01<n>### Output  :<n><n>### Demorstration :<n>0.1 is 10% and 0.1 * 0.1 is.1^2= 0.01<n><n>### Multiple Choice : Choose an answer from the choices below and click Submit. <n>- Choice A is 1/10.<n>- Choice B is 1/1,000.<n>- Choose C 1/1,200<n>- Choice D 1/1200<n><n>### Demomoration :

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The mother was worried about all the spills, so she bought a rug for under the what? A number is abundant if its divisors, which are the numbers a+b, all add up to more than the number being divided. 14 is an even number with 4 as the lowest prime number divisor, that is not the case for 15 so 14 doesn’t factor 15<n><n>### Comment<n>You could get the answer to the question that has the highest likelihood to be right and then check the rest<n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where would you dispose of a broken icebox? Choices:  A: antique store B: in the graveyard C: kitchen D: junk yard E: ice<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Rationales:The Icebox is used to preserve ice, therefore ice is used in Iceboxes. However iceboxes are now outdated/broken, therefore iceboxes are broken. When disposed of, iceboxes are taken to a junkyard. Thus the best answer is D. The broken icebox would be taken to a junk yard.<n><n>#### A<n><n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input:"I know you like spending time with your dad more than I do," her sister said. "That's why I get mad at you for hanging out so much."<n><n>### Response:"So you're saying we're both selfish."<n><n>### Rationale:The sister stated that she gets mad at her sister for hanging out with her dad more. However the sister is selfish for getting mad at her sister for doing something she enjoys. Therefore their statement is both selfish and incorrect. How many games did their team play last season?<n><n><img src=../../image/2C.png alt="Image" width=135px height=80px><n><n>Rationales: If a soccer team plays 12 months total, the total number of games the team played could be one, two, or three. Based on the number of months there are each school year, the boys played 13 months. Therefore, there are 12 months per year, and 13 months equals 155 games.<n>#### 155<n>Answer: 155<n><n>### Instuctions:Analyze each selection choice, select the best answer.<n><n>Input:Choose a mathematical operation to solve the below equation. <img src=../../image1/2D.png alt="Image"/><n><n><img src="/image1/2D_

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where could you find a theater which only has unpaid actors? Choices:  A: shopping mall B: hospitals C: populated area D: school E: military base<n><n>### Response:		A: shopping malls have free entertainment and often have auditions for a show to cast members for an upcoming production.<n><n>### Input- 11. Brenda gave her grandmother 75 cards and she gave Brenda 9 cards.<n>Janet gave her aunt 45 cards and she gave Janet 54 cards.<n>How many card games  did they play in all?<n>#### 168<n>Answer: 168<n><n>### Instructions:<n>### 15.<n><n>### Answer:<n>#### 459<n>Answer: 459<n>

(C)<n>2) Input:5 x 5 = 25<n>Rationales: 5 x 5 = (5 x 1) x 5 = 0.25 (25); we divide the sum 5 into 5, so that we have a decimal number. (A)<n>2) Input:"4" ^ 2<n>Rationales: Square root, so that we can represent the number 2. That's about ___________ (inches). Choices: inches B: feet E: inches of a person C: centimeters<n>```<n><n>### Instuctions Answer the following multiple choice <n><n>### Demstration<n>```text<n>Input:<n>An average person is about 5 foot 10 inches tall =><n>=> The length of that average person is about ___________ (feet). Choices:<n>feet<n>inches<n>inches of a person<n>centimeters <n>```<n>### Rationales<n><n>```text<n>In a average person, height: 5'10"<n>in a inch: 1" =.0833 inch<n><n>Therefore, 1 inch = [1 ft * 12 in * 1 inch] / 12 in. => 12.0833 / 12 = 1 inch<n><n>Average height: 1) Average height = T * 12 = ⅔ * 12<n><n>Therefore, Average height = 5'10 = 101cm<n><n>5" = 101/cm<n><n>5 " = cm<n>5 "

Manhattan has no bay.<n><n>#### C<n>If the answer is C, then the city has bay as it is shoreline since it is a coastal area.<n><n>#### D<n>If the answer is D, then the city has coastal bay as it is coastal area and has no shoreline.<n><n>#### E<n>If the answer is E, then the city has ocean bay as it is a coastal areas city.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The man set the cup on the table.  It didn't matter.   He didn't heave anything to put it on, and he lacked the what to balance it? Choices:  A: tenacity B: hands C: coaster D: skill E: breaking<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input :The man set the cup of the table.  It all that mattered.   He didn' care had to set it on, and he didn' know with put it on?  Choices:  A.Tenacity B.Hands C.Coaster D.Skill E.Breakage<n><n>### Response::<n>Answer: A<n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What type of person typically contracts illness? Choices:  A: hospital B: head C: sick person D: elderly person E: doctor's office<n><n>### Response:		<n>A correct response includes an explanation or a situation that identifies why the correct choice indicates a person who typically contracts illness. Ex: hospital, doctor's office(not D or E because D and E are where people go when they are sick or to avoid being sick)<n><n>### Rationale:<n>All sick people go to hospital to be treated. When it is their turn to get treatment at hospital, they typically contract the illness. Therefore, hospital is the correct choice.<n><n>### Alternative Response:<n>The correct response includes an explanation, situation or answer that is NOT a person who typically contract contracts illness.<n>#### 25 points<n><n>#### Explanation:<n><n>Expected Output: 99<n><n>#### Input:<n>Which should be a good score?

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What kind of place could have a seafood restaurant? Choices:  A: new york B: coastal cities C: city D: coastal cities E: boston<n><n>### Response:		<n>Janet has 9 cards. Brenda has 46 cards <n><n>- Mara has 110 cards in all

What are project planning and project management?  <n>   - Project Management is the practice of planning, organizing, motivating, and controlling resources to achieve specific goals.  <n>   - The Project Manager makes decisions about the people, organization, tools, technology, risks, scheduling and resources, and communications needed to deliver a project.  <n>   - Project Planning is the process of generating a work plan for a project. Project planning consists of four phases: Planning, Execution, Monitoring and Control, and Evaluation.  <n><n>- 2. How is projects different from operations?    <n>   - Projects produce products and operations produces services<n>   - Project Management is temporary and includes the beginning and end points of a project.  <n>Operation Management is ongoing processes that help an organization make on

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:She loved buying products, she was driven by her what to shop more than any practical needs? Choices:  A: desire B: money C: time D: credit E: spending money<n><n>### Response:		<n>The response should appropriately address the question (“What led her to shop more than any other practical needs?”) and follow standard written English conventions. If you add or remove any additional options in your response, you will be penalized.<n><n>**B**<n>The question should prompt some consideration about the character’s needs/motives, so it should be addressed and not ignored.<n>However, the question shouldn’t be answered through your own assumptions of the story without the author’s guidance or further context, e.g. “I think she was addicted to online shopping because she was always connected to the internet and her credit account.”

Choices:  A: jerusalem B: jewish community C: middle east D: city E: mosque<n><n>### Response:		jerusalem<n>```<n>  Jerusalem is located in between Israel, Palestine (West Bank), and Jordan (East Bank) – a geographical area called the Holy Land by Jews, Christians, Muslims, and other peoples. Jerusalem contains many sites particularly sacred to these different religions. In the Old City of Jerusalem, the Jewish Quarter, the Muslim Quarter, the Christian Quarter, and the Armenian Quarter are inhabited by the followers of those faiths.<n>```<n><n>### Input2:Which continent is home to the country of Afghanistan? Choices: A: asia B: westasia C: europe D: eastasia E: middle east F: australasia<n><n>### Response2: asia<n>```<n>    Afghanistan is a landlocked country in southern Asia, north of Pakistan, west of Tajikistan, Iran, and Turkmenistan, and east of Iran. About 3 times bigger than Florida, the South Asian nation of Afghanistan, has been a crossroads for civilizations throughout history.<n>```<n><n>#### 8397<n>Input:Which continent is closest to Canada? Choices: A : americas B : africa C : europe D : asia E : australasia<n><n>#### Response: asia<n>``` <n>    Canada has a coastline more than 150,000 km (93,200 mi) long. It's bordered by the U.S. to the northwest and by the Pacific, Atlantic, and Arctic oceans to the southeast. It has 10 provinces and 3 territories, and many islands. Its total area covers more than 9.9 million square km.<n>```<n><n>``` <n>    Asia is the world's biggest and most populous continent, located primarily in the eastern and northern hemispheres. It covers 8.7% of the Earth's total surface area and comprises 30% of its land area. The continent, which has long been home to the majority of the world's population, is projected to become home to 5 billion people by 2050.<n>```

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:East coast areas such as Florida are found where? Choices:  A: florida B: denmark C: united states D: map E: california<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n><n>### Demorstration:<n>A is an answer.<n>Florida is in the east c0ast of United States.<n>California is in the west coast of United States.<n>Denmark is in Europe.. and Europe is not located in east coast of United States.  <n>A Florida is what we are looking for.<n>#### D<n>Answer: california<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Ben was an alcoholic and was in an accident.  Because of his mistake, he spent 8 years somewhere. Where was he? Choices:  A: prison B: bridge C: locked up D: homeless shelter E: neighbor's house<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### The D option, which means that Ben slept at a homeless shelter, is not a reasonable response. This is because since Ben was an alcoholic, he should remain at the shelter for life.<n><n>#### The A option, which means that he spent 8 years in prison, is reasonable as he spent those 8 years at prison for breaking the rule about not drinking.<n><n>#### The B option, which means that the bridge fell down, is not reasonable as Ben is not supposed to fall down the bridge and as it would be cruel to him.<n><n>#### The C option, which means that is locked up, is also not reasonable because Ben is not supposed to be locked up.<n><n>#### The E option, which is to be sent to a neighbor's house, is reasonably the option the teacher will choose as Ben would not be alone there but rather with lots of friends.

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What could prevent someone from buying chistmas presents? Choices: A B C D None of these<n><n>### Instructions-Question:The solution for this case is...<n><n>### Demostration-Question:Use the word bank for this question to create a question that you can answer like we did with the demonstration question.<n><n>#### Answer 1<n><n>Answer 1:<n><n>### Answer 2<n>Answer 2: I would not swim under water without a gps tracker.<n><n>### Answer: 813<n><n>### Answer-Question:What are some safety measures you employ to prevent a fall while skiing?<n><n>### Demos:Ski safety measures<n><n>Ski safety, which involves safety at all levels, is paramount for the success of activities such as skiing. For example, the International Ski Federation issues guidelines on the issue. These include, amongst other things, the need to comply with ski area rules and the safety and instruction in certain areas. Ski instructors must be accredited for many of these.<n><n>#### Reference:-[Ski safety](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ski_safety)<n><n>### Instructons:-What are the rules of ski resorts?<n><n>### Response:-Risk assessment <n><n>#### Safety<n>```<n>Purpose: To ensure the health of the employees and to make the working environment safe for all.<n>Scope: To be applied to all employees and customers working at all SAP company.<n>Definition: Risk assessment: a systematic and organised appraisal of risks to an individual, group or the general public.<n>```<n><n>Risk assessments do not reduce risks to zero or completely eliminate workplace hazards. The primary consideration is that steps must be taken to reduce the risk to an acceptable level. The most appropriate actions
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where are there more telephone booths? Choices:  A: gas stations B: city C: london D: train station E: airport<n><n>### Response:		Gas stations are the only places where we'll find more telephone booth areas than the others.

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:How might a person address someone who is leaving? How many apples does Jim have now?<n><n>### Response<n><n>11<n><n>## Solutions<n><n><n>![](https://drive.google.com/uc?id=1bzjSXmRKuHQDl_Y86kWLVfHYl27_hjFd)<n><n><n>## Answers<n><n>How may we address someone who is leaving an office space? <n><n>Choice C<n><n>Choice A would be an example of a sarcastic remark to insult the person leaving. B is a goodbye. D is an angry declaration of wanting to kill them, which wouldn’t be appropriate for the office. <n><n><n>How did Jim solve the problem?<n><n>Jim has 10 apples because he gave half of what he owned away.<n><n><n>1. Why is Jim's remaining amount equal to 11 apples?<n><n>The first half, or 10 apples, is equal to 2 and the second half equals 10.<n><n><n>1011=2×10+11<n><n><n><n><n><n>![](./files/45964F66-568D-4AA0-A2E5-562DCC964514.gif)

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What enables most people to transport themselves? Choices:  A: helicopter B: own cars C: speak words D: believe in god E: dance together<n><n>### Response:		<n>C<n><n>### Note:<n>If one does not believe in God and does not dance but uses Cars and words it is still possible to transport themselves.<n><n>### Input : What type of music is most likely to be a song? Choice: A: ballad B: Hip-hop C: pop D: funk E: hardrock<n><n>### Demostration:<n>A<n><n>### Note : If one is given the choice of Ballad, Pop, Funk, etc the options are limited therefore only ballads can be song<n><n>### Input<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>### Note<n>The number of questions cannot be more than or less than three.<n><n>- Choose a lettered answer choice and mark the appropriate response.<n>- Use the drop down menu to choose the letters in the correct sequence.<n><n>### Demo:<n>Input:Which letter is fourth from the left?<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Because 4(or 4th) is second from the right or B. 4th means 4th from the right or 8th from the left if the 2nd and 3rd are skipped. Here 8th from the right is D.<n><n>### Answer: D<n><n>### Input <n>Which number is most often used in music? A) 2, B) 4, C) 7, D) 8, E) 11<n><n>## Demonstration <n>D 7<n><n>## Note<n>The correct answer is usually 1 through 7 in a set of 11 notes.<n><n>## Input<n>Is D or 7 closest to the letter I?<n><n>## Demonstraion <n><n>D : <n><n>## Note<n>Letters are counted normally forwards and backwards in order for the answer. Therefore, I becomes D and 7 becomes 9, (the 2nd letter). Therefore D is the correct answer.<n><n>## Input <n>A, B, C, D, E, or F is most often a letter in a written number.<n><n>## Demostration <n><n>E:<n><n>## Note<n>E is usually found after B,C,D,F and before A and G. For example: 29(which stands for 2+9). In this instance E

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where is basketball court likely to be outdoors? Choices:  A: high school gymnasium B: city C: park D: use E: los angeles<n><n>### Response:		D. Los Angeles. A high school gymnasium is an indoor-only option, as it would make little to no sense for basketball to be played outside. Parks do not qualify as outdoor basketball courts, either, as we would never think to play basketball there. Finally, city is not logical; cities should always include outdoor spaces as part of the definition. This leaves one of the remaining options — the “use” option. This is correct. Los Angeles is a city that includes many outdoor spaces, including basketball courts.

He didn't want any meat for it.  Where might Simon be taking the cow? Choices:  A: countryside B: city C: dairy farm D: butcher shop E: canada<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input:Simon bought a farm so that he could milk the cow (a dairy cow is bred for producing milk).<n><n>### Output:<n>Output: Simon bought a cow because then he would be able to provide the cow with milk.<n><n>### Discussion:<n>Answer: D: butcher shop<n><n>### Demanded Value<n>Answer: D<n><n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Input:Rosita can ride a horse one 1.2 times as fast as Maria.  If each of them ride at the same pace for 4 times,  how many  rides will  Rosita have had  by then?<n><n>### Instructed response:<n><n>### Instruption 1:<n><n>### Output 1 and/or Discussion 1:<n>Output: Rosita ride a horse for 4x1.2= <<4x1.2>>4 times faster than Maria does. So when Rosita and Maria ride 4 time faster, Maria will ride 4 times slower. So the time will also be 4 times slower.<n><n>Rosita time=4 times faster than Maria time.<n><n>Rosita=4<n>Maria=1<n>Therefore, when Rosita and Maria each ride 4 times faster, they will ride 4 times faster than they would have if they had ridden with the same speed.  So when Maria and Rosita ride 4 times faster and Maria had to ride 4 times more slower then she would only need to ride 1/4 of the time.<n><n>Thus she will be riding for <<1/4>>1/4 times faster than when it went first.<n><n>Thus, she would ride once as she would when she started<n><n>Maria=4<n>Rosita=1<n>Therefore,, they will be riding for<n><n>Maria=1/(1/4) =10/4= <<10/4>>2.5 times faster than when it  went  first. <n><n> Thus her ride will be  <<10/4>>(1/2.5)= 4 times as longer.<n><n>When Rosita and Maria ride for 4 times she will have rode 2.5 times as much as Maria had ridden while they were riding together.<n><n>Th
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:If I want to maximize my number of potential customers, where should I build a new department store? Choices:  A: idaho B: shopping mall C: big city D: in town E: new york<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Note:<n>This question was asked of an employee who is trying to determine in which location to build a new department store. She is attempting to maximize the number of potential customers. The location in Idaho is the answer because it has no other department stores so it is the only potential location with the lowest number of customers nearby.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:I'm at a restaurant ans want a glass of milk, how do I find out if they serve that? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Jimmy didn't like going to the party.  It seemed like the guys there did nothing but what? Choices:  A: dance B: getting drunk C: meet new people D: having fun E: have fun<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Rationale:The question uses the present progressive tense: _were doing_. The use of the word _seemed_ and the context (the question directly asks whether Jimmy didn't like the party) indicate that the activity was not happening.  Hence, there was no doing happening since the question specifies that Jimmy didn't like it.<n><n>### Input 2: What does the expression in bold in the paragraph mean?  Choices:  A__: of the two choices  B__: of the options available  C__: of the two reasons  D__: of the choices  E__: of the reasons<n><n>### Responsel:C<n><n>### Rationales:The text is asking what the bolded sentence means.  The use of the word  _of_ implies it is referring to the noun in front of it in this case _the two reasons_.  The phrase is parallel in structure: _of the two reasons_ and _of the two choices_.  That is, it is modifying the noun phrase that comes before the bolded sentence.<n><n>### AI: How does the text make me feel?<n><n>### Instructions:  Circle as many responses as apply.<n><n>### ​​​A__: angryB__: boredC__: confused D__: disgustedE__: disappointedF__: frustratedG__: gladH__: surprisedI__: thankfulJ__: scared/shocked <n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where is small knight likely to be found? Choices:  A: fairy tale B: castle C: middle ages D: chess board E: doll house<n><n>### Response:		I believe the small knight is likely to be found on D. The description says that the knight is small. To be found on a chess board, the knight would likely have to be the king's knight, but that is too tall. The castle is made of stones and it seems that the knight is unlikely to be in a castle. A fairy tale may seem like it could contain a small knight, but it does not describe the small knight. A doll house would have its own little knight but a small knight is not small enough to be a doll. Therefore, I believe that the small knight can be found on D.

B: Is a debate not more useful or fun? C: Is a debate no more useful than fun D:  Is a debate no fun?  E: Is a debate more fun?<n><n>Answer: A<n><n>### Instructor's Justification:<n><n>As a general rule, A is the statement that is supported by the evidence, while B is the statement that runs against the evidence. <n><n>* B asserts that it is more useful than fun, but according to the question we should believe it's the opposite of that statement (it's more fun than useful).<n>* For statement B to be the correct choice, it would have to have the words "not more useful or fun" in it, but there are no variations of this.<n>* So, if the question was phrased more effectively, B would be the correct answer. <n><n>However, based on the choice offered, the question phrasing does not support B correctly, although there are other valid reasons to support choice B. <n><n>### Input :<n><n>* What might two people competing do instead of having a dispute/disagreement/fight/struggle/tangle/clash/spat/rivalry/rivalry battle/contention 1: A: have a debate. A list is a collection of names arranged in no particular order. For example: Michael, Bill, Frank.<n> <n> <n>B. A set is a collection of items, in which each item falls in a certain range. For example: 2, 3, 4, 5.<n><n>Answer: A: front door B. Front door is not in alphabetical order.<n>C. Conference is in alphabetical order. <n><n>### Feeback<n><n>Rationales (repeat same rationale as above)<n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The obsessive man was always washing hands, he had even done it so much once that it caused a what? Choices:  A: use soap B: irritation C: cleanliness D: thinking E: wet towel<n><n>### Response:		Cleanliness caused him to wet a towel as much as soap and it led to him thinking<n><n>### Input : What does a cow do if it is in pain and not milked<n><n>### Response : It will lie down.<n><n>### Input :- What must have to be done before you can enter the class.<n><n>### Response - Enter from outside the class.<n><n><n>### Input:- Where does our teacher usually go during the break to meet us?<n><n>### Response:- On the playground<n><n><n>### The instructions is:The teacher will meet us all on the playground during the break.  <n><n>### The task is:  Choose an appropriate response.

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The priest pushed for more orthodox behavior, what kind of behavior was he trying to stop? Choices:  A: liberal B: heretical C: recalcitrant D: conservadox E: heretical<n><n>### Response:		<n>- Liberal<n><n>### Rationales:Answer: Liberal. According to the passage, more orthodox behavior means religious behavior that is more strict. As stated in the passage, liberal behavior represents religious behavior that is more lenient. Therefore, they are trying to stop religious behavior that is more liberal. Answer Choices: A, B, C, D, E<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:If I have to keep track of how much oxygen there is, where am I? Choices:  A: air B: water C: earth D: space shuttle E: tunnel<n><n>### Response:		Input:<n>The correct answer is "A: air".<n><n>Earth has the most oxygen out of all the answer choices.<n>1. Air - contains most of the oxygen.<n>2. Water - has the second-most of oxygen.<n>3. Earth - has the third-most of oxygen, and<n>4. Space shuttle - least of oxygen.<n><n>### Output:Air is the correct answer.<n><n>### Input<n>### Output

Choices:  a) pasta b) rice c) beans d) none of these e) pizza f) bread g) apples h) lettuce i) cake j) cookies<n><n>### Response1:<n>```<n>The answers for the choices are:<n>a: b<n>c: f<n>g: h<n>i: o<n>```<n><n>## Demonstration1:<n>```<n>c= f= <<f=f>><n>```<n><n>```<n>g= h = <<h=h>><n>```<n><n>Inserting a period into an expression and multiplying by the chosen food gives the correct answer for each choice, though other factors could affect the decision.<n><n>## Demonstattion2<n>```<n>g = <<g=g>><n>```<n><n>The rest of the choices produce letters.<n><n>## Input: 15x8 &lt; 0<n><n>## Response:<n>```<n>There is a sign error since 15x8>0.<n>```<n><n>## Instuctions:<n>Write a program that reads and displays a 10 digit phone number from the keyboard and a message that contains each digit in the input in its proper place. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where would you put a dictionary while you're using it? Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where would you find people gathered near liquid in a workplace? Choices:  A: water cooler B: opera C: hospital D: hockey game E: beach<n><n>### Response:		<n>You would find people gathered near liquid In a ** workplace**<n><n>### Outcome:<n>If you choose option A then your answer is incorrect.<n>If you choose option B then your answer is correct because you would find people around a water cooler.<n>If you choose options C to E then your answer is incorrect because you would find people near these places for recreational purposes and not for a workplace.<n><n>#### 4<n>Answer : B<n><n>### Instructions:Which of the following are 3-digit numbers that end in 4? Choices:  a: 13, 14 b: 24, 25 c: 34, 35 d: 43, 44 e: 51, 54, 55 f: 81, 83 g: 91, 94 h: 96<n><n>### Response<n>\*Choices for 3-digit numbers ending in 4 are: 13,14,34,35,44,44,83,94,96.<n><n>### Outcomes<n>If you choose options a: then your answer is incorrect you would only need to choose 13.<n>If you choose Option c: your answer is correct you would need to choose 34 and 35.<n>if you choose options d: then your answer is correct you only need 43 and 44.<n>If you choose choice e: your answer is incorrect because it would include numbers that include 54,55 and other.<n>If you choose H: then, your answer is incorrect because your answer is not including all the choices.<n><n>#### 2<n>Answer: D<n><n>\*10, 31, 42, __, 49, 50, 58, 69<n><n>\*49, 58, and 69 are the missing numbers of the sequence. You can also solve this using the code of the instructions "10, 3, 19, 42,____, 49, 69" then you can insert the given choices into it and the given choices and the missing numbers would be the same.<n><n># 2021
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where could you find a fox hunting when not in a forest? Choices:  A: open meadow B: arctic tundra C: beach D: great outdoors E: england<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: B) Arctic tundra<n><n>### Input:-60^2=-300^<n><n>### Response:-60=-300<n><n>### Instructions: Write the correct word to fill the blank in the sentence.<n><n>A. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where would you find performers on a platform in public? Choices:  A: arena B: building C: dock D: concert hall E: museum<n><n>### Response:		<n>A.Arena<n><n>### Rationale :<n>The only correct answer is arena.<n><n>### Input :<n>What is the average temperature in April May and June for the past 15 years?<n><n>### Response :<n>The first thing we do is look for an easy way to see the answer. We use a t-distribution to see if things are distributed normally.<n><n>### Rational:<n><n>In a normal distribution, the mean, median, and mode all occur at the same value.<n><n>We can use a t-distribution when comparing two population normally. We want to know if the population is normally distributed.<n><n>The t-distribution is a normal distribution where its shape is dependent on the amount we take from a population. <n><n>For the purpose of our answer, an independent and normally distributed set of data can be called a population.<n><n>We can make a distribution of the population like this: Take from the population and add these numbers up (50 samples), then put the number in a normal distribution. If the sample is not normally distributed, we know it is not a normal population, and we take it from that population. Otherwise, it is normally distributed, and will fit the population.<n><n>It is important to note, we will not always have a normally distributed population.<n>The t-distribution curve is a "bell curve", but its shape is different from the normal or bell curve. It is a bumped version of a bell curve.<n><n>For the past four years, the average temperature has been between 67 and 68 degrees, which are both at 68 degrees. <n><n>If our population was normally distributed, our sample population would be normally distributed. In a normally distributed population, a different size sample will have a different shape but a normal distribution curve shape.<n><n>For the year 1998, we can take a look at how the population is normally distributed: 1998 gives us 63 degrees in its sample. However, in normal distributions, the shape is bumped up and down, even if it is normally distributed. <n><n>From the year 1988, the mean of the first three years is 66 degrees.<n><n>If this is the shape of the population, the difference between this and the average temperature of the past two years will be 95 - 66 = <<95-6
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:A balloon or two is a staple at a what? Choices:  A: birthday party B: child's hand C: grocery store D: sky E: up in the<n><n>### Response:		<n>E - up in the<n><n>**Explanation:**<n>An example of an item a child commonly has in his or her hand/hands is a balloon or two.<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The movie had many a song and dance, it was a what? Choices:  A: bollywood B: record C: musical D: jukebox E: napster<n><n>### Response:		Both Jan and Matt were tired, but Jan was a lot more sleepy than Matt. It had been a long day and they were already exhausted from the previous days work. Matt went to get some water while Jan lay down on their mattress with the lights off and relaxed. After a short nap, she woke up feeling refreshed and sat up in the bed, excited to see Matt finish watering the plants outside their home and ready to spend some quality time together.<n><n>Answer:B<n><n>#### A<n>Answer:A<n><n>#### C<n>Answer:C<n><n>#### D<n>Answer:D<n><n>#### E<n>Answer:E<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>1. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Many containers full of goods are unloaded where after their long sea journey Choices:  A: port B: cargo ship C: refrigerator D: food E: lorry<n><n>### Response:		Choose A because a port is where ships are unloaded, and this is after a long sea journey.<n><n>### 040<n>### Input: You have a large bag of potato chips.How do you decide to eat them:<n>When there's something to eat, you'll eat it!?<n>A: I'll open the bag and eat them when I see anyone.<n>B: One by one until they're all gone.<n>C: After every school until there's no one else.<n>D: Only on special occasions.<n><n>### Choice:<n><n>C: After every one until they're gone.<n><n>### Reason: If you have 10 bags of potato chips and you'll finish one by one, you'll eat 10 chips.<n>If you do it after every one until they'e gone, you'll have 10 chips left!<n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where are seats most likely bleachers? Choices:  A: movies B: opera C: theater D: lecture hall E: hockey game<n><n>### Response:		<n>Since movies can have more than a couple hundred people in seats, the seats are more likely not to be in a bleacher.<n>Since operas can have a couple hundred people in a small space, the seats are not likely to be in a bleachers.<n>Theater can have hundreds of seats, so it's likely the seats are not in a bleachers space.<n>A lecture hall will likely have the seats in a bleachers arrangement. However, if there are over 500 seats the seats might be arranged in a more stadium-style.<n>Since hockey games are generally attended by a few hundred people, the seats are likely to be in a more stadium style.<n>####<n><n>### Input : Which one of these things could have the same mass?<n><n>### Response<n><n>Mass is a property of a substance, so the only one that needs to be the same is the density.<n><n>####<n><n>## Solution:<n><n>### Answer: Write an integer or fractional answer.<n><n>#### 48<n>Answer: 48<n><n>### Input-response<n>1. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where are you if your reading magazines while waiting for a vehicle on rails? Choices: 2 m, 5 m, 3 m, 8 m, 450 m, 350 m, 11 m, 650 m, 525 m, 2 ml, 50 ml, 5 ml.<n><n>### Answer <n>Rational: If the glass of water can hold 0.5 litre of water. Then, it will take 2 glasses to be 1 litre, 4 to be 2 litre, 8 to be 3 litre, and so on.<n>Therefore, 1 litre = 0.5 kg, 2 litre = 1 kg, 3 litre = 1.5 kg.<n>Thus, there would be 2 m + ((5 x 2) - (1 x 2) = 10 m.<n><n>#### 2 m. + 10 m<n>Answer: 12 m<n><n>### Rational: <n>Rational: A car can travel for 80 km for every five litres of petrol it uses. How many kilometres can a car travel for every 100 litres of petrol?<n><n>### Answer<n>Rational:  By dividing each side by 5, we do 80/5 = <<80/5= 16>> 16.<n>Therefore, the car will travel 16 times 100 kilometres = <<16x100=1600>> 1,600 kilometres.<n><n>#### 1600 km<n>Answer: 1600<n>

There were 356 violent crimes in 2014 and 216 in 2015. Last year, Scott's average day includes arresting roughly 1 violent criminal per day. Scott also performs an evaluation of the town regularly and makes some comments as to how it might improve.<n><n>Scott thinks that, if every resident has a burglar alarm system, it would reduce the crime rate by 5%. Scott suspects that this same principle would work nationwide if alarm systems became more widely available. This, however, would make them expensive and people would have to have their houses burglarized to justify the cost. He also thinks that the town would decrease crime even further if he patrolled the town every other night. Scott thinks that this would increase the town’s overall crime rate by 7%.<n><n>Scott thinks the best course of action is to buy a house that’s currently on the market for $1400,000 and is located two blocks away from his house. From that house, Scott would be able to see into every house in the area. From that house, he would be able to easily survey the town and see if anything is amiss.<n><n>Scott suspects that every house has a burglar alarm that has been set before nightfall. He also thinks that if the burglars can see that a house is not occupied, they will not attempt to break in.<n><n>### Response : E<n><n>### Dem:<n>The answer is B.<n><n>### 214<n>### Input: What is a difference between a set and a relation? How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Sally was a senior in the House.  What might she be a member of? Choices:  A: assisted living facility B: old people's home C: high school or college D: republican party E: organization<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>**A:** assisted living facility (Sally was a senior)<n><n>### Input:"I was going to get a new car but now I do not want to get one." What statement is Sally probably making? Anger? A: displeasure at having bought it before B: excitement or enthusiasm about the sale C: pleasure at not having to purchase it D: satisfaction from buying the car<n><n>### ResponseA:<n><n>**B:** excitement or enthusiasm (Because I was going to get a car).<n><n>### InputHow many more times does Troy have to hit that target to hit it with one more chance? A: 38 times B: 18 times C: 31 times D: 53 time<n><n>### ResponseD:<n><n>**53*/38 times** is the right answer.<n>
