Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:John lives in Texas. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:John loves animals and he hates animal abuse.  Because of this, john is very careful about the places he goes.  Where might he avoid going? Choices:  A: pet store B: parking lot C: woodland D: north america E: park<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: B, C, D, and E are examples that might cause animal abuse.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:If you see blinking lights in the air at night, what are you usually looking at? Choices:  A: carnival B: plane C: concert D: turned at night E: a penguin's bum<n><n>### Response:		I would usually see blinking lights in a concert.<n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where in your home would you store birth control pills near your toothpaste? Choices:  A: medicine cabinet B: chemist's shop C: kitchen D: drug store E: bedroom<n><n>### Response:		Birth control pills are often kept in the refrigerator along with perishable foods like meat, poultry, fish, milk, cheese, etc. Some people prefer to keep these medications with them in a convenient location so they can take them as directed. One option that is a close neighbor to the living room (or kitchen) is by the side of the refrigerator.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Medicine cabinets and bathroom shelves are common locations for toothpaste. Many people store over the counter medications in the bathroom as well. These places do not typically have refrigeration. They usually have an electric socket.<n><n>Many bedroom windows would not be appropriate for the type of shelf you suggested, plus it could be difficult to keep birth control pills out of the sight of children. Storing birth control pills in the bathroom could be inconvenient if a woman is taking medicine frequently. Keeping them with the refrigerated foods makes it convenient and less expensive. However, if you keep many prescriptions in the refrigerater, then it may be necessary to have an electric outlet.<n><n>There are small cabinets by the door that could hold toothpaste. These cabinets are not designed for refrigeration. In a drug store, you pay for medications and a pharmacy provides medication.<n><n>You can purchase prescription and non-prescription medication in a chemist shop. One would not store medications that need refrigeration in the kitchen unless the appliances for refrigeration are in easy reach for this item of equipment.<n><n>### Input Where in your home would you like to put the TV? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where can you find a place to eat and places to buy items of many different kinds? How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:He called bull when his friend said a bull can be what? Choices:  A: feeble B: bullbleep C: cow D: female E: charging prey<n><n>### Response:		bullbleep<n><n>### Rationale: Choice C is the best answer because this is what the question asks, "cattle" is not an animal but something else entirely.<n>Answer: C<n><n>### Input : I told you the cat went outside so you might as well check on him. _______ you would? Choices: 1) A: why B: why not C: yes D: No 2) ______ you?<n><n>### Response : why<n><n>### Rationales: Choice A is wrong because it's not a question it is a statement and Choice B is wrong because the question is already stated why would you need to check on it? Therefore the correct answer must be the choice from which the answer comes out of.<n>Answer: A, B<n><n>### Input &nbsp: Choose the letter of the word(s) from the given choices that best fits within italics: Choices: A: a person, a small car, the car, a small thing B: a small car, the person, a small thing, the car<n><n>### Response&nbsp: the person<n><n>### Rationle : "a" stands for a person/a small car which are both "small things"<n><n>Answer: B<n>### Input&nbsp: Choose the word closest in meaning to the given words: Choices: A. a bicyclist B. cyclist C. rider D. cyclist<n><n>### Response  : cyclist<n><n>## Rationales : Choice C "cyclist" matches the sentence most closely. the difference between an cyclist and riders would be you ride a bike and a cyclist rides a bike<n>Answer:C<n><n>### Input&ampnbsp: This question is asking how many?<n><n>### Rates : This question is asking how much more is in order to get the desired price.<n><n>### Choices A would be an example of an integer if you take away 475 it would end up with the value of 428<n><n>### Choice C would be an example of a ratio if you take away the 50/20 it would be equal to the number<n><n>### Choose: 25 would be a whole number because the whole amount that was subtracted by was 475<n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:James drove his niece to her father.  Where did he drive? Choices:  A: great granddad's house B: family picture book C: brother's house D: family tree E: family reunion<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>#### C<n>Answer: C

Write the sum of -1 and 37<n><n>Rationales:Sum of 0 and 1 = <<sum of 0 and 0..1 = 0>>0<n>Sum of 0 and - 1 = <<sum 0 and - 0..-1 = 0>><n>Sum of 36 and 0 = <<sum of 36 and - 36 = 0>><n><n>- - 1 = 36 + 1<n>+ + 1 = 1 + 36<n>- 1 = 37 - 1<n>+ 1 = 1 - 37<n><n>Answer: {Ans}: 0 + 37 + 36 + -1<n>or else<n>{Ans}: -1 + 3+ 36+0 + 1<n><n>If the following statement is given, write its converse, inverse, contrapositive and<n>possibility of both being false. If the original statement is true or both the converse and inverse are true, mark “T”, if they are false mark “F”. If one of the converses, inverses or contrapositives is true and the opposite of<n>either one is true, mark “T”. If neither one nor the opposite of either converse or inverse is true,<n>but the original statement is true, mark “?”, “if”. If neither one nor their opposites is true and<n>the original statement is false, mark “F”.<n><n>Statement: The probability of getting heads on a fair coin is (1/2).<n><n>### Input<n>####Converse: If the probability of getting tails on a fair coin is 1/2 then the <n>probability of getting heads on a <n>fair coin is (1/1).<n><n>## Input<n><n>### Input Statement: A number is a divisor of 14, if and only if it is a multiple of 2 and a<n>multiple of 7.<n><n>### Response Statement<n>- If and only if:A number is a divisor 14 if it is a multiple 7 and if it is a multiple<n>2. {Ans}:

This method adds the two values stored in its two fields. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What will happen if you are successful when committing suicide? Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:A school is most likely to be located in what sort of zone? This is a simple way to demonstrate through examples.<n><n>### Answer:Scientific Method<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What is a common sign that someone is lying? Choices:  A: ordering dog food online B: avoid eye contact C: feel guilty D: fall asleep E: blush<n><n>### Response:		<n>The answer is A.<n><n>####  A<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input 2:What time of day is easiest to avoid meeting someone in public? Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where can you buy a hairbrush along with bandages? Choices:  A: drugstore B: hospital C: bedroom D: car E: house<n><n>### Response:		B C D E<n><n>### Input::Which of the following best describes the relationship between graphic and vector data? Choices:  a: Graphic data describes data by position, shape, color and number. Vector data describes data by position only. b: Vector data describes data by attributes and position. Graphic data describes data using only position. c: Graphic data describes a point in 3D space using attributes and position. The other data types describe a point in space using only position. d: Graphic data describes points in 3D space with attributes. Vector data describes points in 2D space using attributes or position.<n><n>### Response::Incorrect<n>#### A:<n><n>### Response:{A: Graphic data describes  data by position, shape}<n><n>#### B:<n><n>### Rationale:B C D E A graphic is a symbolic representation of data that describes a position of data. Therefore this relationship is invalid.<n><n>### Choice C:<n><n>### C: B<n><n>### Graphic data and Vector data are representations how the data is represented.<n>####  A <n><n>### Answer:A<n><n>### Input:(x^ 2 - x - 4)(x^ 2 - 5x + 4)(x^2 + x -4)<n>### Demo:<n><n>#### x² - x - 4<n>```python<n>x^2 - x - 1 = (x - 1)(x + 1)<n>x^2 = x^2 = x^ +1 - 1 + 1x - 1 = x^3 -1<n><n>x² + x -4 = (x + 1)(x^2 -1) = (x + 4)(1-1/x) x^2 + x - 4 = (x-1)^2<n><n>x-1 = x*-1 = x -1<n>```
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where would a restaurant put a candle? Choices:  A: dimly lit room B: kitchen C: wall D: table E: birthday cake<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### A<n>Rationales: Candles are used to light dimly lit rooms. They do so by burning. Since a birthday cake also burns, a birthday cake is not a good choice. If you blow out the flame on a birthday cake, would it no longer light a room?<n><n>#### B<n>Rationales: Since the only place that candles cannot be placed is a kitchen, kitchen does not suffice in this case. <n>#### C<n>Rationales: The room is the room. A room is what a candelabra lights, so a candelabra cannot be placed on a table unless that table is the room.<n><n>#### D<n>Rationales: <n><n>#### E<n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:A person with children might have a lot of plastic things in what place? Choices:  A: cupboard B: cabinet C: own home D: everything E: garbage dump<n><n>### Response:		A person with children does not live in a garbage dump. A person with children has children. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What does someone living life fully feel? Choices:  A: joy B: valuable C: happiness D: early death E: adventurous<n><n>### Response:		<n>**E**<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Joy: <<JOY>> is a feeling of great happiness.<n>Happiness: <<HAPPINESS>> is a feeling of happiness.<n>Early death: <<Early death>> means death occurs sooner than expected.<n>Adventurous: <<ADVENTUROUS>> means that you like trying new things.<n>Life fully: <<LIFE FULLY>> means that you can achieve everything you want.<n>#### E<n>Answer: E<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>```<n>Brian can take 5 or 1 fewer math test before school the same week. John could take 2 or 5 or 13 fewer math tests. What is the least number of math tests taken if fewer is 30 and at least is 1?<n>Rationales<n>lessest = Math.min(6,5)+1<n>lessest=6+1<n>6<n>Answer: 6<n>```<n><n>### Inputs:<n><n>### Demos:<n><n>### Ratios:<n>Answer: 661<n>#### 661<n>Answer: 600<n><n>### Input/Output:<n><n>```<n>What is the largest quantity a user could order from a bakery, if at least is 3 dozen?<n>Rationales :<n>largest <n>= (20*3)<n>= 60<n>The answer can be anything larger than 60 if it satisfies the 'at least' condition. Answer can be 100 or 61 or even 99 or 62 or 73 or 63.  A bakery can't accept anything greater than 60 though.<n><n><n>User answer:<n>263<n><n><n>Bakery answer :<n>60<n>```<n><n>## Question Splitting (Asking Multiple Questions from Same Input):<n><n>## Demostration:<n><n>#### Input: What two numbers multiply to 129? Choice: 3*49 5*27 8*16. Rationales: 3*48= 128 and 5*26= 120 and 8*12= 128<n>Both 2*49
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What would happen to you if you are not good at playing violin? Choices:  A: happiness B: relaxation C: create music D: sadness E: loud noises<n><n>### Response:		A (happiness)<n><n>```<n>```<n>-[Input] What would happen to you if your parents are both dead or die within few years of their getting married? Choices: A: you won't have the same love or support as before. B: they will not be able to support you financially or emotionally anymore. C: your parents will be able to give you more support. D: you will love your parents more after they pass away. Answer: B<n><n>### Answer:<n>A (happiness) The teacher is asking: "If your parents were both dead or die within a few years of their getting together, what would happen to you?"<n>Since if your parents are dead, you will not have the same love or emotional support as before. You will be alone and will have trouble receiving love and support from other family members.<n><n>### Answer 2:<n>B (they will not be able to give you support) Teacher: "What would happen to you (if) your parents are both dead". Student: "They would not be able to give me any support."<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n><img src="instructions.png" width="500px"><n><n>### Explanations:<n><n><n><img src ="instructions_response.png" width="1000px"><n># How do you get from the top of the mountain to the lake?<n># Choose your answer then click start to begin.<n><n>### How do I get to the lake from here?(A:walking around it)(B: climbing to the top)<n><n>|Choice A|Choice B|<n>|------|------|<n>|This is the wrong route.(the answer is B)|<img src="walk_around.gif" width="160"></img> |<n><n>### Excited, Sad|How much time can we spend exploring? Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where might a human sit for extended periods over a bowl of water? The only choice that includes a math problem is Choice 3: 1 percent.<n><n>3. The best answer is one that shows the correct solution to the problem.<n><n>4. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What animal produces milk? Choices:  A: supermarket B: pig C: cow D: refrigerator E: store<n><n>### Response:		Answer choice D: refrigeratory is correct.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Rationales: Milk is stored in a refrigerator.<n><n>### Input:-4 + 3 + 2 + 1 = 10<n><n>### Response:-10<n><n>## Answer:12<n><n>### Instructions:Fill in the blank to answer the question.<n><n>Dad asked _______ to take him to the store.<n><n>#### A.Dad asked Janet to take him to the sto<n><n>#### B.Dad asked Jan to take him to the st<n><n>#### C.Dad asked Janat to take him to the<n><n>#### D.Dad asked Janne to take him to the s<n><n>#### E.Dad asked Janiq to take him to the <n><n>#### F.Dad asked Janit to take him to the S<n><n>#### G.Dad asked Janie to take him to the Sh<n><n>#### H.Dad asked Janis to take him to the St<n><n>### Answer:D<n><n>### Exercise:Fill in the blank with the matching word.<n><n>The ______ is the part of the body that you use to write and paint.<n><n>#### A: leg<n><n>#### B.head<n><n>#### C.throat<n><n>#### D.spo<n><n>#### E.feet<n><n>#### F.chest<n><n>#### G.think<n><n>### Answer:"feet"<n><n>### Exerciese:Look at the underlined in each sentence and fill in the blank with its correct form.<n><n>Jimmy's _______ in getting up early in the morning made him miss the school bus.<n><n>#### A__: sleeping<n><n>#### B__: sleep<n><n>#### C__: sleepy<n><n>#### D__: slept<n><n>#### E__: slept<n>

It has a certain wavelenght because it follows a particular wave size, wave size, and wave shape. Also, light does not only come as a wave, since particles of light also have wave properties. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Dan outfitted his house to run on the oldest heat source on Earth. What is the oldest heat source on Earth? Choices:  A: fire B: solar energy C: sun D: house E: coal or wood<n><n>### Response:		<n>The oldest heat source on Earth is coal or wood.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>Coal and wood produce heat when we burn them. Fire is a natural heat source. We did not invent it nor did we discover it.<n>However, solar energy and the sun do the same in providing heat. They are not natural heat sources but man-made.<n><n>### Test Out:Answer the following questions. Choose the letter of the best response.<n><n>### 1. Which type of heat source does not require fuel? Choices:  a. natural heat source b. wood burner c. coal furnace d. sun<n><n>Answer: B<n><n>### Rationales: <n>A natural heat source does not require heat.<n>B does require heat because it needs to burn fuel to produce heat.<n>C also requires heat because you must burn coal to produce heat.<n>D may need fuel like solar power does but not to produce heat.<n><n>### The second choice does not require fuel either so is the correct answer.<n><n>### Which of the following sources of light do not shine at night? Choices: <n>A: A sun B: A solar flare C: A house D: A candle E: A flashlight<n><n>### Answer:<n>The only light source to shine at night is the sun. The others do not shine at all.<n><n>### Choice A: The sun is the only source that shines in the day and night. However, in this problem, the sun is a source of heat, not light.<n><n>### A natural heat source that produces heat without using fuel is:<n><n>### A: solar power<n><n>### A heat source that has been produced and manufactured by humans is:<n><n>## A: solar power<n>## C: sun<n><n>## C is false because the sun produces heat on its own.<n><n>### C: the sun<n><n>## C: the sun<n>## A: solar panels<n>## B: a fire<n>## D: coal or wood<n>## E: solar power<n>A cannot be a source because it is not a fuel. Solar panels are not fuel either.<n>#### D and E should each be the correct choice.<n><n>## C is the best response.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Though he was an adult he still stereotypical slept on a sofa bed in his parent's what Choices:  A: garage B: horseradish C: living room D: guest room E: basement<n><n>### Response:		The answer is E.<n><n>### Why?:<n>A: False. The sofa bed is not in the garage.<n><n>B: False. Horseradish is food.<n><n>C: False. A bedroom is not the living room.<n><n>D: False. A guest room is intended for guests only, and we do not know if the adult sells his house to his parents when he grows up.<n><n>E: True. A basement is often an attic, and an attic is often a room (we will refer to a garage later in the questionnaire).

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Sally took her medicine and experienced strong side effects.  What did doctors say about the side effects? Choices:  A: great B: distinguished C: remarkable D: excellent E: peculiar<n><n>### Response:		 E: peculiar<n><n>#### Answer:  <b>E: peculiar</b><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:James was delayed for a couple of hours because he had a connection.  Where might his connection be? Choices:  A: company B: airport C: wall D: computer network E: love<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### A: Company<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>There are many airports, but airport is the only place in the list that a connection would have to be.<n>The other choices could be interpreted as having to do with transportation itself.<n><n>Since a "connected" phone call is a computer operation and the connections were the computer operations which delayed James,<n>A is the correct answer choice.<n><n>### Input : An engineer must keep his equipment in good working order.  How might an equipment check-up be useful? Choices:  Clean and check it for defects A: Make it last longer B: Make sure it works properly C: Identify potential problems D: None of these are applicable<n><n>#### C: Make sure it works correctly<n><n>### Demotration:<n>A is the only option that refers consistently to equipment.  All others refer to the worker performing the task, a person, and therefore not the equipment.<n><n>### Response to input<n>#### E: None of These Are Applicable<n><n>#### C: Identify potential Problems<n><n>#### E: None Of These Are Applicable
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What is the opposite of foolhardy? Choices:  A: thoughtful B: discreet C: calculated D: cautious E: careful<n><n>### Response:		<n>Foolhardy has to do with being foolish or reckless and having an element of bravery. The opposite is usually careful or thoughtful.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Foolhardiness = <<Foo->d+he+y+R+i+n+k+s+s+i+p+i+L+y>> fool+cautious<n><n>Foolish or <<R+i+n->k+e+L+i+c+k+s+i+L+i+y>> reckless means the opposite is cautious. In addition, foolhardy has an element of boldness or bravery, so the opposite may also include thoughtfulness.<n><n>####  thoughtful<n>Answer: thoughtful<n>Answer: A and B<n>Answer: A and C<n>Answer: D and E<n><n>### Input<n>What is the opposite of discreet? Choices:  <<Dis->c+re+e+t+d+A+A+D>>discret+op<n><n>#### 226<n><n>Rationales, the opposite is thoughtful.<n><n>#### 219<n><n>Answer: thoughtful

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:If a student was about to graduate, they would no longer be attending what? Choices:  A: library B: parties C: kindergarten class D: bar E: school<n><n>### Response:		Answer A.<n><n>#### Why: <n>"would no longer be attending" = <n>"would attend" + "no longer" = <<"would attend"+"no longer"="would no longer ">>would no longer<n>mean "about to graduate", not "parties"/"kindergarten class"/"bar/school".<n><n>#### <n>A.<n><n>### Input If a child is not feeling well, does their teacher's assistant call their parents? Choices: A: yes, but only if they're sick B: sometimes C: rarely, if ever. D: yes, every time they don't feel well<n><n>### Response Answer C. Every time they don't well feel.<n><n>#### Why<n>"if they're sick" means they will be only once when they're sick<n>If they're feeling well, then they will rarely do it.<n>Rarely is about sometimes.<n>Every time they don't have sick, they will also be called by their teacher's assistant.<n>Therefore, the parents will be always called by the teacher's assistant. They will be called every time the child in not feeling well.<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>### Input Does it hurt when a baby is born? Choices: A no B: No, but it can be painful for the mother C: maybe, but not usually D: Yes all the time<n><n>### Response Yes, all the time.<n><n>### Response to Rationale:<n><n>---<n>#### <n>D.<n><n>### Multiple Choice<n>Input: The word "lust" as a meaning of wanting something. Choices: A: love B: hate C: craving D: obsession E: longing<n><n>#### Why Choice: D<n>"love" and "hate" have two meanings not similar between the choices.<n>"longing" doesn't sound like "craving" or "lust" doesn't sound likes "obsession".<n>The other definition "longing" is what we mean.<n>Therefore, we should choose D.<n><n>### Ending Answer: ( )<n><n># - What are some activities that require both physical skill and strategy? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Why would someone confess to committing murder? Choices:  A: guilty conscience B: fear C: go free D: problems E: find god<n><n>### Response:		<n>Confesses guilty conscience:  It’s an internal feeling of guilt that causes someone to confess in order to feel better, even though their crime may not be punishable.<n>Demonstration Example: The person confesses guilty conscience because their conscience is bothering them. Their conscience has nagged them and they need relief.<n><n>Confesses fear:  Refers to the crime itself or it’s consequences, like: the consequences of staying in jail, the criminal system’s punishments, or losing freedom because of a consequence.<n>Demonstrating Example: The person confessing their fear because they want to avoid the jail.<n><n>Confesses go free:  This choice indicates that a confessor wants to get out of trouble and believes that confessing is a way to get this relief.<n>Demonstrative Example: the one who confesses because they do not want to jail.<n><n>#### Confesses problems:<n>It represents other factors in their lives, including: personal or family stress, or other personal or family issues.<n>Demonstrator Example: Someone confesses their problems due to some problem at home which they feel they shouldn’t go to jail for.<n><n>Confesses find god:<n>It means that that confessors had felt a desire to come back to their faith.<n>Demonstrated Example: They wanted to come back to God, and that confessed because God told them that they would only be forgiven if they confessed.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The crowd wasn't that big.  It can better be described as what? Choices:  A: field B: alone C: small group D: solitude E: solitary<n><n>### Response:		small group<n><n>### Input:(The crowd)  wasn't ______ big.  It can best be described as _______. Choices:  A) a; a group B) a; alone C) a; small group D) a; solitude E) a; solitary<n><n>## Solution Description:<n><n>1. Input<n>    - Input: The crowd wasn't that  big. It can better be described  as what? Choices :  A: field B. Alone C: Small group D: Solitude E: Solitary<n>2. Demonstration<n>    - Demonstration: The crowd wasn' t that  big. It means it was small or not at all. We use can when the verb is in the past tense. (was )  When we are describing something as in this question it does not matter that the verb is in the  past (is) or present (are) tense.<n>        <n>          <n>          <n>3. Solution<n>    - Solution: It is best described as group because that is what the question asks us to answer.<n>    - Solution: I would use the verb to ask better to describe. I <n><n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:People were talking on the corner, who were they talking with? Choices:  A: god B: mix C: with people D: have friends E: see people<n><n>### Response:		<n>There are two reasons why these people are talking.<n><n>* One reason is god.<n><n>* Another reason is a friend.<n><n>So, the right answer is Choices:  A &amp; E.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>The people could be talking about religion to god.<n><n>Therefore, the right answer is choice B.<n><n>However, the people could be talking about the lives of people in their local region.<n>Since those people can be talking with people.<n><n>Therefore the right answer is choice C.<n><n>Answer: A &amp; E<n><n>### Input:-3 divided by -1<n><n>Rationales:-3 divided by -(-1) = 3<n>

Complete the request as appropriate. Write a response that uses at least 2 complete sentences.<n><n>### Exercise:Give an example of words that do not need to agree in order to be correct.<n><n>### Answer:The words like “some” and “most” are not always followed by plural nouns.<n><n>### Example:"Is this most of something?" "No. It's some of it."<n><n>### Answer:"Is this some of something?" "Yes."<n><n>### Demofration:<n><p style="text-align: center">Some of something <img src="https://www.learnandteachwithkyle.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/exercise.jpg" alt="some of something" width="200" height="200"></p><n><n>### Input:'Do we have to do all of this ourselves?' Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where could you put some olives to prevent them from getting nearby food wet? Choices:  A: eaten B: glassess C: jar D: pizza E: refrigerator<n><n>### Response:		<n>Response: D<n>Rationales: A: Eaten. Choice A does not prevent the olives from getting nearby food wet.<n>B: Glasses. Choice B does not prevent the olves from getting nearby food wet or wet ones from getting in the food.<n>C: Jar. Choice C does not prevent the olve from getting nearby food wet/wet olves from getting in the food or wet food from getting in the olves.<n>E: Refrigerator. Choice E would do all three, hence, the correct answer is Choice D.<n>#### 1<n>Answer: D<n>```<n>11:06<n>```<n><n>### Input:\#301<n><n>Rationales: Choice A is not a function because the two expressions have different outputs. As you can see, two people wearing 301 shirts would result a different output as you do not multiply or add the two expressions.<n><n>Choice B is the correct option.<n>#### 0<n>Answer:<n>```<n>0<n>```<n>Answer:<n>```10:01```<n>Answer:<n><n>### Input:(C) x (B) = x (A)?<n><n>Rationales:(A) = x [1, 3]. Hence, the output is [1, 3, 3].<n><n>(B) = x [1/5, 4/5]. Hence, the output should be [1/5, null, 4/5, null]. (C) = x [11, 14, 17, 20]. Hence, the output will be [11,14,17,20].<n><n>Therefore, (C) x (B), which is (C) x [1/5 4/5] = [5, 2, 8, 10] x [11,11,11].<n><n>Choice A is "D" since both input sets are identical.<n><n>Choices B and C cannot be the correct ones since the operations are not done in a manner that they would add values to each other.<n><n>#### 2<n>Answer: <n>11:07<n><n><n>### Input:%1<n>-9 %1 =<n>A: 73<n>B: -15<n>C: 534<n>D

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:James wanted to stop competing.  What might he have been feeling? Choices:  A: pressure B: death C: trying harder D: quitting E: winning or losing<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer:James wanted to stop trying harder.<n>He might have been feeling pressure and trying hard to try hard.<n>Therefore he wanted to stop competing, because he wanted to stop trying harder and feeling pressure.<n>[ 6 ] [ 2 ]<n><n>[A.A.T.,L.V.T., D.C.] <n><n>### Demographics:<n><n>### 1.Gender:  <select> <option onclick="count='+1'">Male</option><option onclick="count='-1'">Female</option></select><n><n>### 2.Age:  <select>  <option onclick="count2='+1'">3-5 yrs</option><option onclick ="count2='-1'">6-9 yrs</option></select> <span id="count">0</span><n><n>### Instance:<n>- [ ] [ ] [X]<n><n>### Response(Answer):<n>- [ ] [X] [ ]  <n>### Your response<n>- <input onclick="count2=0" type="text" name="yourresponse" id="yourresponse" class="answer">

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:A man was driving himself to the airport, where did he put his luggage? Choices:  A: closet B: at hotel C: sidewalk D: bus stop E: trunk<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input:{a,b}={1,2}. Choices: A: {a(1) = a} B : {a(2) = a + b} C: {b(2) = b} D: {a(1,2) = 3} E: {a = a + b}<n><n>### Response:{a,b}<n>Answer: E<n><n>### Input : A = 13, B = 5, C = 16. A + B/ C =? Choices A: 15 B : 19 C : 18 D: 17 E: 21<n><n>### Response :<n>Answer: D<n><n>### Input 2:<n>[a+c] = 13<n>b*c = 16<n><n>### Response 2:<n>b*c = ((13/b * c)/a) = c(13/b*a) = b*c-(b *c)/(b*a) = 1*13-16/13 = 13 - 1<n><n>### C<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Why might someone want to be buying beer? Heidi is twice as old as Jake.<n>3. Jake is 4 cm taller than Heidi.<n>4. How old are Brandon and Heidi?<n><n>Answer(s):<n>47 cm(Brandon), 23 cm(Heidi),<n>4cm(Heidi) = 4cm(Jake) = 4<br><n>Brandon is 1 cm (1 cm) shorter than 16<br><n>Hence, 16 = 17 = 16 + (2 * (23-1)) = 1 + (2(23-1))<br><n>So (23-1 = 22)(17/2) = (23 -1)/2 = 13 (Heidi)<br><n>Hey Jake, you're only 1 cm away from 48 cm. <n>### Input:<n>What is the median, mode, and mean of the following data?<n><n>7, 4, 4, 10, 10<n><n>### Answer:<n>We first set the median = mode = mean to 7<br><n>Then we take the range and divide by 2 = 6<br><n>Next we square all the data and sum.<n>6 <br /><n>25 <br /><n>A.  4.5<n>B.  1.25<n>C. 10.5<n>D. 11.25<n>Answer:  A<n><n>### Input1:<n>Input a positive integer.<n><n>### Answer1:<n>Input 3<br><n>4, 5, 6<br>The result should be  4 + 5 + 6 = 15 = 3 <br><n>Thus, it outputs “3. 3”<n><n>### Input2:<n>Input a positive two-digit integer.<n><n>## Output2:<n>Input 5<

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:If a human wants to enjoy another human's company, where might they go? Choices:  A: place of work B: office C: friend's house D: workplace E: deep thought<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: Place of Work<n>B: Office<n>C: Friend's Place<n>D: workplace<n>E: deep thinking<n>#### A: place of Work<n><n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input-: I've been so stressed and anxious lately so I couldn't read.<n>Rationales-: As a human wants to enjoy human company, so maybe you want to rest a place where you can take deep breath and calm down.<n>You can go to the library of your school or college.<n>Answer-: Place of Work<n><n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The only baggage the woman checked was a drawstring bag, where was she heading with it? Choices:  A: garbage can B: military C: jewelry store D: safe E: airport<n><n>### Response:		<n>B- Militar<n><n>### Correct answer:<n>B- Military<n><n>### Solution:<n>The only baggage was a drawstring bag.<n>If a bag was checked it would have been luggage, not a drawstring bag. Therefore, she must have headed to the military.<n><n>#### Solution:<n>The only  baggage  the  woman  checked  was a  drawstring  bag,  where  was  she  heading  with  it? Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Of all the rooms in a house it was his favorite, the aromas always drew him to the what? Choices:  A: yard B: basement C: kitchen D: living room E: garden<n><n>### Response:		<n>Of all the rooms in the house, it was his favorite because the aromas always led him to the gardens.<n><n>### Answer: E: Garden<n><n>#### E: Garden<n>

How many more objects does B have?<n><n>### Rationales:The number of objects B has is <<570-25>>570-26=545545 because A has 570 and only B has 25.<n><n>### Answer : B's number of objects left is 10 more than A's<n><n>### Input<n>My grandpa works at the supermarket, his coworkers are named 1. 2. Forms are those strict rules or structures that are used to create a poem. Genres, on the other hand, are how poems are identified by the general content.<n><n>### So, in answer 1 choose C since it fits in with both of the groups above and that is why it is a type of poetry.<n><n>### Types:<n><n>### * Ballad<n>> This form of poetry is made up of a series of stanzas with a constant meter of some sort. They tell stories usually in a singable style and are intended to be told aloud.<n>### * Haiku<n>> The haiku is a very simple form of poetry whose verses can be divided into three sections or lines of three, five

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The evacuation became mandatory, so what came on the TV? Choices:  A: advisory B: mandate C: soap opera D: elective E: optional<n><n>### Response:		<n>-  A: advisory<n><n>### Demystifier:Sometimes we have to remember the difference between “advisory” and “mandatory.” An advisory is something that suggests but does not require. A mandate is a rule that requires you to complete a task in order to comply with the law.<n><n>An order to evacuate a neighborhood is a mandate. An advisory on the possibility of an incoming hurricane is, of course, an advisory and not a mandate.<n><n>Similarly, to order someone to comply with the request to evacuate their neighborhood in an emergency is a mandate. When the TV presents the news about the order, its function is to inform the audience; when the TV presents the news that there is a mandatory evacuation, its function is to order or advise.<n><n>### Answer Key:<n>A: advisory<n><n>#### The question is in the context of an emergency, so it uses the word "mandatory" when it refers to an order to evacuate the neighborhood. But we would be much more likely to hear the words "mandatory" or "order" when a TV station is asked to inform its audience about a news event and not necessarily to urge its audience to comply with a requirement. So if something is mandatory to a local government it does not necessarily become mandatory to us when we hear an advisory or a report about it.  <n><n>B: mandate<n><n>C: soap opera<n><n>D: elective<n><n>E: optional<n><n>#### B: mandate<n><n>### Inputs:<n>The bank must close at 3:00 pm. Two hours after that, Janey decided to go shopping. After her decision, two bank employees, Marla and John, arrived. How much time is Janey late? Answer the multiple choice question by clicking the answer that shows the correct option.<n>Answer: 1<n><n>### Demand:<n><n>### Demands:<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Let's analyze the following example.<n><n>Janet and Brenda left their homes at 3:07 am. Janey is walking down the sidewalk at 3:10 am. When she realized that she didn't have enough time to get across the street before the bank had to close she decided, at 3:

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Learning languages is difficult. Choices:  A: owner B: foot C: subordinate D: base E: point<n><n>### Response:		<n>### Input: 1) If it takes longer than 30 seconds to make a file transfer, what's an alternative to transferring files over the internet?<n><n>### 1) A: Email messages<n>2) 2) FTP<n>3) 3) SSH<n>4) 4) Use a USB memory stick<n>5) 5) Try again from the beginning.<n><n>### Demo.<n>Input: Try 3<n><n>Output 1: It took 10 minutes and 2 seconds to transfer a file. That's an option.<n>Output 2: It failed to transfer the file.<n>Output 3: You gave up before the transfer was completed! Do you really want to leave? Yes No<n><n>### 6) You should try the command `rmdir` again. It will try again from the beginning. I'm afraid that you gave up before the file transfer completed.<n><n>### 7) It will take at least 30 seconds to finish if it took at least 30 sec.<n>8) 8) If you really want to leave, you press 'y' to confirm.<n><n>9) 9) You should try, but there is a problem.<n><n>**It takes longer than 33 minutes in one transfer and more than 30 seconds. It has no effect.**<n><n>In a comment, I would like to say, "It took longer than 30 minutes to finish the transfer" and "it couldn't be finished because it didn't finish the transfer faster than 30 second".<n><n>### <n><n>### This is a test case. 50 cases should be considered.<n><n>### Solution: A) B) C) D) None of the above.<n><n>### The following tasks are done in 8 steps. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What is required to be good at playing tennis? Choices:  A: tennis racket B: skill C: competition D: tennis court E: legs<n><n>### Response:		<n>Rationales:<n>#### B <n><n>Skill<n><n>#### C <n><n>Competition<n><n>#### D <n><n>Tennis court<n><n>#### E <n><n>Legs<n><n>#### A<n><n>Tennis racket<n><n>### Input <n>John has 150 more coins than Bill. Bill’s collection of coins is 3 times as many coins as John’s.  If John has 50 more coins today than he has yesterday, how many coins does John have in all?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input :<n>John has 1 coin more than Bill. Bill has 60 more coins than Jim. John has 50 coins in all.<n><n>### Input<n>Cars A and B have the same distance of halfway from origin. How many times of the cars must be travel when A starts with a distance of 150km more than the B to the end of the journey.<n><n>### Rationales<n>#### C <n>1/2 A+B = <<1/2(A+B)=1>> 1<n><n>#### A<n>1/4 A = <<1/4A=1>><n><n>\[ \frac{B}{2}\] + \[\frac{1}{2}A\] = <<\frac{B}{2}+\frac{1}{2A}=1>><n><n>### Input :<n>Janet has 9 cards less than Brenda. Marcia has twice as many cards is Janet. How many more cards do Jim have in all if Marcia has<n>cards of Janet?<n><n>### Rationale<n>#### 3 <n>Ratio of Jame: 1:2<n><n>#### 2 <n>Ratio of Janet (since 1:3 = >>1/3=<1-3=1>> <1-3=1/3>, ratio of Janet = (1/3))<n><n>### Test Scenario<n>A: You can do this.B: This is impossible to do<n><n>### Test Results<n>A:  You cannot complete it by yourself because you need others.<n><n>### Test Summary<n><n>* You need others to complete it.<n><n>### Additional information<n><n>D: I don't know.<n><n>### Output <n>D:\Program Files

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The man uses grooming before a job interview, what is he trying to portray? Choices:  A: looking good B: beauty C: tardiness D: handsomeness E: neatness<n><n>### Response:		D. handsomeness<n><n>### Answer:D<n><n>### Reference:<n><n>[Grooming](http://www.urbandictionary.com/define.php?term=Grooming)<n><n>"Grooming is the practice of self-improvement in preparation for an activity or event."<n><n>### Output<n><n>### Output Description<n><n>Output should be submitted in the comments section below.<n><n>### Notes<n><br><n><n>### Discussions<n><br><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:To learn must have the right book, to work efficiently what must one have? Choices:  A: improve yourself B: become knowledgeable C: have tools D: persistence E: have more knowledge<n><n>### Response:		A: improve yourself<n><n>#### A: improve<n>Answer: improve myself<n><n>#### 0<n>Answer: 0<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Explanation: Persist is the quality that helps people to have patience. Therefore people who persists are those people who have more knowledge.<n>There are 4 choices that are not correct and persists is not the right answer.<n>Choice: A, Persistent people have more knowledge and that is not how to answer the question.<n>Choice: B, Persistence means to have more knowledge. To have more knowledge is what we should be doing to work efficiently.<n>Choice: C, Improving and having tools are what is needed to work efficiently. Tools are the equipment and materials that help you learn something, thus tools are what you need, not knowledge, that’s why B is incorrect.<n>Choice: D, Persist means to have more knowledge but to learn you need more than that, so we leave D incorrect.<n>Choice: E, One must learn in order to work efficiently, therefore E is incorrect.<n><n>### Exercise:What will be the total of the three numbers when it is added. Choice: Choices: A: None of these choices are correct B: 12 C: 3 D: 5 E: 45<n><n>### Answer:<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Rationales: Adding 2 and 9 and 6 gives us 12.<n><n>### Response Choice A:None of these choices are correct<n>Rationales: Choice A:None are not correct as adding these two numbers does not give you 12.<n>Adding 9+5 doesn’t give you 12 and 3+5 doesn’t either.<n><n>### Answer Choice B: 12<n>Rationales:Answer Choice B:12 is correct. <n>1+2=3\<n>\*A B\*B C\*C D\*D E\*E<n>Answer:A\*A+B\*A+B+C\*B+C+D\*B+C\*(A+B+C)+E\*B+C=A+B+C+D+E<n><n>### Exercisec::What is the product of 84 and

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:If you want to make a big splash in a river with a rock, from where should you throw it? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where do you buy tickets at a ticket booth for games/ Choices:  A: train station B: cathedral C: metro station D: fairgrounds E: amusement park<n><n>### Response:		In this question there are 5 choices to select an option from, out of those 5, B.<n><n>### Input:"How many cards do you have in your deck? You have 93 less than Tom." Which of the following sentences is in logical order?" -A: How many cards do you have?" -B: I have a deck of 93 cards." -C: I have 93 more than Tom." -D: You have 93 fewer than Tom." Choices:  A,C B,A D,B E,D<n><n>### Response for Choices B and C<n>This answer, D, is correct. Tom has a deck of 92, while you have one with 93.<n>You have 92 - 93 = <<92-93=1>>1 cards, which is why A, D is the correct answer.<n>If Tom has a deck of deck of 92 + 1, that means you also have deck 92 + 2 = <<92+2=94>>94 cards.<n>If both have a deck of the same number, they will have the same amount, which is why C, C is the correct answer. And B, A is incorrect because you have a deck that has 2 more.<n><n>### Demo:<n>If Tom has 12 cards in his deck, that means you have a deck with <<12+5>>12+5 cards, since you have 5 more.<n><n><n>### Input "How late is the movie?"<n><n>### Response "The movie is starting at 5:30 pm."<n>This answer, D is correct. The movie will start at 5:33.<n><n>### 5:30<n>Answer: 5:30

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The game was on sale.  I got it then because it was usually what? Choices:  A: buying B: purchase C: overpriced D: way to much E: expensive<n><n>### Response:		I got it then because it  usually purchased A to B to D.<n><n># Example of Explanation of How to Use Conditional Statements<n># 21st-century learning in math is the ability to write a compound conditional statement that uses the code statement:<n><n>If <condition> then <action> elseif <condition> then <second action> else <action> fi<n><n>In this example, we see the condition tested and the results.<n><n>This code statement is what the computer follows and is how the math algorithm is written.<n><n>The example of "21st-century math" includes a "then" statement. It may also have several "then" statements in case "if" and the "then" statements do not result in an "else," because the logical code tests the "then," and if the "then" test fails, the "else" is tested to see if it passes. If it fails, the algorithm tests the next condition and sees if it passes, too. It repeats until it gets to the else of the first condition, sees it passes or fails, and continues.<n><n>"21st-century in Math" means that a student has to be able to understand the flow of how the computer solves the problem by writing if-then statements for a computer to follow.<n><n>---<n><n>### 21st century learning in math is the students ability to understand the  flow of how the computer programs solve issues by writing if-then statement for a computer to follow<n><n>---<n><n>This means that they would be able to read an issue being solved or a program and understand how it tests a condition, the solution in a if and then statement, and the solution in an else if and then statement and the final solution in a fi statement.<n><n>---<n>---<n>### <iframe height="550" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/0wb8KGxMl64" title="If you are seeing this message, it means that the JavaScript is not working in your browser. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What is the hope of playing sports without competition? Choices:  A: running B: have fun C: balls touch D: winning E: get tired<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct choice is **B** "have fun".

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What does a chef do when working in the evening? Choices:  A: cook dinner B: study french cooking C: taste sauce D: prepare food E: thin sauce<n><n>### Response:		<n>[A](https://i.stack.imgur.com/B8VdI.png)<n><n>### Response Rationale: Choice A: Answer: When a chef works in the evening, he or she cooks dinner. <n>#### 212<n>Answer: A<n><n>-----<n><n>\(<2k+k-1>\)<n><n>### Input<n>What is the remainder when \(<a_10+a_2+a_4>\)?<n><n>### Response<n>Answer: a4<n><n>#### 213<n>Answer: a4><n><n><n>-----<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Find the quotient of 4478 in Simplest Form<n>### Demonstraion:<n>Input: 440/21<n>Answer: 30<n><n>### Instuctions:<n>Find the greatest of 1/2, 1/3, 1/4<n><n>### Demostration:<n>1\(n\) 1/3 1/4 = 1/[3+4]=1/7<n><n>### Instructons:Find the greatest of 2/21 and 5/14<n><n>### Response1:<n>Response1: Answer: 5/14<27/21 or 3/7>(5/14<3/7>)(27/21<5/14>).<n><n>#### 27/(21/07)<n>Answer: 27/(2*2=4)=14<n><n>#### 5/(14/07)= 5/(0.8111*7)/0.7)= 5/0.059404 (rounded)<n><n>### Demstration1:<n><n>[**2121**](2121-answer-to-the-practice-question-14)<n><n><n>-----<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:After his mother saw his report card he knew he was going to be doing housework, what could have prevented this? Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What do people in the same family often share? Choices:  A: brown hair B: names C: two eyes D: will E: brains<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Rationale:<n>Family members share a lot of things. What kind of things should be shared?<n>Answer:<n><n>### Input :Which property is used when dividing fractions? Choices: A: Order B: Cancellation C: Commutative D: Odd<n><n>### Response :<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Cancellation and Order both apply when dividing fractions. Cancel means to eliminate something. You may get rid of some of the values when dividing fractions - especially if you're dividing by the same number. Commutative means that you can change a formula's order and get the same answer. In other words, 3 x 3 = 3 x 3.<n>Dividing by odd and even numbers are two different things. When you divide by an even number, you do it twice.<n>Cancellation<n>What is the last and final operation in an addition problem? Choices: A) Subtraction B) Division C) Multiplication D) Addition<n><n>---<n><n>### Rules:<n>To use the **`let`** directive, you must have an initializer and a name for each variable.<n><n>To use the `if` statement, you must include three expressions:<n><n>The test, an if statement, and an else statement.<n><n>To use **`for`**, you must have an initialization that assigns the index of the loop. This is followed by an expression that creates an empty list or empty dictionary where each value and key is assigned in turn.<n><n>Next comes a loop variable for each item in the list. Lastly, an expression. After an empty list or dictionary is returned, all the variables are undefined.<n><n>The **`for`** expression looks like this:<n><n>```js<n>for(expression, initializer, variable for each item in list, another expression) {<n> ...<n>}<n>```<n><n>The **`return`** directive returns the value of the expression.<n>In any arithmetic expression, numbers and booleans can be multiplied, divided, subtracted and added together.<n>```js<n>(operand a) = operand b<n>```<n><n>In this expression of<n><n>```js<n>operator a operator b<n>```<n><n>`a` and `b` are any operand and operator can represent any values, such as a number, a

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What would children do if they are bored? Choices:  A: walk B: change shoes C: play tag D: smell smoke E: reach over<n><n>### Response:		I would chose B. Change shoes<n><n><n><n>### Input 2: 49 x 10 = 8 times 8 = 80<n><n>### Response 2: 8-0<n><n><n><n>## 🔹 Answer the following multiple choice question by choosing the best multiple choice answer.<n><n>### Input :In a race between two cars if one car is two minutes faster than the other, how long does it take them to complete their first two laps? The racetrack is one mile in circuit. Choices :  A: One minute.<n>B: Three minutes. C: Two minutes.<n>D: More than one minute. E: Less than three minutes.<n><n><n>### Response :C = Two Minutes and A = 1<n><n><n><n>## **🔹Instruction : What is 3/4 in decimal?**<n><n>## Response : 075(0.75)<n><n><n>## **❒** ***Instruction ❒**<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: In a room of about 60, there are 21 children (71.43%); two teachers (32.1%); and two parents (32.1%).<n><n>Rationales: Seventy-one point four three percent or seventy-one point four _two_ percent<n><n># Maths Form 2 2017<n><n>Question 1.<n><n>Find the value that can replace the question mark.<n><n><n>`57% of x is 7.`<n><n><n>```<n>27% - 41% =?<n>49% + 41% = 22.<n>```<n><n>The answer is:<n><n><n>27% - or  27% of x= -41%<n><n><n><n>## Maths Form 2 Marking Scheme<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Demonstration:Write a response appropriately that completes the question asked.<n><n><n><n>The formula for converting a _per cent_ to a decimal is divided by _100_ as below:<n><n>* 48% = 48/100 =.48<n><n>1.) Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where is a good place to get a ball? How many seconds does light travel 20 miles at this speed? Choices: 1: 174 seconds2: about 180 seconds3: about 250 seconds<n><n>### Response (2 points)<n>I got the speed as: 187533.18753 km/sec. 20 miles/1 km=2000 km/2000 km=0.001km/0.001(round)= (1/1000)km/0.091875km/0.01875km (rounded)= (0.018)km/ (0.019)km=0.944444 times the speed of light.<n><n>Speed of Light = (0.9) <n>Speed of Light(s) = 591.8651356 (rounded to 2 dp)<n><n>Now to find the seconds.<n>Speed of light(s) = 20/(591.8)<n>Number of seconds = 17 (rounded)<n><n>### Instructors comments:B<n>Answer: 174

What should you do?<n><n>### Answer Choices:<n>A: Move your car over so it is next to the one in front of you.<n>B: Do not move your car. It could endanger the car in front of it.<n>C: Move your car over and make sure to endanger the car infront of you.<n>D: Move your car over (to the left) so you can stop.<n>E: Move your car over on the right side so that car in front of you can stop.<n><n>### Option:<n>A<n>Move it so it can stop and not endanger another car.<n><n>### Inference:<n>The car in front will be able to stop if I move my car next to it.<n><n>### Multiple Choice:<n>The statement has a 17-letter word. Choices:  A: swim B: jog C: excercise D: work out E: rock climb<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: C<n><n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Instructions:You are a contestant on a game show, "Jeopardy". The show runs for 150 shows. You must earn a total of $30,000 or more dollars to win. The average winnings for each show are as follows: 60% chance of winning $175, 35% chance of winning $425, 5% chance of winning nothing, and 0% chance of winning more than $750. The probability that you will win $175 or more in any given show is $0.6$0.6. How much should you bet per show?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>The chance of winning $1,750,000 + $30,025 is given by $0.6$9.6.<n><n>$9.6\gt $0 and so, the game should still be played.<n><n>The chance of winning 175,000 + 30,0050,050<n>$\neq $ 0 and so, the probability of winning over 175, 000 is zero, so bet as much as possible to win $175,050$.<n><n>In particular, this means that you should bet $30,015$. <n><n>#### 338.65<n>Answer: 338.20<n><n>### Instuction:The average score on a math test at your school is 52. The standard deviation is 5. A student scores are given below: 70, 74, 55, 58, 25, 73, 39, 54, 69, 70. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What are ai machines known for doing? Choices:  A: fly B: milk cows C: eat D: answering questions E: fail to work<n><n>### Response:		A: fly<n><n>### Dem: input: 2/2 1=1 A:2 2 B:1<n><n>#### 2<n>Answer: 2<n>
