Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:He wore the wrong shoes while walking all day, now he has what on his heels and toes? Choices:  A: exercise B: moving forward C: feet D: blisters E: locomotion<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### A: Exercise:<n><n>### Rationale:<n>The question states he is walking on his heels and on his toes. The choices are:<n><n>A: Wealth: Money accumulation<n>B: Moving forward: movement from point A to point B without stopping or turning away<n>C: Feet: What is used to walk with<n>D: Blisters: An injury caused by walking<n>E: Locomotion: Walking<n><n>Exercising, moving forward, and walking uses feet. If the word for the shoe was the same as one of the options, it would have been a better question, as would picking another option.<n><n>#### B: Moving forward:<n><n>#### He wore the wrong shoes.<n>He wore the wrong shoeclose<n><n>### C: Feet<n><n>#### Exercise:<n>The correct answer was exercise<n><n>#### B: Wrong shoes<n>Wrong shoesclose<n><n>#### A: He wore the wrong shoecloses<n><n>#### C: Feet:<n>Feets open<n><n>### Bolded words:<n><n>Word = Feet<n><n>**Sentence:**<n>- He wore the wrong shoess.<n><n>#### C: Exercise:close<n><n>#### Exercse:close  <n><n>#### Exersice:close<n><n>#### D: Blistersclose<n><n>#### D: Walkingclose<n><n>### Categories(if applicable):<n><n>Exercise, Wrong Shoes

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:A common saying, Sam thought, was to go forth, also this. Choices:  A: reverse B: backwards C: back and D: back and E: tally back<n><n>### Response:		 **E** - There are a number of different ways in which one can tally, counting forward and backward can both be considered to be tallying<n><n>### Input<n>While I am able to remember the difference between forward and backward, I can not do it without counting. I find myself always counting by threes to know if I’ve got <n>the number correct or not. That’s why I prefer to count forward when dealing with numbers.<n><n>### Response<n>Given, we want to count in multiple ways, but we are only given two of those ways. One way of counting is by counting by ones. If we wanted to count by seven, it would go like this: 1,2,3,4,5,6,7. We could also decide to count by multiples of three. If we wanted to start at one and count to twelve, it would go like so: 1,3,6,9...12,36,.... These are two of the many ways we can count.<n><n>### Input (incomplete)<n><n>I was able to easily remember 11 + 11 in my head which means 2 + 2 x 5 x the number on which the 2 and 5 are multiplied. 2 x 7 = 14 3 x 5 = 15 4 x 5 = 20 5 x 5 = 40 6 x 5 = 30<n>6 x 14 = 84<n>But I cannot recall 43 x 14 without counting which I did out loud.<n><n>### Rational<n>When I have to know how many seconds are in a minute or how many minutes are in an hour I do not need to put numbers into my head. I can easily remember (43 x 12) which is 516 and <n>then subtract that by 14 to get 43 x 43 = 1822 -14 = 1808.<n><n>### Summary<n>I found the task to be slightly more difficult than the first one. At first I assumed the task was asking how many minutes there were in 2 hours, as the number 2 appears to the right of <n>the sub-traction equation. When I read that it was 14 minutes I was very
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:A shower is an expected amenity when you reserve a what? Choices:  A: gy mnasiu m B: motel room C: seashore D: bath room E: locker room<n><n>### Response:		<n>If you go to the beach, you'll probably want to reserve a motel room.<n><n>### Why:<n>You should reserve a motel room because motels are commonly associated with beach vacations, but it may not be logical when you go to the beach.<n><n>### Solution:<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Residential bathrooms commonly have showers (for showering), but motel rooms also have showers (for guests who go to the beach). Additionally, motel room showers often are associated with beach vacations because motels are associated with beach vacationers.<n><n>### Input<n>You are 14 and it is your birthday. A: <n>You are in 7th grade and you are about to turn 14. <n>B: <n>You are 1 of 8 siblings that all have the same age because they were born on the same day, but each child has a different mother. <n>C: You’re 14-years-old?! I guess you’re old enough to drive! <n>D: You just turned 14 and you’re in 8th grade now. <n>E: Well, I’m turning 14 this year.<n><n>### Answer:<n>A<n>Answer: <n>Response:<n>* You are about to turn ‭14 because you are 14 now and you are not in 8th grade anymore. Therefore, you're not 14 now and not in 7th grade.<n>* You're turning ‭14 because it's your birthday - I bet ‭it’s ‭so much fun!

So it must be: independent.<n><n>### What type of variables are you testing in this study?<n> <n>__A: Independent__<n>__B: Controling__<n>__C: Independent__<n>__D: Controlling__<n>__E: Non Controling__<n>__F: extraneous__<n>__G: None__<n>__H: Predicatior__<n>__I: Dependent__<n>__J: Cost__<n>__K: Weight__<n>__L: Type__

Choices:  A: make B: raise C: entice D: build E: fix<n><n>### Response:		<n>The Answer is: D.Build<n><n>### Explanation:<n>The choice of B is incorrect since the word building is meant to build something.<n>The options C and E are incorrect since this word only entices something but not repair or build something. Moreover, A is incorrect since making something is an expression used as a verb.<n>Thus, D, which means to construct or build something is the correct option.<n><n>### Choices:  A B C D E F<n><n>Choices:  A B<sup>1</sup> C<sup>2</sup> D<sup>3</sup> E<sup>4</sup> F<sup>5</sup><n><n>### Input : Anita 44, Amanda 38 and Ashley 31 how old are they if Anita is younger then the sum of Amanda and Ashley? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:They wanted to eat at home but the cupboards were barren, so they had to go what? Choices:  A: cook dinner B: eat C: go back to work D: make food E: get food<n><n>### Response:		Answer: A<n><n>### Explanation:<n>#### A: cook dinner<n>Cook dinner means they will cook.<n>If the cupboards are barren, then they cannot cook.<n><n>#### B: eat<n>Eat means they will have to go somewhere so they can eat.<n>If Jan's cupboards are barren then she would not go to eat because she would be starved.<n><n>#### C: go back to works<n>If they go back to works, then they would not be able to have time to eat since would be still busy working in work.<n><n>#### D: make food<n>If they make food, it means they have to prepare a food with their cooker. If she does not have cooker then it would be difficult for them to make food.<n><n>#### E: get food<n>Get food means getting more food by purchasing some food. If they already have food but there is less food then it would be difficult to buy more food because they do not have enough money to purchase more food.<n>Therefore, choose answer answer: A<n><n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What would you do if you have curiosity about something but cannot leave your house? Choices:  A: hear testimony B: go somewhere C: see exhibits D: outdoor concert E: surf net<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>**Option (C)**. You would either hear testimony or see exhibits if you cannot leave your home. There is a problem though. How can one exhibit something to another exhibit when they are both at home? It is too far-fetched. You can also try surfing the net, but that is not what you are concerned about. You have to see an exhibit, you don't want to hear testimony. Testimony, as I assume you know, can be seen anywhere. But since you are home, you want to see exhibits. But unfortunately, you have chosen wrong, because exhibits are something that is mostly located in museums, or any other outdoor places. So, option (C) is wrong.<n><n>Now, let's get on track with our answer. Option (B) is probably correct. It is something that can be achieved at home as well, except that hearing testimony needs a judge, lawyer or other officers in the court to hear it. However, for option (B), I will show you my answer below:<n><n>```<n>Answer: (B) hear testimony<n>```<n><n>### Test:The diagram below shows the locations of six points and a line segment on the grid. The number in each circle represents the number of miles to any point.<n><n>### Note:You should not be able to see the answer choices.  The multiple choice answers are listed below.<n><n>### Answer A:  The line segment AB is part of a circle with a radius of 3.<n><n>### Choices:  A circle with a radius of less than 3 B a circle with a radius 3 C a circle with a radius greater than 3 D a circle with a radius less than 3 E a circle with a radius equal to 3<n><n>### Response A: Circle with radius of 3, in case you are confused about the radius of the Circle, it denotes the distance from one section (edge) of the circle to the other section (edge) of it.<n>A circle with a radius of more than 3.<n>B-D are incorrect since the line segment AB is part.  Therefore, Answer A is correct.<n><n>### A: The line segment AC is part of a circle that touches the grid.<n><n>### B:  The line segment CD is part of a circle whose radius is 2.

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where would you get a bag after someone fills it with clothes? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where would you put a handle if you want to bring it with you? Choices:  A: briefcase B: coffee cup C: carry object D: frying pan E: on a hat<n><n>### Response:		Carry Object<n><n>### Rationales: If your briefcase has a handle that allows you to bring it with you, is it a briefcase? No. Is a coffee cup is a container that has a cap handle? Yes. But what is a Coffee Cup not? Is a Coffee cup, not, a Carry Object? Yes.<n>#### Yes (Carry Object)<n>### Choices: B: Briefcase (Carry Only)<n>### C: Carry Object (Handle)<n>### D: Coffee Cup (cap handle)<n>### E: Hat (Handle) (Not a Handel if it is not Carry Object)<n><n><n>### Exercises:<n><n>1. If I add 10 to x, then 1 to y, the result is (10x -1 + y). What is x and y? I will show you.<n>2*x = y<n>10x -1 = 9x<n>9 = y<n>1 = x<n><n>#### 4 = 9 = 1
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:while luck plays a big role, every person who is great at something has focus and what to it? Choices:  A: hatred B: surprised C: compliments D: dedication E: solutions<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Justification: every person who is great in something have to dedicate that one thing and focus on it.<n><n>### Explanation: Luck plays a big role for some people, others it is focus and dedication <n>```python<n>while luck plays a big part it does not always work in their favor...<n>while some people are really lucky it may not have to work hard to achieve the things they want to have.<n>there are also those who have skills at something but what makes them stand out in their chosen career is their focus and dedication.<n>```<n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input:(1)The first three digits of a two-digit base 10 number are the last three digits of the number. How many two-digit numbers are there with this property? Choices: 1: 5 2: 6 3: 9 4: 16 5: 24 6: 18<n><n>### Response:(6) 18<n><n>#### 134<n>Answer: 134<n><n>### Input::1.How many two-digit numbers begin with 6 and have digits that total 20? 2.How many two-digits numbers have the digits of the tens digit that is evenly divisible by 3? (Rules: Use numbers only.)<n>#### 7<n>Answer: 7<n><n>### Input:--1.You start with an eight ball, and you add it to your pocket every time you have a total of seven. If you lose you need to start again. After 73 rolls you have seven. What is the total number of 7 you have had during the game? 2.Say you play 90 games and win 195. What is you total number of 7?<n>### Demonstators:<n>1-<n>```python<n>You start with an eight and everytime you get seven in the previous ones you add then it<n>in your pool<n>if you losse you need to start again and you got 7 in the previous ones you need to start over again<n>so if you did 73 times or you have 7 as total 73 times you will get 7<n>```<n>```python<n>- 7<n>**Answer: The total number of 7 we have after 73
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What chore might a child have to do after breakfast, before getting on the bus? Choices:  A: drop out of school B: ask questions C: enter school D: wash dishes E: read book<n><n>### Response:		What chore might they have to do?<n><n>#### A<n>C: enter school<n><n>#### B<n>A: drop out of school<n><n>#### C<n>D: wash dishes<n><n>#### D<n>E: read book<n><n>#### E<n>None of the choices<n><n>### Answer:What chore might that child have to do?<n>Answer: None of the choices<n><n>#### None of the choices<n>C: enter school.<n><n>#### D: wash dish.<n><n>#### E: read book<n>None of the choices. <n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where can someone view a county highway as a line? Choices:  A: from the sky B: map C: cross counties by car D: country E: michigan<n><n>### Response:		The answer is map.<n><n><n>Given that you are a student in MSC who just got admitted into a community group to read together after work to discuss and improve your presentation skills by sharing what you have learned. As you gather in the community read together area, you discover the community group leader is missing. As you look around for her, you discover the community read room which used by the community was open. The room is full of chairs, tables, bookshelves, cabinets, and a big desk surrounded by open bookshelves. The open bookshelves cover the four walls and have 20 books on some of the bookshelves. All of the bookshelved and the wall are white. You decide to write a quick note to your group leader to let her know you can’t stay for book club, and so you’ve decided to head back to work. As you write your note, you see she already left her note on how the community room has 20 books in it. At 5 o’clock the door is still open. When you walk in there is a cabinet next to the desk and a table full of chairs covered by 20 blue blankets. Behind the cabinet, you see a 6 bookshelf filled with more books. After you leave the community read area to head back to work, you see there are no desks in the community read area. You now must answer the question: "How many bookshelves, and blue blankets are in the community read area?"<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: The community read area has four walls.<n>Open bookshelves has 20 books.<n>The community room contains 6 bookshelves, a desk covered by open bookshelving, a cabinet, and a table full of 20 blue blanket.<n>The community room has 5 bookshelves with 50 books.<n>There is no desk.<n>There are no blue blankets.<n>### My rationales: The community read area only contains one cabinet, one table and 8 bookshelves so there can’t be 80 books. They can’t leave the community room because there is no desk. 6 - 6 = <<6-6=0>>0 Bookshelves with 6 books.<n>5 -2 = <<5-2

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What is another term for instituting civil action? Choices:  A: confusion B: complications C: riot D: arrest E: protests<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer:  D<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Sixth sense of "riot": (archaic)  The legal prosecution and punishment of an offender by the law of the land for an act done maliciously or violently, or otherwise of a criminal nature, or by an injurious act, or with negligence.  Rationales: The  civil action here is not a legal process, but a violent action.<n><n>```<n>1: D<n>2: B & C<n>3: C<n>4: D<n>5: E<n>```<n><n>### Instructions:Complete the task.<n><n>### Task Instructions:<n>Please find the word <n><n>### Exam Instructions: <n>Please use a dictionary to define the words and write your answers.<n><n>### Directions:Write the correct form of the word given.<n><n><n>### Instrument:<n>How do you ______ a piece of paper onto a picture?
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where would I put a rosebush if I did not have any containers to store it in? Choices:  A: flower garden B: garden center C: pot D: pot E: formal garden<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: flower garden<n><n>### A. Rationales<n><n>#### Flower garden<n>Roses like warmth and do not grow where there is frost. For that reason, rosebushes do not grow in containers or pots. They only grow in garden patches.<n><n>### B. Rationales<n>Since it is unclear what type of flowerbush or floral arrangement could be in the garden. We should assume that there could be a flower garden (A)<n><n>#### Pot<n>There will be no need to buy a flowerpot as it should be included with the price of the rosebush. This choice is invalid since it leaves out too much information.<n><n>#### Pot (E)<n>This option is invalid as well. Since there exists no flowers that are grown in pots or pot-based arrangements, only flower patches exist.<n><n>#### Formal Garden<n>This is a nonsensical option since it doesn’t tell in any clear way where a rose bush, potted or not, could potentially be placed. <n><n>### C. Rationales<n>Pot:<n>The pot would not be a fitting location for a rose bush, as there would be no room in a pot that small for a rose garden. Pot (D) is another option that has to be rejected as well - this option, like the formal garden (E), is not a possible answer. (The rose garden is also a place where there is no space for rose bushes as it’s a garden, not a flower pot).<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where in a town would you put your shed? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where in your entrance hall can you keep you head wear? Choices:  A: school B: large home C: house D: hat rack E: closet<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct answer choice is: C: house.<n><n>### Input and Output:An animal can run an average of 42 miles per hour.<n><n>### A.  Find its average speed<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Since the animal runs an average of 48 miles per hour, it runs at<n><n>    (48 miles per hour)  in 1 hour.<n><n>and<n><n>    (42 miles per hour)  for 2 hours.<n>    (42 / (2 * 3600))<n><n>As a result, the correct answer choice is: 4 hrs.<n><n><n>### B. How far does a fox run from its den to find food?<n><n>### A fox finds its food at a distance of less than 5 miles. The fox eats twice as many mice as the fox can digest.<n><n>### Let the fox's ability to find the food is represented by "X" which is 4.2 times greater than it's ability to digest<n><n>### the mice it can eat which happens to be 0.2.<n><n>### An animal can run an average speed of 48 miles/hour, so we can find how many mice the fox can eat in 1 hour by dividing 48 by 0.2. So there are 240 mice.<n><n>Now, we must find how many miles (42 miles per hours) the fox runs from its den.<n><n>### 48/0.2 is 240 <n><n>### 240/42 is 5.6.<n> <n>### So, the fox runs about 5.5 miles to the den to find food.<n><n>#### Input: What's the best color to wear to a wedding?<n><n>### Incorrect choice:B.  A black dress.<n><n>### Correct choice:A. A white dress since bride and groom must be the center of attention in contrast of everyone and everything.<n><n>### Answer: A white dress.<n><n>## Input and Output:A bird can eat 24 grains of wheat. An old cow eats twice as many grains as the bird. How many grain of wheat does the cow eat
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:If I wanted to see a lizard in its natural habitat but I do not speak Spanish, where would I go? Choices:  A: utah B: south america C: new hampshire D: japan E: new mexico<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: If I wanted to see a [lizard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lizard) in its natural habitat but do not speak Spanish, I need to go to New Mexico.<n>Rationales: New Mexico is the only southwestern state in the United States that are not in Mexico.<n>I also need to go to the state that is closest to Texas where I do not have to know Spanish because there I will see a lot more reptiles (both lizards and snakes).<n><n>## Problems:<n>1.	**C:** 150. Brenda has 150-9=<<150-9<===141>>141 cards since Janet has nine more than Brenda. The total of these cards is \(141+55+41=247\).<n><n>150. I will answer C for the multiple choice question.<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Sarah opened his chest and found a second heart. How many people are in this household?<n><n>### Response<n>I'd say 221 people are in this household.<n><n>### Rationale: The difference between 121, 40, and 81 is 40. There are 2 more differences in the set, so there are 41. However, there are 2 fewer people, so there are 22 people in the house.<n><n>### Solution<n>Let `x = number_of_people`<n><n>### Then `x - 2 = twice_number_of_people - 120`<n><n>### Rearranging this equation gets us `x - 2 - 2(twice_number_of_peoples) + 120 = 0`<n><n>## A Problem Solving Activity<n><n>Complete the following activity by determining which choice would be an appropriate response for the teacher's request.<n><n>## Directions:<n><n>Answer the following multiple choice questions below:<n><n>### Which of the following is closest to 181418351859187191219754983?<n><n>### Which number is next in this pattern?1643206860730188758151258544703<n><n>### Which is the smallest integer?11679941274892<n><n>### Which word is the prefix of "reality"?ReaReAl<n><n>### Write the definition that best describes the underlined in the sentence below:<n><n>## If you need to convert to a number in scientific notation, put a decimal point in front of the non-zero digits in the answer.<n><n>## How big is the number with this definition?The number is between 1 and 10.<n><n>### Answer to this exercise: 0.3<n><n>### In which of these expressions is the coefficient of x the greatest?c) 5^2 - 4

Input: 1,2,64.  Input: 4. Input: 14. Input: 5,3,46. Input: 59. Input: 97,7,35.<n>Rationale: Maximum total price of the two items is the sum of minimum prices of the individual item and maximum prices of each item. If the maximum price is < maximum price of individual item, the individual item is greater. For the list of inputs, we can determine the maximum total price for the two items. We can determine for each input list to be a set for the group with < in the set.<n>- Input: 1,7 and 64 Input: 64 + input = 64 + 1 = 65 + 1 = 1 for which 64 = 2 = 1 and for which 64 + 7 = 64 + input64 + 64 + 65 = 66 + 65 = the individual item is 66. - Input: 14 and 14 Input: 14 + 14 = 15 + 1 = the individual item is the set 1 and the set is 15 Input: 14 - input: 0 = the individual item of <n>  - Input: 5 + 3 + 46 = for which 46 + 0 + 0 = 46 + <46 + <= 0 = <= the individual item < = to the individual item of 46 <= the group for which the individual item for 46 + 22 = = 48 <= the individual item. - Input: 97 + 7 = 2 for which each item > the entire inputs. - Input: 5, 3,46 + 59 = the same as 3,46 and 8 = 46 + and 8 < 59 = 97 + and < 7

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What do humans take in while breathing? Choices:  A: lungs and diaphram B: oxygen C: abdominal muscles D: air E: open throat<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is letter E.<n><n>### Detailed explanation:<n>Choice A is incorrect because the lungs and diaphragm are part of the respiratory system, not part of a human's breath. They control the lung which help the body to breathe, they don't breathe themselves. Choice B is incorrect because oxygen is a component and not something which we take in while breathing. Choice c is incorrect because abdominal muscles are not responsible for breathing. They help you maintain posture. Choice D is incorrect because the open throat is only involved in some breathing processes, not in general breathing. Choice E, on the other hand, is correct. We inhale air so that we can breathe.<n><n>### Example of incorrect answers:<n>Letter A is incorrect because the lung is part of the respiritory system while it is not part of breathing process.<n>Letter C is incorrect because muscles control the motion, it doesn't breathe.<n>Letter D is incorrect because the air is only one of the components of air which we can breathe and it also is incorrect because it's a direction rather than a component.<n><n>### Response that uses rationales<n><n>#### Answer: E<n><n>### E: Open throat<n><n>## Contributors:<n>#### Diane Kwan<n>#### <n>

Therefore, the correct answer is "legroom."<n><n>### Discussion:<n>There are always two or three ways to complete an instruction. Some of them are correct while the others are incorrect.<n>Be aware of that difference.<n><n>#### 1190<n><n>Answer:<n>legroom<n><n>### Input 2:Rewrite this English phrase using the symbols >, <, =. Give the formula for G(x, y).<n><n><n>Answer:<n><n>>n>r<n><n>B. What is n?<n><n>C.  What is m? What is k?<n><n>D.  What is x and y?<n><n>E.  Give n^2 < m < n.<n><n>### Input3:Input a 4-digit number. Start with an example by describing what to do as you would do it.<n>2.  After explaining the first step, write the next one (2).<n>3.  Write the next one and explain (3), etc.<n>4. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:John is a human who is in a wheelchair due to an accident.  Where would he go to get to the third floor of his apartment building? Choices:  A: space shuttle B: detroit C: stairs D: downtown E: elevator<n><n>### Response:		<n>I would choose the elevator to the third floor of the apartment building.<n><n>### Output:<n>Input:<n><n>Janet has 9 cards less than Brenda.<n>A: Janet has 55 cards.<n>B: Mara has 55 cards.<n>C: Brenda has 55 cards<n>D: 211 cards<n><n>### Demostartion Response:<n>Input:<n>This example says,<n>John is a human who in a wheelchair is due to an accident.<n>Where would he go to get through the third floor of his apartments building?<n><n>Choices are<n> space shuttle B :<n>Detroit<n> C: Stairs D: Downtown<n> E: Elevator<n><n>### Answer:<n>A) : space shuttle<n><n>### 211<n>A : space shuttle B Detroit <n><n>### Rules<n>Useful when I want to solve the problem.<n>-  If I use all three methods for any step then, I will get the same answer.<n>-  I will also make sure that no more than three of my cards have the same number.<n>-  I can't use the same card to solve more than once problem at a time<n>-  I will not move less than three of my cards at a time.<n><n>To get points for this assignment :<n><n><n>**Rule 1 of 4:**<n>When I solve the problems, I will use at least three of the methods listed on the right side of the chart.<n>| Name  | Method  |<n>|-|-|<n>| 1) Subset, superset or both.  | Using one or more subset or superset as my start point.<n>| 2) Multiply or divide a number.  | Using at least one multiplier or divisor.<n>| 3) Shuffle only two cards.  | Shuffling the top two cards and putting the bottom two cards back in their original place.<n>| 4) Reorder or rename more than two cards. | Changing the order or the name of more than two cards.<n>| 5) Swap two cards. | Swapping the values of two cards.<n><n>**Rules for Subset, supersets, and multipliers & divisors will apply:**<n><n>Subset:

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:One might find theirs open, with the letters that had been delivered stolen. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where are a lot of offices in New York? Jan has 1,000 - 18 = 982. She is 82 cards less than Mara.<n><n>####82

He searched and found a cafe.<n><n>### Rationale: <n>A) A: No, it's not.<n>The advertisements show a price when the bitcoins are sold. <n>B) B: Yes, it is.<n>The bitcoins are a currency and the news show bitcoin prices and it can contain tips on how to use bitcoins.<n>C) C: No, it't not.<n>A bar can be a place to buy or sell bitcoins and it contains cash, alcohol and food. <n>D) D: No, it'ss not.<n>An internet site can show the bitcoin prices but there are no drinks, alcohol or food.<n>E) E: Yes, it's.<n>A cafe can be a place to trade bitcoins and it has food, alcohol and drinks. Choices:  A: rock band B: sea of japan C: sushi restaurant D: fish market E: atlantic ocean<n><n>### Response:		He found the blowfish OFF THE COAST OF the Carolinas, it was at the ATLANTIC OCEAN... The question you asked has no choices only a question. Try again.<n>####<n><n>## Required<n><n>- At least 1000 characters<n>- Maximum 2000 characters<n><n>## Optional<n><n>- Bulleted, numbered, and/or bullet pointed information<n>- Markdown formatting (a href, i, b, etc.)<n><n>### Markdown Tips<n>- #### H1 - H6 are headings, they are also bold<n>- H1 is the biggest and H6 is the smallest<n>- # Headings can be done in a list<n>- Lines that start with ### are bulleted<n>- Lists that start with numbers or dashes are ordered<n>- Lines  with asterisks are unordered lists<n>- Lists start with * or -<n>- Indented lines are bullets<n><n>### Optional<n><n>- [HyperLink Text](link_text.com)<n>- [Image link here](images/name_of_the_image.jpg "A description of the image title")<n><n>## Extra Credit<n><n>- You could include some additional relevant details<n>- You could include 5-7 short sections of paragraphs<n>- You could include a brief diagram<n>- You could include any additional relevant details<n>- Extra credit is anything above the minimum requirement, its completely optional<n><n>### Final Word<n><n>Good job!<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What area is likely to contain a large village? Choices:  A: rural area B: big city C: suburbs D: ohio E: countryside<n><n>### Response:		D<n>Rationales: The area where a village will be found will likely be in a countryside.<n><n>### Input1:<n>A large village is likely to be found in a rural area.<n><n>### Response1:<n>A<n><n>### Input2:<n>A village may be found in suburbs.<n><n>### Rationales2:<n>A village will likely be found in a rural or small town area. A village in cities can be called a neighborhood. Therefore, a village is more likely to be found in suburbians.<n><n>### Output:<n>A<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:She a deep love for all her friends, every Friday she had an open invitation for them as she loved to host and what? Choices:  A: wait for B: eat out C: entertain D: please parents E: paint<n><n>### Response:		EAT OUT<n>Demonstration:<n>She has deep love for all her frenes, every friday she has an open invitation as she love to host and?<n><n>### Input : She a deep love for all frens she entertains every fridey, she has a deep love for her frenes, she every friday has an open invitation?,<n><n>### Rationals:<n>She entertains every Friday, as she has deep love for all frends. She has open invitation for them every Friday because she love to host & entertain them. <n>She has deep love & respect for all her frentds, & she has deep love for frends, hence she has an open invites for them & she entertains every Friday.<n><n>__A deep love - for __frens__ - is to - entertain every - fridey_________.<n><n>- A: eat out - - <n>- D: please parents -  <n>- B: wait for - <n>- E: paint -  <n>- C: entertain<n><n>#### C<n>Answer :C<n><n>### Explanation :  <n>- A is wrong since she has deep love for her friends, but she only entertains every friday.<n>- B is wrong since wait for is about waiting for the guests, not about making some arrangements for the party.<n>- D is wrong since it is to entertain the friends and not her parents. <n>- E is wrong since she has no intention to paint.<n>- C is the correct one of all since entertain is to invite guests and hosts a party in return to the love she has for her friends. <n><n>### Instructions: Answer this question with a response.<n><n>### Input  :She had a party to entertain and her parents and she painted the wall and she served them food. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The circus monkey waived a white surrender flag, the conductor joked the monkey must work in the what? Choices:  A: french government B: friend's house C: zoo D: south africa E: madagascar<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: A<n>			<n>#### A<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n><n>## Task:<n><n>### Instructor:<n><n>How do we show a task, and how do we write out a task. An instructor should use a combination of the following methods:<n><n>1. Write instructions using one of the [NARRATIVE](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Narration_(rhetoric)) [METHOD]( https://en.wikipedia.or g/wiki/Paradigm), [ENUMERATION]( https://en.wikiped ia.org/wiki/Enumeration), or [DIAGRAM]( https://en. wikipedia.org/wiki/Diagram) styles.<n>2. Use a [LIST]( https://en.wiki pedia.org/wiki/List) and add an [ANSWER]( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Answer) to it.<n>3. Write multiple sentences into a paragraph.<n>4. Write several instructions, one for each of the following:<n>	1. Instruct the problem<n>	2. Instruct the solution<n>	3. Instruct the answer<n><n>### Instrument:<n><n>These are the most used ways to write instructions:<n><n>To create a list and an answer,<n><n>  #### 1<n><n>### Demo:<n><n>1. An informative list<n><n>An informative list is a list that only provides information and leaves out writing solutions or answers.<n>  - [ ] Task<n>    - [ ] List of Instructions<n>    - [ ] Answer<n><n>2. A task list<n><n><n>The task is a list of instructions and answers at the same time.<n>  - [X] Task - List of instructions and answers.<n><n>3. A problem with a solution<n><n><n>To summarize the task and the solution by writing [ANSWERS](https:// en.wikipedia.org/ Wikipedia/Answers) and using [LISTS](https://en. wiki pedia.org/wikipedia/List).<n><n>- [X] Task <n>  - [ ] List of tasks<n>  - [ ] Answer to the task<n><n><n>## Solution:<n><n>### Instrutor Solution:<n>Instructor's Solution:<n><n>#### 216<n><n>

Which of the following could she purchase with her money? Choices: A: sneakers B: 1 3 C: 1 6 D: 1 24<n><n>### RESPONSE:<n>While Janet has 2 6-cent coins, she cannot buy many sneakers.<n>20 6-cent coiins would be worth $2.10<n><n>#### 24<n>Janeet is in the store and she has to buy sneakers to buy for $1.24.<n><n>#### 16<n>Janeet is still at the store and she has $35.30. She has spent $1.24 and still has $35.20.<n><n>#### C<n>Answer:<n><n>### Demionstration : how to answer the question : what is the ratio of the amount of money Jane has after she bought 3 pairs of sneakers and the original amount of money she had?<n><n>### Input question : what is the amount of money Jane originally had? Choices: A:$10<n>B:$20<n>C:$30<n>D:$40<n><n>Answer : 40<n><n>### Answer<n>RATIO = A / B<n><n>#### A<n>After 3 pairs of snake, she has $39. She is $1 better now. (1)<n><n>#### B - 1<n>After 3 pairs, she buys 3. She is 1 better than B ( 39 - 38 ) and B is 1 less then D.<n><n>#### B -6<n>The ratio is B/D -6<n><n>#### C<n>If she buys 2 pairs, she is $10 better. She spent $19 and has $10 more now. 19 / 10<n><n>#### D<n>After buying 2 pairs, The ratio is B/C -2.<n><n>#### C<n>R
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where above your kitchen sink could you store canned food? Choices:  A: cupboard B: oven C: grocery store D: pantry E: cellar<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Rationales:The answer is [&apos;C&apos;] because canned food is stored below cupboard.[&apos;Cupboard&apos;] canned food can also be stored in [&apos;the pantry&apos;], not the [&apos;cellar&apos;] as mentioned in the choices.<n><n>### Input:"The cashier is giving you 23% off. How much was the item before?" Choices: A: $7.50 B: $3.50 C: $3 D: None of these.<n><n>### Response:[&apos;D&apos;] <n><n>### Input:[&apos;Tiffany is buying a new suit. How much does she need to have to buy it? Chooses: A: $5 B: $1 C: $10 D: None of these..]<n><n>### Rationale:I believe [&apos;None of these..&apos;] should be answered since [&apos;Titian can’t have the suit without the price..&apos;].
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where is a road known as a motorway? Choices:  A: scotland B: europe C: race track D: new jersey E: england<n><n>### Response:		Answer that is most appropriate to the question.<n><n>## Instruction:<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions. Use the drop down menus to provide answer choices. Each question has a list of four options; choose the best answer to each question.<n><n>## Demonstration:  <n>*Input:What is the lowest temperature ever recorded in Kansas? _Choices:_ _1._	38 degrees fahrenheit _2._ 34 degrees fahrenheit _3._ 58 degrees fahrenheit<n><n>*Output:What is the lowest weather temperature ever reported in Kansas? _Chooses:_ _1._ 38 degrees fahrenheige _2._ 37 degrees fahrenheit _15._ 25 degrees fahrenheit

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:How might compassionate thoughful be described as being? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The teachers needed to get their classrooms ready for the school year.  What is one thing they might do? Choices:  A: talk too much B: teach children C: open boxes D: answering questions E: giving homework<n><n>### Response:		Giving homework answers the question.<n><n>## 📖 Source Codes:<n>### 💃 Janet<n>```<n>        print("I have one hundred and ten more cards")<n>        for i in range (50-150):<n>          print("Janet has", i,"more cards than Brenda does")<n>        print("Janet has two hundred sixty more cards than Brenda")<n>        for i = 50:<n>          a = b = 9<n>          if i < 150:<n>            b = i<n>            a=i-1<n><n>        print("Jan is 26,30,38 or 47 cards more than Brenda")<n>```<n>###🔖 Brenda<n>```<n>        print('Brenda also has', '55 fewer cards than Jan')<n>        print('Brend has', 55,'fewer cards than Jan')<n>```<n>## 💼  Instructors Notes:<n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:If a person is seeing new things, what do they most often feel? Choices:  A: curiosity B: excitement C: boredom D: wonder E: fear<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Input:'We have a good idea of where we are going.' Choices:  A. Not quite yet.  B. Definitely.  C. Not really.  D. Somewhere in the middle. E. I don't know. <n><n>### Response:'We have a good IDEA of where we are going. <n><n>##<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Give your own examples for each.<n><n>### Rationale(s):<n>1. A: Not quite yet.  For example, when a friend said they'd be at the mall on Saturday at 1:00 p.m., then at 1:04 p.m. had not arrived.<n><n>2. D: Somewhere in the middle For example, when a person is at the mall on the weekend and he is not sure when his friends will arrive.<n><n>### Summary<n>In summary, both statements, not quite yet and somewhere in the middle, are used to provide information in a narrative. However, somewhere in the middle is used when a person expresses uncertainty about the arrival of another person. On the other hand, a person may say not quite yet to express that they are uncertain about when they will act or do something.<n><n>### Input<n>For example, when a person says, 'We will pick you up by Friday, so you can visit the zoo on Saturday.'<n><n>### Response<n>A. We will pick you up not quite yet.<n><n>### The answer is<n><n>### 'Friday.'<n><n>### Input'You'll never know.' Answer:(Use the one on the top)<n>A. I'm certain not.<n>B. I don't care.<n>C. I hope I never will.<n>D. I guess it depends.<n>E. I surely will.<n><n>### Response:(Use the one that is correct)<n>F. I hope I never do.<n><n>### Answer:F

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What does one chop us a grape for? Choices:  A: fresh fruit B: wine press C: fruit basket D: fruit cocktail E: picnic basket<n><n>### Response:		<n><n><p>What does one chop of us a grape fruit cocktail for?</p><n><n>* Answer: B<n>* Rationales: Grape (fruit) => choose B<n><n>### Input<n><n>Four years ago, Sammie was 3 times Jack’s age and 1 year younger than Kara. Now Sammie is 5 years older than Jack and 4 years younger than Kara. How old is Jack now?<n><n>#### Rationales:<n><n><n><p>Four years ago, Kara’s 1 year younger than Jack and 3 times Jack’a age, her age is 4 years younger than Jack’s age now.<n>Sammie is 5 years younger than Jack, but is 3 times Jack’ age. Since Sammie is 3 times Jack, Jack is 1/3 his age</p><n><p>So now, Jack is 1 year older than his age 3 years ago</p><n><n><p><label>Four years ago: </label>Kara’s age: Kara is Jack-3 =<<Jack-3=Kara>>1 year younger than Jack<n>Sammie’s age: Sammie-5 =<<Sammie-5=Kara>>4 years younger than Jack<n></p><n><div><n>  <blockquote><n>    <p>Jack now is (Jack-Kara)+Kara =<<Jack-(Kara)]+Kara=Jack-Kara=Jack+Kara >>Jack-Kara+Kara is equal to Jack, so the sum of his age and the age of when he met each of those friends =Jack</p><n>  </blockquote><n></div><n><n><div><n><p>Jack is 1 year older and 4 years younger =<<Jack+Kara-Jack->Kara-Jack>>+4</p><n>  <blockquote><p>That adds up to 1+4 =<<1+4=5>> so Jack is 5 years old</p></blockquote><n></div><div> </div><n><n>### Rationales:<n>A: fresh fruit => pick fruit for yourself; B: wine press => make fruit juice by yourself;<n>C: fruit basket => pick fruit for others, D: fruit cock
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:James was a student who had a report that is due tomorrow.  Where might he spend most of his time today? Choices:  A: university B: college class C: class room D: classroom E: library<n><n>### Response:		<n>James is done with his class and now he must work on his report. He can either go to college class or university class. Now university is where James probably goes to spend most of his time because that is where he needs to turn in his report to.<n><n>### Input : What is the difference of the 5 digit number,48735-258, and the sum of the digits of the number?<n><n>### Response :<n>The difference is: 48735 - 258 = 48477<n><n>### Input<n>The sum of the digits of number is :<n><n>2 5 8 = 15<n><n>### Response<n>Sum of the digits = 15<n>The difference is :<n>48735 \- 15 = 48580<n><n>### Input <n>The sum of the numbers is 394<n><n>### Response <n>Sum of the numbers = 394<n>Subtract the number with 100 = 144<n><n>### Input    <n>98432 + 10482 = 108854 <n><n>### Response  <n>A.98432 \+ 1048 = 108482B.10482 \+ 1168 = 105580C.9843 \+ 1036 = 10961D.6610 = 7610E.1168 =92 8E.76 = 19424

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:If I need deodorant, where do I go to but some? Choices:  A: medicine cabinet B: medicine chest C: armpits D: grocery store E: kitchen<n><n>### Response:		<n>### Rationales: The medicine chest or the pantry is where to find deodorant.<n>### E<n>The pantry and medicine cabinet both have food.<n>The medicine cabinet and the pantry are both in the kitchen.<n>The kitchen contains these objects:<n>- pantry<n>- refrigator<n>- medicine cabinet<n>- cabinet<n><n>### Other Solutions:<n>A: Medicine chest<n>B: Medicine cabinet<n>C: Armpits<n>D: Grocery store<n>E: Kitchen<n><n>### Input :A 4-digit code is used to enter a building.  In the first 2 digits the hundreds digit is given twice.  In the last two digits, the ten thousands digit is given once and the lesser number is given twice.  What is the three-digit code for the entrance?<n><n>### Response :<n>### Rational : In the first two digits, the hundreds digits is twice. That means those first two digits equals to 400. The third digit is 4 and the forth digit is 2. That means that in the ten thousands digit, the ten thousands digit equal to 2. That means the third digit has to be 0.<n><n>### Other :<n>#### Input:A 4-digit extension number is given. The first number is the hundreds digit. The second number is twice the first number. The tens places, the third to fifth digits are the same as in the first. The sixth and seventh digits are both the tens digit from the first digit plus 1.  What is the extension number?<n><n>#### Response :<n>#### Rational : In the second number, the second number is twice the of one. That it why the second number has to equal to 18. In the fifth number, the numbers are in the tens place are the same as in one. In the sixth number, the sixth and number equals to 11. The seventh number is equals to 12 since its is an eleven plus 1. That means that in this example, the extension number is 211.<n><n>#### Other :<n>#### Question: Choose the option below that correctly completes the question.<n><n>#### Input: If you buy 45 apples, 26 oranges, 50 pears, and 32 grapes, how many different pieces of fruit can you

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What prevents someone from getting sleep at night? Choices:  A: relax B: dreams C: have nightmares D: restlessness E: snore<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: What prevents someone from getting sleep (sleep) at night (night)? Choices:     A: relax B:<n>dreams C: have nightmare D: restlessness<n>E: snore<n><n>#### Explanation:<n>Choices (A) and (B) mean relax and dreaming which are not related to sleep.<n><n>Choices (C) and   (D) mean a nightmare and restlessness from a nightmare which refer to sleep in a night.<n><n>Choice (E) means sleeping soundly without sleeping problems caused by snoring, which is related to sleep.<n>Rationales: 1. Choice (A) and (C), which are a relaxation and having a nightmare,  are not related to sleep,  so (A) and (D) <n>are wrong. 2. Choice (E) means sleep soundly, which is related to   sleep, so (E)  is the right answer. 3. To solve this, think first before writing it <n>down. The choices have meaning to the question. 4. So, the correct answer is answer (E).
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:John spent too much money buying products for his swollen testicles.  He did so because he was feeling what? Choices:  A: pleasure B: delight C: bankruptcy D: agony E: owning<n><n>### Response:		<n>1-Pleasures are temporary, but testicles are permanent.<n><n>2-A man is a fool to give what is irreplaceable for what is replaceable.<n><n>3-Lust is better than owning.<n><n>4-One's desire is the end of one's power of understanding.<n><n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Demstration:<n>Input : What happens when 30% of people are 10 % of the people?<n>Output: 40<n><n>30%*30=<<30*30=<9>>9 in a group of 30.<n><n>10%*10=<<10*10=1>>1 person in a group of 10.<n><n>9*1=99 people from 30*10=<<300-9=291>>291 people.<n><n>300-9-99=40 people left from 291.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What do people look for when competing against someone? Choices:  A: edge B: desire to win C: friendship D: rivalry E: skill<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: Competition<n>Answer: B<n><n>### Input:-What is the difference between a pictogram and a histogram?<n>-Choices:A- a picture B- a countC- a bar graphD- a scatterplot<n><n>Answer: Input:-A pictogram shows different frequencies. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Three quarters of what are covered by the ocean? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:When people want to watch a new move, the often go see it at the? Choices:  A: town B: conference C: bathroom D: theater E: train station<n><n>### Response:		Theater<n><n>### Rational:  In the above, the people are going to a theater because they want to watch a new movie.<n><n> <n>### Instruction for this section:<n><n> <n>## Solution<n><ol start='1'><n><li><p>Input: Janet has <b>9 cards more</b> than Brenda. Maras has twice as many cards <u>as Janet.</u> How many cards do they hve in al<i>&nbsp;&quot;if Mara has 4 0 cards less than 30</i><u>&nbsp;&quot;? </u></p></li><n><li><p><b>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Rationales</b>&nbsp;&nbsp; For each card in the hand of Janet, there are 2 in Maras (they are same). The hand of Janet &nbsp; will have 15 + 9 + 15 + 15 = 54 cards. The hand of Brenda has 15 + 2(9 - 1) = 22 cards. The hand of Mara <U>&nbsp;&quot;has 40 cards less</u>&nbsp; than 150(which means: 150 -&nbsp; 40 = <<60>>60 cards). The total&nbsp; cards in the hands of <U>&nbsp;&acute;</u><U>&nbsp;&quot;</U>Janet, Brenda &amp; &nbsp; Mara = 54 +&nbsp; 22 +&nbsp; 60 + 50 =&nbsp; 110. But Brenda has 110 - 9 =&nbsp; << 101>>101 cards.</p></li><n></ol><div><p><b></b><n></p></div><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where would you buy a ticket to sit in a room with a lot of chairs facing the same direction? Choices:  A: conference B: theater C: building D: floor E: church<n><n>### Response:		<n>I would buy a ticket to sit on an E: church floor<n><n>### Input-output Examples:<n><n>### Ex: 1:<n>The first row shows $20 for $15, $9 for $7, $13 for $6, $16 for $18, & $21 for $19. <n>$20, $15, $7; $21, $19; $16, $18; $9, $7; $13, $6<n><n>### Dem.:<n>*$15 * $13 = 195$<n>*$19 * $16 = 304$<n>*$13 * $16 =  208$<n>*$16 * $9 =  144$<n>*$7 * $7 = 49$<n><n>### Explanation:<n>*First, we multiply the left side with the right hand side, and place the result and parentheses next to the row that was multiplied.<n><n>*Then, we start with the ones place ($20) and multiply row with it, next the two's place ($15), then the result ($19), with the 5's place ($7), the rows ($7 * $7 = $49) with it, and so on.<n><n>*Multiplication by zero: ($7 * $7 * $15 * $19 * $13 = $4900$)<n><n>*Multiplying by $144$ gives $28896$<n><n>*Multiply $144$ with each one of the rows gives $ 208-7 * 144 = 208 * 49 * 144 $<n><n>*Total of the whole equation gives $28886$<n><n>### Input and Output Example 2:<n><n>### Input<n><n>*I am having a birthday party. I will serve 200 guests.<n><n>*Each guest will receive a package that is wrapped in paper.<n>*Packages are wrapped in at least two pieces of paper.<n><n>*I will throw out any package that is wrapped in two pieces of paper with designs.<n><n>*I have 220 pieces of wrapping paper.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The keys were black and white, what were they attached to? Choices:  A: front pocket B: cabinet C: purse D: chain E: piano<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>a = input()<n>if a == 'A':<n>    print('A')<n>elif a == 'E':<n>    print('E')<n>elif a == B:<n>    print('B')<n>elif a == C:<n>    print('C')<n>elif a == D:<n>    print('D')<n>elif a == E:<n>    print('E")<n>elif a == F:<n>    print('F')<n>elif a == G:<n>    print('G')<n>else:<n>    print('None')<n>```<n><n>#### Output:<n>```python<n>A front pocket<n>Front pocket<n>B A cabinet C purse D chain E piano<n>Piano<n>```<n><n>### Input::Give the 4th coordinate in the pair of coordinates. Choices: 1) (0, -1, 2, 3) 2) (-1, 0.5, -4, 5) 3) (0, -4, 3, -3) 3) -1, 0, 5, -1 and 4) -3, 1, 2, -4<n><n>### Response<n>```python<n>a=input()<n>if a in [('0', '-1', '2', '3'),('-1', '0.5', '-4', '5'), ('0', '-4', '3', '-3'),<n>       ('-1', '0', '5', '-1'),('-3', '1', '2', '-4')]:<n>    print('true')<n>else:<n>        print('false')<n>```<n><n><n>#### 3 Output:<n>```python

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where could you find a laundry room that is only used by staff? Choices:  A: house B: hotel C: green house D: college E: dorm<n><n>### Response:		House because house is where people live and not in the dorm.<n><n>### Input What is 52 divided by 6? Choices: A: 8 B: 9 C: 10 D: 11 E: 12<n><n>### Response The first digit is a ten so to get 52/6 you would need to move the next digit and the next digit to get 8 because if the first 2 digits are ten then the next digit would be 2 and if you take 2 from 52 you get 50.<n><n>### 52<n>Divided 52 by 6<n><n>The first digit added is a TEN so you do subtraction to get the last digit. Then you move the next digit to its place after the last digit and the last digit you subtract for the DIVISION.<n><n>###<n>Input: What is 10 divided by 3? Choices: A 3 B 1 1/3 C 2/3 D 3 C 3<n><n>### Response 10/3= 3. When you divide you need to take away a digit. There is 3 digits so the first one goes to 3 in which the answer is 3. (100/3=33<n>33/3=11<n>11/3=3<n><n>### 12<n><n>I have 12 pieces of candy and I give 6 to my brother. How much do I have left?<n><n>- 12 - 6 = 6<n>- 6 - 3 = 3<n>- 3 - 2 = 1<n>- 1 - 1 = ____<n><n>### 3<n><n>I have 3 apples and 2 bananas. I have 2 left over. How many do I have left? <n>- 3 apples + 2 bananas = 5<n>- 5 apples + 2 left over = 7<n>- 7 apples + 2  left over =9<br><n><n>###<n><n>###<n>I have _____ bananas. I use 1 and 2. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The artist didn't use many colors to capture the view, he was famous for his very plain what? Choices:  A: landscape B: east side C: countryside D: middle america E: georgia<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```python3<n>#!/usr/bin/python3<n><n>n = int(input("Enter the number:"))   <n>    if n < 1:<n>        print("the number can't be less than 1")<n>    else :  <n>        print("the digit of the number is:",n)<n>        if n > 9:<n>            print("the number greater than 9")<n>        else:<n>            print("number smaller than 9 and even")<n>    exit(0)<n>```<n>    <n><div class = input><n><n>### Sample Output <n>  Enter the number:1<n>  <n>  the number can't be 1 <n>    <n>  Enter the number:-501<n>  <n>  Enter the digit of the number:78<n>  <n>  the digit of the number is 78<n></div><n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>### Demostration<n><n><div class = instructions><n><strong style="font-size: large;"><n><n>### Sample Input<n><n></strong><n><n>123<n><n><strong style="color:red;"><n>Enter the number:<n></strong><n><strong><n><n></strong>   <n><n><strong style ="font-style:none;"><n><n>### Output<n> 13<n></strong><n>  <n>  the word to number conversion is: 1 + 3 = 4<n><n><strong style = "font-size:large;"><n><n>### Sampler output<n><n></strong>12 +3 = 15<n></strong><n></div><n><div class = instruction><n><a href = "https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/1891732/how-do-you-write-an-if-statement-with-an-elif-with-python-3"> <n><n>### Samples output<n>         <a href = "https:math.stackexchange.com:181770"><n>         <a href ="https:math.stackexchange:18173":181773"><n>         <a id="1"><n>         <a><n>         <a href="https:math.stackexchange:"<n>         <a href=""<n>         <a href<n>         <

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What does a judge do when someone is convicted of a crime? Choices:  A: conduct trial B: arrest C: bring in verdict D: pass sentence E: serve justice<n><n>### Response:		Bring in verdict<n><n>### Input:-13=_____<n><n>### Demostration:-13=<<-13=>0>>0<n>#### -13=0<n>Answer: 0, since 13 minus 13 is 0.<n><n>### Input,-9=x<n><n>### Demosrtration:-9=<-9=x>x<n>**-9==<-9=>x>x**  <n>**-9=(-9)x>x**   **-9=(-9x)x**   **-0==-9**<n>#### -0<n>Answer:-0<n>

Given a set of inputs, provide a response that appropriately responds to the request.<n><n>Input: Margo is 20 years less than twice the age of Nate who is five years more than twice the age of Shirley. How old is Margo?<n><n>Rationales: Nate is 10 years more than twice Shirley’s age. Shirley is 5 years more than twice her age.<n>So Shirley is 2 years more than twice her own age. Shirley is 8 years old.<n>Nate is 18 years old. Margo is 2 times the older than Nate.<n>So Margo cannot be less than 2 and not more than 2 times the older age than Nate.<n><n>Nate is 2 times younger than Margo.<n>So Margo’s is older 2 times that 10. So Margo is 2 + 20 = <<2+20=22>><n><n>#### 123<n>Answer: 22<n><n>### 99. Given a set of constraints, develop a response that identifies a solution that meets constraints.<n><n>Input: There are 3 more boys than girls in this classroom. If there are 6 more girls than boys now, how many are there altogether?<n><n>#### 28,29,57<n>Answer: 57<n><n>### Demos:<n><n>Rationales:(3 more boys than girls).So there are 3,1 and 0. If 3,1,0 are not in this class so 1 more than 0, add 1 more.<n>(If there are 6 more Girls than boys now).So there are 6,5,4,3

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where is a snake likely to reside?
